mission: CURATORIAL AND LIBRARY -SEE SCHEDULE O2019 CURATORIAL PROGRAMSTHE SCREEN SHOWFEBRUARY 9 SEPTEMBER 22, 2019ROTHSCHILD GALLERYTHE FARNSWORTH ART MUSEUM RECENTLY ACQUIRED TWO EARLY TWENTIETH-CENTURY FOLDING SCREENS: MANSHIP TOASTING THE ANGELS BY BARRY FAULKNER DONE IN 1923, A DREAM LIKE DEPICTION OF HIS TRIP TO THE WINE COUNTRY OF FRANCE DURING PROHIBITION; AND ONE BY CARROL THAYER BERRY WITH A FANCIFUL VIEW OF CAMDEN HARBOR DONE IN 1930. FOLDING SCREENS WERE ESPECIALLY POPULAR IN THE LATE NINETEENTH AND EARLY TWENTIETH CENTURIES, SERVING TYPICALLY AS ROOM DIVIDERS AND OFTEN USED BY THEIR OWNERS TO DRESS OR UNDRESS BEHIND. PROMINENT ARTISTS, ARCHITECTS, AND DESIGNERS IN BOTH EUROPE AND AMERICA EXPERIMENTED WITH THE FORMAT, INCLUDING JAMES MCNEILL WHISTLER, THOMAS DEWING, LOUIS COMFORT TIFFANY, THOMAS HART BENTON, DONALD DESKEY, ANSEL ADAMS, JIM DINE, HELEN FRANKENTHALER, ROBERT RAUSCHENBERG, AND DAVID HOCKNEY, AMONG MANY. THE MUSEUM'S TWO SCREENS SERVED AS A DEPARTURE POINT FOR THIS EXHIBITION, SEEKING SUBMISSIONS BY MAINE ARTISTS TO CREATE THEIR OWN FOLDING SCREENS. A JURY OF PROMINENT ARTISTS AND CURATORS SELECTED PROPOSALS BY GUGI AEA AND OWAIN HARRIS, ALLA BROEKSMIT, ALISON DAVIS, LAURIE DOWNEY AND RYAN RHOADES, SUSAN LEVETT, AND JOHANNA MOORE. ANDREW WYETH: WITCHES, GHOSTS, AND MISCHIEF SEPT 21, 2019-APRIL 12, 2020HADLOCK GALLERY AT THE END OF EACH SUMMER ANDREW WYETH ENGAGED WITH MAINE'S SHIFTING SEASONS. RESPONDING TO THE ANNUAL CYCLE OF DEATH AND REBIRTH WYETH BLENDED CAREFULLY OBSERVED DETAILS WITH HIS IMAGINATION AND MEMORY. MANY OF THE RESULTING PAINTINGS OF STORMS, WET LEAVES, AND PECULIAR FIGURES BECAME INFUSED WITH AN EERINESS THAT CAN LEAVE VIEWERS UNSETTLED AND QUESTIONING. ""OFTENTIMES PEOPLE WILL LIKE A PICTURE I PAINT BECAUSE IT'S MAYBE THE SUN HITTING ON THE SIDE OF A WINDOW AND THEY CAN ENJOY IT PURELY FOR ITSELF. IT REMINDS THEM OF SOME AFTERNOON. BUT FOR ME, BEHIND THAT PICTURE COULD BE A NIGHT OF MOONLIGHT WHEN I'VE BEEN IN SOME HOUSE IN MAINE, A NIGHT OF SOME TERRIBLE TENSION, OR I HAD THIS STRANGE MOOD. MAYBE IT WAS HALLOWEEN. IT'S ALL THERE, HIDING BEHIND THE REALISTIC SIDE."" (P. 205, UNKNOWN TERRAIN)THE DRAMA AND EXCITEMENT OF HALLOWEEN EXHILARATED WYETH WHO REVELED IN THE SCARECROWS, PUMPKINS, COSTUMES, AND PRANKS OF THE NIGHT WHEN SPIRITS OF THE DEAD CAN SUPPOSEDLY MINGLE WITH THE LIVING. EQUALLY ATTRACTED TO THE FICTITIOUS DR. JEKYLL AND DRACULA AS TO THE ACTUAL GRUESOME HISTORY OF REVOLUTIONARY WAR BATTLES THAT OCCURRED IN HIS OWN PENNSYLVANIA BACKYARD, WYETH COMBINED REALITY AND FANTASY IN HIS PAINTINGS. ANDREW WYETH: WORLD WAR IMARCH 23 LATE 2019WYETH STUDY CENTER GALLERYTHIS EXHIBITION OF WATERCOLORS AND TEMPERAS AFFORDS THE OPPORTUNITY TO SEE HOW ANDREW WYETH'S CHILDHOOD INTEREST IN WORLD WAR I, FUELED BY CHRISTMAS GIFTS OF TOY SOLDIERS, BECAME A LIFE-LONG SOURCE OF INSPIRATION. BORN IN 1917, WYETH WAS TOO YOUNG TO REMEMBER THE WAR BUT IT BECAME REAL TO HIM TO THINGS IN HIS FATHER'S STUDIO. N.C. WYETH PAINTED SEVERAL LARGE-SCALE CANVASES OF WORLD WAR I SUBJECTS, AND COLLECTED UNIFORMS, WEAPONS, AND PHOTOGRAPHS FOR SOURCE MATERIAL. HE ALSO WATCHED KING VIDOR'S EPIC 1925 SILENT FILM ABOUT AN AMERICAN SOLDIER'S EXPERIENCES FIGHTING IN FRANCE, THE BIG PARADE, OVER AND OVER. AS AN ADULT, WYETH BEFRIENDS REAL LIFE SOLDIERIES LINING NEAR HIS HOMES IN CHADDS FORD, PENNSYLVANIA, AND IN CUSHING, MAINE. HE MET FARMER KARL KUERNER IN CHADDS FORD AND DEPICTED HIM THE AGING SOLDER IN THE GERMAN AND PINE BARRON, STUDY. HE ALSO MET RALPH CLINE AT HIS SAWMILL IN SPRUCE HEAD, MAINE, AND DEPICTED HIM IN THE PATRIOT.SLAB CITY RENDEZVOUSAPRIL 13, 2019 MARCH 15, 2020CROSMAN GALLERY IN THE YEARS IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWING THE END OF WORLD WAR II, A GROUP OF YOUNG, AVANT-GARDE ARTISTS BASED IN NEW YORK DISCOVERED, LIKE GENERATIONS OF ARTISTS BEFORE THEM, THE PLEASURES OF SUMMERING AND WORKING IN MAINE. THE PAINTERS ALEX KATZ, HIS WIFE JEAN COHEN, AND THEIR FRIEND LOIS DODD, WHO OWNED A HOUSE ON SLAB CITY ROAD IN LINCOLNVILLE, WERE AMONG THE FIRST. THEY WERE SOON FOLLOWED BY THE PHOTOGRAPHER AND FILMMAKER RUDY BURCKHARDT AND HIS WIFE, PAINTER YVONNE JACQUETTE. THE MULTI-TALENTED PAINTER-SCULPTOR-INSTALLATION ARTIST RED GROOMS CAME HERE WITH HIS WIFE, THE PAINTER MIMI GROSS, AND PAINTER RACKSTRAW DOWNES SOON FOLLOWED. NEIL WELLIVER WAS AN EXCEPTION TO THIS GATHERING OF SUMMER RESIDENT ARTISTS, CHOOSING INSTEAD TO LIVE HERE YEAR-ROUND, COMMUTING TO PHILADELPHIA TO TEACH AT THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA. WHAT THEY FOUND IN AND AROUND THE MIDCOAST VILLAGE OF LINCOLNVILLE WAS A SIMPLE LIFESTYLE THAT OFFERED A WELCOME RESPITE FROM THE OFTEN FRENETIC PACE AND ALL-ABSORBING NATURE OF LIFE IN NEW YORK. AN ADDED BENEFIT WAS THAT IT WAS RELATIVELY INEXPENSIVE TO LIVE HERE, IMPORTANT TO ARTISTS AT THE VERY BEGINNING OF THEIR CAREERS WHEN FINANCIAL SECURITY WAS SOMETHING SOUGHT BUT FAR FROM A REALITY. IMPORTANTLY, THEY ALSO FOUND ATTRACTIVE SUBJECT MATTER FOR THEIR WORK. SEEKING AN ALTERNATIVE TO THE ABSTRACT EXPRESSIONIST STYLES THAT DOMINATED CRITICAL CIRCLES IN NEW YORK, MAINE'S COASTS, ISLANDS, WOODLANDS, AND PEOPLE PROVIDED THE ARTISTS WITH AN OPPORTUNITY TO FORGE NEW DIRECTIONS THROUGH THEIR LARGELY REPRESENTATIONAL WORK BASED ON WHAT THEY SAW AND EXPERIENCED HERE. WHAT THEY CREATED OVER THE COURSE OF THE FOLLOWING DECADES WAS A BODY OF WORK THAT HELPED EACH OF THEM ESTABLISH NATIONAL REPUTATIONS. MOST, LIKE KATZ, DODD, DOWNES, BURCKHARDT, JACQUETTE, AND WELLIVER MADE THEIR WORK IN MAINE A FUNDAMENTAL PART OF THEIR OEUVRE; WHILE FOR GROOMS IT WAS A SPRINGBOARD FOR A LONG AND SUCCESSFUL CAREER LESS DEFINED BY WHERE HIS WORK WAS DONE. THE WYETHS: FAMILY AND FRIENDSJUNE 8 DECEMBER 29, 2019WYETH CENTER, COWAN GALLERYTHIS CONTINUING PRESENTATION FEATURES WORKS BY ARTIST MEMBERS OF THE EXTENDED WYETH FAMILY, INCLUDING FAMILY PATRIARCH N.C. WYETH, HIS SON ANDREW, AND HIS GRANDSON JAMIE. IN ADDITION, THERE ARE WORKS BY MERLE JAMES (ANDREW'S BROTHER-IN-LAW) AND HENRIETTE WYETH HURD (ANDREW'S SISTER, AND HENRIETTE'S HUSBAND, PAINTER PETER HURD. ALMOST ALL OF THESE AND OTHER WORKS ARE FROM THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION.PHYLLIS WYETH: A CELEBRATOINJUNE 7- SEPTEMBER 8, 2019: FARNSWORTH ART MUSEUM, ROCKLAND, MEOCTOBER 2 - DECEMBER 29, 2019: GREENVILLE COUNTY MUSEUM OF ART, GREENVILLE, SCHADLOCK GALLERYFROM THE LATE 1960S ONWARD, PHYLLIS MILLS WYETH (NOVEMBER 13, 1940 JANUARY 14, 2019) WAS A MUSE TO HER HUSBAND, ARTIST JAMIE WYETH. THE SELECTION OF PAINTINGS ASSEMBLED IN THIS EXHIBITION ARE A MEMORIAL TRIBUTE AND REFLECT PHYLLIS WYETH'S VIBRANT SPIRIT AND LOVE OF NATURE, HORSES, AND HER EVER-PRESENT DOGS.INCLUDED ARE 26 PAINTINGS AND DRAWINGS, RANGING FROM THE ARTIST'S FIRST PORTRAIT OF HER (PHYLLIS MILLS, 1967)DEPICTED OUTDOORS AND COVERED IN FALLEN LEAVESTO MORE RECENT WORK, SUCH AS THE LUSHLY PAINTED OVERSLEPT (2018). JAMIE WYETH CAPTURED THE MANY FACETS OF HIS WIFE'S REMARKABLE LIFE, INCLUDING SEVERAL WORKS THAT ATTEST TO HER ACCOMPLISHMENTS IN CARRIAGE DRIVING, SUCH AS INTO THE GORGE (1975) AND CONNEMARA (1984), AND TO HER SUCCESS AS A THOROUGHBRED HORSE BREEDER AND OWNER, MOST NOTABLY IN WINNER'S CIRCLE, BELMONT STAKES (2012), CELEBRATING THE WIN OF HER CHAMPION HORSE UNION RAGS AT THAT ILLUSTRIOUS RACE IN 2012. PAINTINGS SUCH AS CATCHING POLLEN (2012), STEALING HOLLY FROM THE IRNES (2016), AND SOUTHERN LIGHT (1994), ATTEST TO PHYLLIS WYETH'S LOVE OF NATURE AND THE DISTINCTIVE LANDSCAPES SURROUNDING HER AT HOME NEAR CHADDS FORD AND IN MAINE. ALSO ON VIEW IS A SELECTION OF INTIMATE DOMESTIC SCENES, PAINTED AS CHRISTMAS GIFTS FROM HER HUSBAND, AND DEPICTING HER BELOVED DOGS.JAMIE WYETH: UNTOWARD OCCURRENCES AND OTHER THINGSJUNE 8 OCTOBER 27, 2019WYETH CENTER, LOWER GALLERYAN EXHIBITION OF RECENT WORKS BY JAMIE WYETH DATING FROM 2010 THROUGH 2017, IT INCLUDES A SERIES OF WORKS HE HAS ENTITLED SUITE OF UNTOWARD OCCURRENCES ON MONHEGAN ISLAND. INSPIRED IN PART BY DREAMS AND BY HIS LONG-STANDING CONNECTIONS TO MONHEGAN ISLAND AS A SOURCE FOR HIS WORK, HIS SUBJECTS INCLUDE ARTIST ROCKWELL KENT, FRIEND AND SUPPORTER DAVID ROCKEFELLER, AND WORLD WAR II VETERAN AND PRISONER OF WAR HARRY ODOM. THE SHOW WILL ALSO INCLUDE OTHER WORKS, TWO DEPICTING FELLOW ARTIST, ANDY WARHOL.KATHARINE COBEY: A DIFFERENCE VOICEROTHSCHILD GALLERYOCT. 5, 2019- APRIL 12, 2020 KATHARINE COBEY'S WORDS COME FROM HER UNDERSTANDING OF WHAT CERTAIN MATERIALS SUGGEST AS CARRIERS OF IDEAS. FOR HER, WRITING POETRY WAS AN EARLY MEANS TO EXPRESSION. CURRENTLY, KNITTING IS HER CREATIVE PATHWAY, A MIND-TO-HAND WORK THAT SHE ADAPTED FOR UNUSUAL MATERIALS AS A MEANS OF CONSTRUCTING THREE-DIMENSIONAL FORMS. BASIC GESTURES OF KNITTING, UNCOMPLICATED KNIT AND PURL STITCHES ARE THE ESSENTIAL ALPHABET, THE BUILDING BLOCKS THAT GIVE SHAPE TO COBEY'S MATERIALS AND IDEAS. EDUCATION PROGRAM ACCOMPLISHMENTS - SEE SCHEDULE O EDUCATION PROGRAM ACCOMPLISHMENTSTHE FARNSWORTH'S EDUCATION PROGRAMS OFFER NEW PERSPECTIVES ON THE MUSEUM'S COLLECTION, EXHIBITIONS, LIBRARY AND HISTORIC SITES THROUGH THE MULTITUDE OF PROGRAMS OFFERED BY THE EDUCATION STAFF. TOGETHER WITH PARTNERS AND COLLABORATORS, WE OFFER TALKS, TOURS, FAMILY DAYS, ART CLASSES, WORKSHOPS AND MORE. PROGRAMS MAKE CONNECTIONS BETWEEN VISUAL ARTS AND OTHER ART FORMS SUCH AS FILMS, MUSIC, THEATER, LITERATURE AND MORE. OUR PARTNERS ARE DOCENTS, CURATORS, TEACHERS, ART HISTORIANS, CULTURAL HISTORIANS, THOUGHT LEADERS, MUSICIANS, ACTORS, ARTISTS AND PERFORMERS TO NAME ONLY SOME. OUR AUDIENCES ARE BOTH THE BEGINNER IN ART TO THE EXPERT IN ART AND INCLUDE PRESCHOOLERS, K-12 COMMUNITY, EDUCATORS, FAMILIES, RESIDENTS, VISITORS, SENIORS AND YOUNG PEOPLE. WE WELCOME THE PUBLIC BOTH ON SITE AND ONLINE TO INTERACT, IMAGINE AND BE INSPIRED BY THE ART ON VIEW. IN ADDITION, WE HOST A COLLEGE LEVEL INTERN IN THE MUSEUM EDUCATION DEPARTMENT EVERY SUMMER. THE INTERN LEARNS ABOUT MUSEUM EDUCATION, ASSISTS WITH PROGRAMS AND EDUCATION EFFORTS AND WRITES A PAPER SUGGESTING IDEAS REGARDING PROGRAMS THAT THE MUSEUM COULD OFFER. THE ARTS IN EDUCATION PROGRAM FY 2019:IN THE FALL 2018, THE FARNSWORTH BEGAN ITS EIGHTH YEAR OF THE SUCCESSFUL YEAR-LONG STORIES PROGRAM FOR 4TH AND 7TH GRADES. DURING THE TIME PERIOD COVERED IN THIS REPORT, THE MUSEUM WORKED WITH 8 CLASSROOMS AT 6 DIFFERENT SCHOOLS. THIS NUMBERED 16 TEACHERS AND 155 STUDENTS, SEEN MULTIPLE TIMES OVER TEN MONTHS. THE END RESULT WAS A MUSEUM EXHIBITION OF STUDENT WORK, WHICH INCLUDED STUDIES IN MARINE INDUSTRIES, MARITIME HISTORY, SCIENTIFIC ILLUSTRATION OF LOCAL FLORA, FAUNA, AND INSECTS, AND RECYCLING. THE EXHIBITION WAS VIEWED BY OVER 27,000 VISITORS FROM MAY-SEPTEMBER 2019. IN ADDITION, SHORTER MULTI-VISIT UNITS WERE OFFERED TO 8 CLASSROOMS DURING THE FALL AND SPRING OF 2018/2019, REACHING 137 STUDENTS IN GRADES 2 THROUGH 9. THE PROJECTS TOOK PLACE OVER A 4-6 WEEK TIME PERIOD, AND INCLUDED SCIENTIFIC ILLUSTRATIONS OF BIRDS, LOCAL HISTORY WITH CREATIVE WRITING, AND AN ADVOCACY FILM TO RAISE AWARENESS OF ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES AND THEIR IMPACT ON STUDENTS. EXHIBITIONS OF STUDENTS' WORK WERE DISPLAYED IN THEIR RESPECTIVE SCHOOLS.THE ARTS IN EDUCATION PROGRAM ALSO OFFERS A ROBUST PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM CALLED THE EDUCATOR COHORT. THIS PROGRAM HOSTS MONTHLY WORKSHOPS FOR EDUCATORS TO EXPLORE THE FARNSWORTH'S GALLERIES AND ART-MAKING TO CREATE ARTS-INTEGRATION LESSONS WITH THE HELP OF TEACHING ARTISTS AND MUSEUM EDUCATORS. A TOTAL OF 73 TEACHERS PARTICIPATED IN SEVEN COHORT SESSIONS DURING FY 2019.FINALLY, WE CONTINUE TO CREATE INTEREST IN ARTS IN EDUCATION ONLINE, OUR EDUCATION WEBSITE. WWW.FARNSWORTHARTSINEDUCATION.ORG DESIGNED SPECIFICALLY FOR EDUCATORS, WHICH OFFERS FREE ONLINE RESOURCES FOR EDUCATORS INTERESTED IN TEACHING THROUGH THE ARTS IN THEIR CLASSROOM. THE WEBSITE WAS VIEWED 5,805 TIMES DURING FY 2019. SCHOOL AND DOCENT PROGRAMS FY 2019:A CORNERSTONE OF THE EDUCATION DEPARTMENT PROGRAM IS SCHOOL TOURS. DURING THE 2019 FISCAL YEAR, THERE WERE 89 SCHOOL GROUPS THAT VISITED THE MUSEUM FROM AROUND MAINE, TOTALING 2,437 STUDENTS. THESE STUDENTS RANGED FROM KINDERGARTEN THROUGH HIGH SCHOOL, AND EACH GROUP HAD A GUIDED TOUR EXPERIENCE LED BY DOCENTS AND EDUCATION STAFF, AND HANDS-ON ART MAKING EXPERIENCES WHEN REQUESTED. THE MUSEUM'S DOCENT PROGRAM CONTINUED TO MEET TWICE A MONTH DURING THE ACADEMIC YEAR FOR ONGOING TRAINING TO ASSIST WITH THE MANY PUBLIC TOURS. IN ADDITION TO STUDENT TOURS, MUSEUM DOCENTS GAVE A WIDE VARIETY OF ADULT TOURS IN FY 2019: TOURISTS VISITING THE MUSEUM (USING CRUISE LINES, BUS COMPANIES, ETC.) AND SPECIAL GALLERY TOURS FOR ORGANIZED GROUPS, AND FINALLY HIGHLIGHT TOURS FOR GENERAL VISITORS, FOR A TOTAL OF 2,318 PEOPLE. IN ADDITION, DOCENTS ASSISTED IN OFFERING THE MEMORY GALLERY PROGRAM SEVERAL TIMES A YEAR FOR SENIORS LIVING WITH EARLY MEMORY LOSS. PUBLIC PROGRAMS FY 2019 THE FARNSWORTH HELD 27 PUBLIC TALKS AND LECTURE PROGRAMS DURING FY 2019, CONDUCTED BY OUR CURATORIAL STAFF AND GUEST SPEAKERS. SOME HIGHLIGHTS INCLUDED WYETH DAY, FEATURING A CONVERSATION BETWEEN ARTIST JAMIE WYETH AND ART HISTORIAN HENRY ADAMS, AND TALKS BY GUEST SPEAKERS SUSAN DANLY AND MELISSA RACHLEFF FOR THE SPECIAL EXHIBITION, SLAB CITY RENDEZVOUS. CURATOR OF MODERN PRINTS AND DRAWINGS AT THE NATIONAL GALLERY OF ART MARY LEE CORLETT SPOKE ON THE ART OF DESIGNING THE INDEX OF AMERICAN DESIGN, RELATING TO THE EXHIBITION MAINE AND THE INDEX OF AMERICAN DESIGN. A NEW PROGRAM OF MIME-LED FAMILY TOURS IN THE GALLERIES PROVED QUITE POPULAR. OTHER PUBLIC PROGRAM OFFERINGS INCLUDED FILMS, MUSICAL AND DANCE PERFORMANCES, AS WELL AS AN ONGOING COLLABORATION WITH EVERYMAN REPERTORY THEATER TO OFFER DRAMATIC READINGS OF TONY-AWARD WINNING PLAYS. OVERALL, THESE PROGRAMS SERVED OVER 2,500 INDIVIDUALS.THE FARNSWORTH HELD 26 ADULT STUDIO WORKSHOPS AT THE FARNSWORTH'S GAMBLE EDUCATION CENTER IN FY19, WHICH TOOK PLACE YEAR-ROUND, WITH 90 PARTICIPANTS. THESE PROGRAMS INCLUDED, AMONG OTHERS, BOOKMAKING, WATERCOLOR PAINTING, FIELD SKETCHING, RUG HOOKING, AND FELTING. IN ADDITION, THE FARNSWORTH HOSTED 10 FAMILY AND STUDIO PROGRAMS FOR CHILDREN. THESE INCLUDED A COLLABORATION WITH ROCKLAND PUBLIC LIBRARY TO OFFER STORY HOUR AND AN ILLUSTRATION WORKSHOP. IN FY 2019 WE HELD SEVERAL COMMUNITY OUTREACH PROGRAMS, INCLUDING THE MILLAY ARTS & POETRY FESTIVAL IN HONOR OF ROCKLAND-BORN POET EDNA ST. VINCENT MILLAY, HELD IN COLLABORATION WITH MILLAY HOUSE AND ROCKLAND HISTORICAL SOCIETY. PECHA KUCHA, ANOTHER COMMUNITY COLLABORATIVE HELD THREE TIMES A YEAR THAT CELEBRATES THE CREATIVE WORK OF 8 INDIVIDUALS LIVING AND WORKING WITHIN THE MIDCOAST COMMUNITY, PRESENTED TO SOLD-OUT CROWDS AT EVERY EVENT. IN THE SPRING, WE PARTICIPATED IN ROCKLAND MAIN STREET'S SUMMER SOLSTICE, AND OUR ANNUAL FREE FAMILY EVENTS, FALL FAMILY FESTIVAL AND SHARE THE WONDER REACHED WELL OVER 1,500 CHILDREN AND FAMILIES IN THE MIDCOAST. ALL TOLD, THESE PROGRAMS SERVED OVER 2,800 PEOPLE. MUSEUM STORE
reason: The summary focuses on art exhibitions, education programs, and community events without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: Personal Care Assistance - Case management and needs evaluation services by unlicensed specialists for persons with a disability in the State of Maine receiving home and community based personal care assistance. Disabled persons achieve independent livings goals. 1,146 clients served during the fiscal year. Independent Living Services - Federal and state funded programs to provide services that allow persons with a disability in the State of Maine to live independently. Core services provided include information and referrals, peer support, skills training, outreach and individual advocacy. Other services provided include transportation, vocation and recreation. Disabled persons achieve independent living goals. 2,299 client contacts during the fiscal year. Fee Based Services - Architectural, transportation and skills training services for both individuals with a disability and businesses for the purpose of allowing persons with a disability in the State of Maine to live independently. Disabled persons achieve independent living goals. 956 clients served during the fiscal year. Sales and Repairs - Sales, installation and service of home accessibility products such as ramps, lifts, residential elevators and scooters. 135 customers served during the fiscal year.
reason: The summary focuses on providing services for persons with disabilities and does not mention any religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: RESIDENTIAL GROUP HOMES - ORGANIZATION OPERATES THREE GROUP HOMES FOR ADULTS WITH DISABILITIES REQUIRING RESIDENTIAL SUPPORT IN DAILY LIVING IN A CONGREGATE SETTING (2 TO 6 RESIDENTS PER HOME). DAY HABILITATION AND EMPLOYMENT SERVICES - PROVIDES ASSISTANCE TO ADULTS WITH DISABILITIES WITH ACQUISITION, RETENTION, OR IMPROVEMENT OF SELF-HELP, SOCIALIZATION AND ADAPTIVE SKILLS, WHICH TAKES PLACE IN A NON-RESIDENTIAL SETTING AS WELL AS ASSIST WITH OBTAINING EMPLOYMENT, OFFERING ASSESSMENTS, AND JOB DEVELOPMENT. SERVICES FOCUS ON ENABLING THE INDIVIDUAL TO ATTAIN AND MAINTAIN HIS OR HER MAXIMUM FUNCTIONAL LEVEL THROUGH ACTIVITIES CONSISTENT WITH THE INDIVIDUALS PERSONAL PLAN. SHARED LIVING - CONTRACTS WITH HOMEOWNERS IN LOCAL COMMUNITIES TO PROVIDE HOMES FOR INDIVIDUALS WHO WANT TO LIVE IN A FAMILY SETTING. TARGETED CASE MANAGEMENT - CASE MANAGERS ASSIST CHILDREN WITH DISABILITIES TO SECURE SERVICES AND NEEDED SUPPORTS.

mission: The Association exists to encourage and promote the participation, instruction, practice, and advancement of its members in the sport of skating on ice. The Association's programs include, but are not limited to, learn to skate, figure skating, and hockey, and are promoted in accordance with the rules and regulations of each sport's National Governing Body (NGB). The Association also strives to instill the ideals of good sportsmanship, honesty, and teamwork in its members. During 2012, the Skating Association of Maine served approximately 400 children and youth through formal programs and countless more participated in free skates.

mission: THE ORGANIZATION PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR EDUCATION OF THE PUBLIC AND ANIMAL SHELTER EMPLOYEES AS WELL AS SUPPORT TO IMPROVE SHELTERS OF ANIMALS.

mission: ARCafe Local Foods Market provided distribution of over 6,600 lbs. of vegetables and over $30,000 in earnings for 8 Vinalhaven farmers. Served over 2,000 local foods meals,a $32,000 value. Provided the only community space with daily free Internet access to approximately 4,000 individuals. Employed and trained 20 local young adults to staff a cafe. Trained 4 young women to manage a retail service business. Provided four year-round salaried jobs. Fresh Foods Initiative distributed over $1,500 worth of fresh local produce to approximately 30 Vinalhaven low-income families through the Vinalhaven Food Pantry. Facilitated the procurement of fresh local produce to the Vinalhaven School. In October 2011, provided local foods lunches for 140 students at the Vinalhaven School, a value of $150/week. Received WIC and EBT licenses, helping to make local food affordable to all islanders regardless of income. Community Learning Center & Vinalhaven Public Education offered weekly classes and workshops related to food preparation and preservation, healthy lifestyles, and practical life-skills, such as self-presentation, entrepreneurship, and applied science and mathematics. Open to all community members with an average class size of 4 and an age range of 10 to 60+. Created four program tracks and delineated content areas. Developed program standards and the associated definitions and rubrics. Employed a Maine certified teacher to compile and complete The ARC's standards-based materials in one program binder. Met with, informed and engaged key school staff and piloted the new standards-based program with one student for one week. Arranged for the student to present the complete pilot project to the school staff and received approval to demostrate The ARC's programs with additional students. The students will present to the School board and seek school credits for program participants.
reason: The summary focuses on community services, food distribution, education, and job training without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: ART EXHIBITIONS - THE WENDELL GILLEY MUSEUM HAS REGULAR GALLERY HOURS MAY THROUGH MID-DECEMBER AND YEAR-ROUND TOURS FOR GROUPS. EVERY YEAR, IN ADDITION TO ROTATING EXHIBITIONS DRAWN FROM THE GROWING PERMANENT COLLECTION , THE MUSEUM MOUNTS AT LEAST ONE MAJOR, TEMPORARY EXHIBITION BRINGING ARTIFACTS FROM OTHER MUSEUMS AND PRIVATE COLLECTIONS TO SOUTHWEST HARBOR. SEVERAL FREE ADMISSION DAYS ARE HOSTED ANNUALLY BY THE MUSEUM TO ENCOURAGE ATTENDANCE REGARDLESS OF ECONOMIC MEANS. IN ADDITION, ADMISSIONS FEES HAVE BEEN KEPT DOWN AND A LOW-COST MEMBERSHIP OPTION IS OFFERED AS WELL FOR THOSE WISHING TO PARTICIPATE IN PROGRAMS. BIRD CARVING AND OTHER HANDS-ON WORKSHOPS - OUTSIDE OF VISITOR HOURS, THE MUSEUM BUILDING IS AVAILABLE FOR COMMUNITY GROUP MEETINGS AND PUBLIC PROGRAMS AT NO CHARGE. BIRD CARVING WORKSHOPS ARE OFFERED YEAR-ROUND AND OTHER HANDS-ON CREATIVE PROGRAMS ARE OFFERED PERIODICALLY THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. SESSIONS RANGE FROM 1 1/2 HOURS TO 10-WEEK SERIES OF 3-HOUR CLASSES TO MEMBERS, SCHOOL GROUPS, SENIOR GROUPS AND OTHER COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS. MUSEUM MEMBERS ARE WELCOME TO MEMBERS' CARVING CLUB HELD WEEKLY NOVEMBER- APRIL, ENSURING REGULAR YEAR-ROUND ACCESS TO THE MUSEUM. NATURAL HISTORY PROGRAMS - NATURAL HISTORY AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS ARE OFFERED YEAR-ROUND TO SCHOOL GROUPS, HOMESCHOOLERS, AND OTHER ADULT AND CHILDREN'S GROUPS. EXAMPLES OF CURRENTLY OFFERED PROGRAMS ARE OWL ECOLOGY, ""MY CHANGING NEIGHBORHOOD"" STORYBOARD, AND ""BUILD-A-BIRD."" DURING MUSEUM VISITING HOURS, FILMS, PERSONAL TOURS AND CARVING DEMONSTRATIONS ARE REGULAR FEATURES. THE MUSEUM LIBRARY IS AVAILABLE FOR PUBLIC USE WITH SPECIALIZED HISTORICAL RESOURCES AS WELL AS CURRENT PUBLICATIONS FOCUSED ON BIRDS OF THE WORLD AND THE WORLD OF BIRD CARVING. A COLLECTION OF MOUNTED BIRDS IS MAINTAINED AS REFERENCE MATERIAL FOR ARTISTS AND NATURALISTS. THE MUSEUM GIFT SHOP STOCKS LOCAL BIRD CARVINGS, CARVING TOOLS AND SUPPLIES, ORIGINAL BLANKS, AND INSTRUCTION BOOKS, AS WELL AS BIRD-RELATED BOOKS, AUDIO-VISUAL GUIDES, BINOCULARS, AND OTHER ITEMS OF INTEREST TO AVIAN AFICIONADOS. THE MUSEUM STAFF WORKS WITH SCHOOL TEACHERS, OTHER EDUCATORS AND COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS TO CREATE CUSTOMIZED TOURS AND WORKSHOPS FOR STUDENTS AND ADULTS OF ALL AGES.
reason: The summary focuses on art exhibitions, workshops, and educational programs without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: The Maine-Dartmouth Family Medicine Residency is an education based program that educates physicians for a lifetime of competent, compassionate and personally satisfying practice. The Organization strives to improve the health of Maine people with particular emphasis on rural areas and underserved populations while promoting the involvement of physicians in the life of the broader community. The Organization creates a community of learners which honors patient care responsibilities, balances learning and patient care in a way that combines scientific rigor and humanity and values the community caregivers.The Organization strives to create a workplace culture that fosters respect, teamwork, support for personal well-being and openness and appreciation for difference.

mission: BIRCHWOOD LIVING CENTER- INTERMEDIATE CARE NURSING FACILITY FOR FIFTEEN INDIVIDUALS. PROVIDES 24 HOUR NURSING SERVICES TO PEOPLE WITH MENTAL RETARDATION AND OTHER DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES. THE CENTER IS THE ONLY NURSING FACILITY THAT SPECIALIZES IN SERVING DEVELOPMENTALLY DISABLED IN HANCOCK AND WASHINGTON COUNTIES. THE STAFF PROVIDES MEDICAL AND OTHER ACTIVE TREATMENT PROGRAMS WHICH BENEFIT THE INDIVIDUAL BEING SERVED WITH THE GOAL OF DISCHARGE TO A MORE NORMAL, LESS RESTRICTIVE, LIVING SITUATION. THE 15 RESIDENTS ATTEND DAY PROGRAMS AND PARTICIPATE IN COMMUNITY INTEGRATION ACTIVITIES. IDA W. LOCKHARDT RESIDENCE AND HEATH HAVEN RESIDENCE - THESE RESIDENTIAL PROGRAMS ARE LOCATED IN ELLSWORTH, MAINE. THEY EACH SERVE 5 ADULTS WITH DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES AND SUBSTANTIAL MEDICAL ISSUES. THE PROGRAMS PROVIDE A RANGE OF SERVICES ADDRESSING THE NEEDS OF EACH INDIVIDUAL, BASED ON FUNCTIONAL ASSESSMENTS AND THE NEEDS AND DESIRES OF THE INDIVIDUAL. CAPACITA LEARING CENTER AND ZILPHA M. BOOTH LEARING CENTER - THESE FACILITIES ARE LOCATED IN EAST HOLDEN AND ELLSWORTH, MAINE RESPECTIVELY. THEY SERVE UP TO 17 ADULTS WITH DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES. THERE ARE THREE BASIC ELEMENTS TO THE PROGRAMS INCLUDING PERSONAL AND SOCIAL ADJUSTMENT. LEVEL I, WHICH IS DESIGNED TO FOCUS ON BEHAVIORS AND ACTIVITIES WHICH ARE BASIC TO SELF MAINTENANCE, SELF AWARENESS, AND SELF MOTIVATION. PERSONAL AND SOCIAL ADJUSTMENT LEVEL II IS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE AND PROMOTE THE PRACTICAL AND USEFUL APPLICATION, ADAPTATION AND INTEGRATION OF DEVELOPMENTAL SKILLS NECESSARY FOR SEMI OR INDEPENDENT DAILY LIVING. PERSONAL AND ADJUSTMENT LEVEL III, IS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE TRAINING AND SERVICES WHICH MAXIMIZE INDIVIDUAL FUNCTIONING IN PERSONAL DEVELOPMENT AND COMMUNITY LIVING.

mission: HAZARDOUS MATERIALS COURSES THIS 40-HOUR COURSE, KNOWN AS THE HAZWOPER, IS DESIGNED TO MAKE WORKERS AND OTHERS AT UNCONTROLLED HAZARDOUS WASTE SITES AWARE OF THE POTENTIAL HAZARDS THEY WILL ENCOUNTER. THE MLGH TEACHES STUDENTS TO ANTICIPATE, RECOGNIZE, EVALUATE, AND CONTROL HAZARDS; TO SELECT, USE, AND CARE FOR RESPIRATORS AND PROTECTIVE CLOTHING; AND TO CONDUCT AIR MONITORING. THE COURSE PROVIDES THE NECESSARY KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS TO MINIMIZE RISKS, PROTECT HEALTH AND SAFETY, AND LIMIT THE SPREAD OF HAZARDS. MLGH ALSO PRESENTS THE REQUIRED 8 HOUR REFRESHER COURSE. OTHER COURSES INCLUDE THE CONFINED SPACES ENTRY, OPERATIONS LEVEL TRAINING AND REFRESHERS FOR FIRE DEPARTMENTS AND DECONTAMINATION COURSES. DURING 2010, MLGH CONDUCTED 28 SUCH CLASSES WITH 242 PARTICIPANTS. LEAD PAINT COURSES LEAD ABATEMENT SUPERVISORY PRACTICES AND PROCEDURES IS A 32-HOUR COURSE WHICH MEETS THE REQUIRED TRAINING FOR THE RESIDENTIAL LEAD ABATEMENT FIELD UNDER TITLE X, SEC. 1031, WORKER PROTECTION, FOR THE HOUSING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT ACT OF 1992. WORK PRACTICES, HEALTH EFFECTS, LEAD PAINT DETECTION METHODS, AND SUPERVISORY ISSUES (INCLUDING LIABILITY CONCERNS) ARE DISCUSSED. PARTICIPANTS ARE EXPECTED TO PASS A STATE ADMINISTERED EXAM AT THE END OF THE TRAINING. MLGH IS A D.E.P ASBESTOS TRAINING COURSES THIS 40-HOUR SUPERVISORY COURSE MEETS THE REQUIRED TRAINING IN THE ASBESTOS ABATEMENT FIELD AND COMPLIES WITH REQUIREMENTS OF TSCA TITLE IV, AHERA, AND NESHAPS REGULATIONS. WORK PRACTICES, HEALTH EFFECTS, ASBESTOS DETECTION METHODS, AND SUPERVISORY ISSUES (INCLUDING LIABILITY CONCERNS ARE DISCUSSED. PARTICIPANTS ARE EXPECTED TO PASS A STATE ADMINISTERED EXAM AT THE END OF THE TRAINING. MLGH IS A D.E.P. LICENSED TRAINING PROVIDER (TP-0013). ADDITIONAL COURSES INCLUDE THE OSHA TRAINING COURSES OSHA Basic Rights informs workers of their basic health OSHA Basic Rights informs workers of their basic health OSHA Basic Rights informs workers of their basic health OSHA Basic Rights informs workers of their basic health OSHA Basic Rights informs workers of their basic health OSHA Basic Rights informs workers of their basic health

mission: SPURWINK SCHOOL - RECOGNIZED BY THE NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF SPECIAL EDUCATION OPERATES A YEAR-ROUND SPECIAL EDUCATION AND THERAPEUTIC TREATMENT PROGRAM FOR CHILDREN FROM K - 12 WITH BEHAVIORAL AND/OR LEARNING DISABILITIES. mission: PROVISION OF ACUTE & SUBACUTE HOSPITAL CARE RELATED TO OUTPATIENT CLINICS AND HEALTH CARE SERVICES. SERVED 30,088 PATIENT DAYS OF ROUTINE SERVICES AND 80,599 OUTPATIENTS. PROVIDED SERVICES REGARDLESS OF ABILITY TO PAY AS WELL AS EDUCATION AND PROMOTION OF HEALTH. PROVIDED OTHER UNCOMPENSATED CARE (AT COST) OF $2,362,040.Please see the following excerpt from the EMHS Annual Report to the Community for details of community benefit projects by TAMC.Leadership: Sylvia Getman, President and CEO; and Gene Lynch II, Board ChairLocation: Presque Isle, Caribou, Fort Fairfield, and Mars HillEmployees: 1,000Description: The Aroostook Medical Center (TAMC) is northern Maine's leading provider of healthcare services, an advocate for the people we serve, and the area's largest employer. TAMC is a nonprofit organization with passionate employees dedicated to serving the healthcare needs of the people of Aroostook County with outstanding skill and compassion, working closely with our partners to bring the best technology, physicians, and standards of care to the people of northern Maine.TAMC highlights-Began work on new centers for cancer, orthopedic, cardiac, and eye care; improvements were also made in the medical/surgical and women's and children's inpatient units through ongoing work at TAMC's main campus, representing the most significant changes in two decades - the Fort Fairfield Health Center (primary care) and Mars Hill's Aroostook Health Center (rehabilitation and long-term care) facilities are also undergoing renovations-Expanded specialty care offerings in northern Maine by bringing in new providers and introducing advanced technology in urology, orthopedics, rheumatology, dermatology, ophthalmology, and pediatric care-Engaged with several community organizations to introduce a significant number of health promotion and wellness activities throughout the region, including a Summer Fit and Fun series, Discovery Days activities for youth, run/walk and triathlon activities, community health fairs and screenings, programs for seniors, and winter activities-Honored with several awards and commendations, including second consecutive ranking by the American Hospital Association as one of the nation's Top 25 Most Wired Rural Hospital, Avatar's Exceeding Patient Expectations award, and ranking among top hospitals in Maine for maternity care-TAMC president and CEO, Sylvia Getman - Made the Mainebiz Next List of Maine's Ten Key Players Shaping the Future of the State's Economy for her work in ""guiding a rural healthcare system during a time of rapid change""-Provided northern Maine patients the latest in imaging technology that is close to home and that increases patient comfort with new MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) technology; more than 2,200 MRI scans are performed annually at the regions largest medical centerTotal Community Benefit: $16,935,586Community Health Improvement Services: $207,421Community Building Activities: $7,377Community Benefit Operations: $115,374Health Professions Education: $1,180Subsidized Health Services: $254,054Financial and In-Kind Contributions: $52,822Unrecoverable interest cost on funds used to subsidize state MaineCare/Medicaid underpayments of $2.8M; $180,120Traditional Charity Care: $2,632,470Unpaid Cost of Public Programs: Medicaid: $1,804,763 Medicare: $11,680,005Philanthropy: $56,104 MEDICARE SHORTFALLS (AT COST). 9,087 PERSONS SERVED CHARITY CARE PROVIDED (AT COST). 948 PERSONS SERVED EXPENSES $2,687,763. INCLUDING GRANTS OF $0. REVENUE $55,293.

mission: BALLET TRAINING: PSB ENROLLED OVER 150 STUDENTS LAST YEAR, PROVIDING BALLET INSTRUCTION TO STUDENTS BETWEEN THE AGES OF 4 AND 70. THE NATIONALLY RECOGNIZED CORPS PROGRAM FOR HIGH SCHOOL AGED PRE-PROFESSIONAL DANCERS HAD ANOTHER SUCCESSFUL YEAR. 100% OF THESE STUDENTS WERE ACCEPTED INTO NATIONALLY COMPETITIVE SUMMER PROGRAMS SUCH AS AMERICAN BALLET THEATER, SCHOOL OF AMERICAN BALLET, JOFFREY BALLET, AND BOSTON BALLET. THE ADAPTIVE DANCE PROGRAM SERVED 15 CHILDREN WHO LIVE WITH CHALLENGES SUCH AS DOWNS SYNDROME, AUTISM, AND CEREBRAL PALSY. EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH AND PERFORMANCE: PSB BROUGHT LECTURE-DEMONSTRATIONS INTO AREA SCHOOLS AND SENIOR LIVING FACILITIES, EXPOSING SCHOOL CHILDREN AND SENIOR CITIZENS TO THE ARTISTRY AND ATHLETICISM OF BALLET. STUDENT DANCERS ALSO DANCED AS PART OF THE TOWN OF KENNEBUNKS'S MAY DAY FESTIVITIES, AS WELL AS PERFORMING FOR THE VICTORIA MANSION, THE CHILDRENS MUSEUM OF MAINE, PORTLAND HIGH SCHOOL, AND AS PART OF THE PORTLAND SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA DISCOVERY SERIES. THE SCHOOL GROUP PERFORMANCES OF ""THE VICTORIAN NUTCRACKER"" AND ""AROUND THE WORLD WITH FLAT STANLEY"" BROUGHT GROUPS FROM OVER 20 DIFFERENT SCHOOLS/3000 CHILDREN TO THE THEATER TO SEE THE BALLET. TEACHERS PREPARED THEIR STUDENTS FOR THESE PERFORMANCES BY USING OUR PRE-PERFORMANCE EDUCATIONAL GUIDES, WHICH ARE ALIGNED WITH MAINE'S LEARNING RESULTS. PERFORMANCE: PORTLAND BALLET COMPANY PRESENTED A FULL SEASON OF DANCE INCLUDING HALLOWEEN SPOOKTACULAR, JACK THE RIPPER, THE VICTORIAN NUTCRACKER, BOY MEETS GIRL, AND BOLERO TO BAYADERE. PBC CONTINUED THE SERIES OF FREE AND ACCESSIBLE PERFORMANCES IN THE FRONT WINDOW OF THE PORTLAND PUBLIC LIBRARY AS PART OF THE FIRST FRIDAY ART WALK. THIS PROFESSIONAL COMPANY ALSO PROVIDES PERFORMANCE TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR PSB'S ADVANCED DANCERS. MANY STUDENT DANCERS ARE CAST IN OUR ANNUAL PRODUCTION OF THE VICTORIAN NUTCRACKER, AND OUR ADVANCED DANCERS SERVE AS UNDERSTUDIES TO EACH OF THE PROFESSIONAL PERFORMANCES. THESE OPPORTUNITIES PROVIDE PSB STUDENTS WITH ESSENTIAL PERFORMING EXPERIENCE AND A GLIMPSE INTO THE LIFE OF A PROFESSIONAL DANCER. PORTLAND BALLET STUDIO THEATRE: PORTLAND BALLET CONDUCTED A FUNDRAISING CAMPAIGN AND IN OCTOBER 2014 OPENED THE PORTLAND BALLET STUDIO THEATRE IN THE SPACE ADJACENT TO OUR STUDIOS. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT WAS TO PROVIDE AN INTIMATE PERFORMING SPACE TO GIVE AUDIENCES A VERY PERSONAL EXPERIENCE OF DANCE, TO PROVIDE MORE PERFORMING OPPORTUNITIES FOR OUR STUDENT DANCERS, AND TO SERVE AS A HOME FOR THE MANY TALENTED LOCAL PERFORMING ORGANIZATIONS FOR WHOM LARGE VENUES ARE NOT AN OPTION. AFTER LESS THAN ONE YEAR IN OPERATION, OUR STUDENTS HAVE PRESENTED THREE SHOWS, OUR COMPANY HAS PRESENTED TWO SHOWS, AND THE THEATRE HAS BEEN RENTED BY SEVEN OUTSIDE PERFORMING GROUPS. THE ART GALLERY LOBBY HAS ALSO GENERATED A SENSE OF COMMUNITY, DISPLAYING THE WORKS OF LOCAL PAINTERS AND PHOTGRAPHERS.
reason: The summary focuses on ballet training, performances, and educational outreach without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: The Park-Danforth provides high quality, dignified, safe and affordable housing (70 independent living apartments) to those whose means are defined as ""very low income"" or ""extremely low income"" in accordance with federal eligibility guidelines for the HUD Section 8 program.In providing Section 8 housing, The Park-Danforth, in partnership with the U.S. Department of HUD, provides housing to those who would otherwise be at financial risk due to the high cost of housing and utilities. These apartments are specially designed to optimally meet the needs of those who are aging in place. As these residents age, by virtue of their residency, they are given priority for transfers to the assisted living program at such time as a higher level of care is needed. This priority and transfer is financially made possible by Home for the Aged, another 501(c)(3) entity, co-located at the 777 Stevens Avenue, Portland, Maine site.

mission: The Islesboro Preschool runs programs for two age groups. The Infant and Toddler program is for children ranging in age from 3 months to 2 1/2 years. The Preschool program is structured for children aged 2 1/2 through 5 years old. Both programs are now housed in our brand new facility at 152 Main Road located next door to the town office and fire department.In addition, summer camps are available for infants - 5 years of age.The Islesboro Preschool provides an atmosphere that encourages social, emotional, physical, and intellectual growth and development of the child as a whole. Using the Maine Early Childhood Guidelines and Infant/Toddler Guidelines, our program structures activities to meet those goals. Programs such as Creative Curriculum and Handwriting Without Tears provide structure and assessments to guide and monitor children along their developmental continuum. A typical day at the Islesboro Preschool will include a variety of activities including the following: sharing and conversation time, stories, songs, and finger plays; creative arts and crafts; games and large muscle play with outside play; nature, science, and math activities; field trips on the island; and exposure to readiness skills for Kindergarten.
reason: The summary focuses on early childhood education and development activities without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: TOGETHER PLACE SOCIAL CLUB IS A PEER RUN CLUB PROVIDING SOCIAL, RECREATIONAL, EDUCATIONAL, VOCATIONAL, PEER SUPPORT AND RECOVERY OPPORTUNITIES FOR ADULT MENTAL HEALTH CONSUMERS AND/OR ADULTS WITH DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES. PARTICIPATION IS DIRECTED TOWARD ENHANCING AND SUPPORTING THE INDIVIDUALS INDEPENDENCE IN THE COMMUNITY. APPROXIMATELY 500 UNDUPLICATED INDIVIDUALS ARE SERVED ANNUALLY. EMPLOYMENT CONNECTIONS IS A PROGRAM DESIGNED TO HELP ADULT MENTAL HEALTH CONSUMERS PURSUE THEIR VOCATIONAL INTEREST IN THE COMMUNITY. ASSISTED BY CLIENT REFERRALS AND FUNDING FROM THE BUREAU OF VOCATIONAL REHABILITATION AND THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES, THIS PROGRAM PROVIDES: CAREER EXPLORATION, JOB COACHING AND SUPPORTS. IN ADDITION TO WORKING WITH COMMUNITY EMPLOYERS, EMPLOYMENT CONNECTIONS OPERATES A CUSTODIAL SERVICES CONTRACT PROGRAM, WHICH EMPLOYS SEVERAL MENTAL HEALTH CONSUMERS IN THE AREA. COMMUNITY CONNECTIONS IS A STATEWIDE PROGRAM THAT SUPPORTS THE INDIVIDUAL ADULT MENTAL HEALTH CONSUMER REGAIN INDEPENDENCE AND IMPROVED QUALITY OF LIFE THROUGH PARTICIPATION IN RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES IN THE COMMUNITY. SERVICES INCLUDE ACTIVITY INFORMATION, LEISURE PLANNING, ADVOCACY, DEVELOPMENT OF RESOURCES AND FINANCIAL SUBSIDIES. THE PROGRAM IS COORDINATED THROUGH A NETWORK OF VOLUNTEER SITES THROUGHOUT THE STATE. CURRENTLY, STATEWIDE MEMBERSHIP EXCEEDS 5,600 INDIVIDUALS. TOGETHER PLACE HOUSING IS A HOUSING CO-OPERATIVE, WHICH RECEIVES A SUBSIDY FROM DHHS. THE CO-OPERATIVE HAS ITS OWN BOARD OF DIRECTORS, CONSISTING OF ITS SHAREHOLDING TENANTS AND A REPRESENTATIVE FROM FRIENDS OF TOGETHER PLACE, A SEPARATE ORGANIZATION. THE CO-OP IS THE ONLY SUCH LIMITED EQUITY HOUSING CO-OPERATIVE FOR MENTAL HEALTH CONSUMERS IN MAINE AND IS CONTROLLED BY THE PEOPLE WHO LIVE IN IT. MEMBERSHIP TO THE CO-OP IS OPEN TO LOW INCOME ADULTS WHO HAVE MENTAL HEALTH DISABILITIES. CURRENTLY THE CO-OP CONSISTS OF ELEVEN UNITS IN THREE SEPARATE BUILDINGS.
reason: The summary focuses on social, recreational, educational, and vocational support for adults with mental health issues and does not mention any religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: SET APART BY OUR SMALL SIZE AND FOCUS ON NON-COMPETITIVE ACHIEVEMENT, BIRCH ROCK CAMP HAS PROVIDED A SUMMER HOME FOR BOYS AGES 7 16 SINCE 1926. THE CAMPS MISSION IS TO CHALLENGE CAMPERS TO TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR THEIR OWN LIVES, AND TO HELP THEM APPRECIATE THE NEEDS OF OTHERS IN EMPHASIZING OUR MOTTO: HELP THE OTHER FELLOW. BIRCH ROCKS PROGRAM PROMOTES THE WELL- ROUNDED DEVELOPMENT OF ITS CAMPERS BY BUILDING CHARACTER AND ENCOURAGING COOPERATION, CONFIDENCE, AND A WILLINGNESS TO TRY NEW THINGS. A PROUD AND ACCREDITED MEMBER OF THE AMERICAN CAMP ASSOCIATION AND ACTIVE PARTNER WITH MAINE SUMMER CAMPS, BIRCH ROCKER IS AN OLD-FASHIONED BOYS RESIDENTIAL CAMP WHERE TRADITION AND HALLOWED RITUAL SURROUND EVERY ASPECT OF THE DAY FROM THE WAKEUP BELL TO THE LIGHTS-OUT CALL. OUR DAILY PROGRAM OFFERS THE RIGHT BALANCE OF STRUCTURE AND FREE CHOICE - AS WELL AS THE PERFECT BLEND OF ENERGETIC FUN, QUIET CONCENTRATION ON TASKS AND RELAXING DOWNTIME INCLUDING IN OUR UNIQUE LIBRARY. WHILE THERE ARE MANY ACTIVITIES (CAMPING TRIPS, SWIMMING, WATERCRAFT, FIELD SPORTS, ARTS, NATURE AND PRIMITIVE SKILLSETC.) TO CHOOSE FROM DAILY, EACH CAMPER IS REQUIRED TO SET GOALS FOR HIMSELF AND SET A PLAN FOR ACHIEVEMENT. LEARNING BY DOING AND SHARING IS HOW BIRCH ROCKERS BUILD MORE SELF-ESTEEM AND PERSONAL SUCCESS. THE BIRCH ROCK COMMUNITY IS DISTINGUISHED BY THE MANY CAMPERS AND COUNSELORS (3 TO 1 RATIO) WHO RETURN EACH YEAR, AND EVEN FOR DECADES. BIRCH ROCKERS ARE COMMITTED TO BEING THE FINEST MENTORS, AND PASSING ON OUR VALUES AND CHERISHED TRADITIONS TO GENERATIONS OF CAMPERS TO COME.
reason: The summary focuses on a summer camp's activities and values related to personal development, cooperation, and mentorship without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: Maine Veterans' Homes Bangor operates 150 beds, providing skilled nursing, physical/occupational/speech therapy and rehabilitation, long-term care, memory care, and assisted living services. During fiscal year 2020, we provided 50,147 days of care to 346 residents. Efforts to protect our residents from the coronavirus were all consuming in the latter part of the fiscal year. These efforts were effective as Bangor avoided any residents or staff testing positive for the virus. Maine Veterans' Homes Scarborough operates 150 beds, providing skilled nursing, physical/occupational/speech therapy and rehabilitation, long-term care, memory care, and assisted living services. During FY20, we provided 49,823 days of care to 292 residents. In October 2016, MVH Scarborough received the American Health Care Association's Gold Level Award for Excellence in Quality - one of only three in the nation for the year and one of only 31 since the program's inception! Efforts to protect our residents from the coronavirus were all consuming in the latter part of the fiscal year. Scarborough experienced an outbreak of coronavirus in April. Through the efforts of staff at Scarborough, the outbreak was limited to one unit. Maine Veterans' Homes Augusta operates 150 beds, providing skilled nursing, physical/occupational/speech therapy and rehabilitation, long-term care, memory care, and assisted living services. During FY20, we provided 48,708 days of care to 261 residents. In Fy19, MVH Augusta achieved Silver Level Award for Achievement in Quality - a distinction held by less than four percent of facilities nationwide! Efforts to protect our residents from the coronavirus were all consuming in the latter part of the fiscal year. These efforts were effective as Augusta avoided any residents or staff testing positive for the virus. We operate three additional facilities in Maine, one in South Paris (90 beds), Caribou (70 beds) and Machias (30 beds). During FY20, we provided a combined total of 64,812 days of care to 258 residents. in FY19, each facility achieved at least the Silver Level Award for Achievement in Quality, while Machias has achieved Gold Level status. MVH Pharmacies provides medication and consulting services to all six MVH facilities and external nursing homes.
reason: The summary focuses on healthcare services and does not mention any religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: PROGRAM 1: FOSTERING YOUTH LEADERSHIP MEEA WORKS WITH YOUTH AND EARLY CAREER PROFESSIONALS TO CREATE LEADERSHIP OPPORTUNITIES THAT EMPOWER THEIR DRIVE FOR SOCIAL AND CLIMATE JUSTICE. THIS SUPPORT INCLUDES TOOLS, RESOURCES, AND STIPENDS FOR THEIR TIME AND EXPERTISE. COMMUNITY BUILDING IS ESSENTIAL TO FOSTERING YOUTH LEADERSHIP. THEREFORE, WE CONNECT YOUTH TO NETWORK PEERS, COMMUNITY PARTNERS, MENTORS, AND COACHES. WE RECOGNIZE OUR YOUTHS WORK THROUGH AWARD NOMINATIONS. PROGRAM 2: SUPPORTING EDUCATORS EDUCATORS ARE CRITICAL CHANGE AGENTS, AND WE AIM TO SUPPORT THEIR WORK THROUGH PEER CONNECTIONS, CONVENINGS, PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, AND FINANCIAL AND NON-FINANCIAL RESOURCES. WE ELEVATE STORYTELLING AND CELEBRATE EDUCATOR SUCCESSES TO SHARE THESE ACHIEVEMENTS WITH OUR STATE AND NATIONAL NETWORK. IN 2023, WE AWARDED 119 MINIGRANTS TO SUPPORT EDUCATORS. PROGRAM 3: ADVANCING TRANSFORMATIONAL POLICY MEEA STRIVES TO ADVANCE RESEARCH-INFORMED,TRANSFORMATIONAL POLICY SOLUTIONS THAT WILL FURTHER ELEVATE THE IMPACT OF OUR PROGRAMS. OUR APPROACH FOCUSES ON GRASSROOTS ENGAGEMENT, COLLABORATING WITH COALITION PARTNERS, AND BUILDING RELATIONSHIPS WITH STATE AND FEDERAL DECISION-MAKERS. PRIORITIZING RESEARCH AND EVALUATION - RESEARCH AND EVALUATION ARE CRUCIAL IN HIGHLIGHTING THE NEEDS OF OUR COMMUNITY, SO MEEA WORKS TO IDENTIFY STATEWIDE TRENDS, PATTERNS, AND NEEDS. MEEA UTILIZES THIS INFORMATION TO SUPPORT PROGRAMMATIC EVALUATION, ASSESS PROGRESS TOWARD SYSTEMS CHANGE, AND DISSEMINATE LOCAL CASE STUDIES OF INNOVATION. MEEA ALSO SEEKS TO COMMUNICATE BEST PRACTICES FROM THE NATIONAL LEVEL. SHIFTING CULTURE- MULTISCALE CHANGE IS ESSENTIAL TO MEEA'S WORK. MEEA BUILDS ORGANIZATIONAL INFRASTRUCTURES TO CULTIVATE VALUES-ALIGNED PROCEDURES, EMERGENT STRATEGIES, TRANSPARENCY WITH FAILURE AND PROCESS, AND AUTHENTIC RELATIONSHIPS. MEEA SHARES THE LESSONS LEARNED WITH OUR STATE AND NATIONAL NETWORKS THROUGH MODELING, TEACHING, AND ENSURING ACCOUNTABILITY FOR OTHERS WORKING TOWARDS THESE CULTURE SHIFTS.
reason: The summary focuses on youth leadership, education, and policy advocacy without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: HEALTHY ANDROSCOGGIN'S SUPPLEMENTAL NUTRITION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM EDUCATION (SNAP-ED) COORDINATORS ASSISTED IN PROVIDING 94 FAMILIES WITH MEALS EVERY DAY OVER THE SCHOOL SUMMER BREAK. A COMMUNITY FOOD RESOURCE GUIDE WAS CREATED AND UPDATED EVERY MONTH SO THAT COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN NEED WOULD HAVE THE MOST UPDATED INFORMATION ON FOOD RESOURCES. IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING MEALS AND RESOURCES, PRE-RECORDED EDUCATION VIDEOS AND VIRTUAL FIELD TRIPS WERE PRODUCED AND DISSEMINATED THOUGH THE HEALTHY ANDROSCOGGIN YOUTUBE CHANNEL FOR SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS TO UTILIZE. AN ONLINE REGISTRATION WAS DEVELOPED FOR NUTRITION CLASSES, INCLUDING POSTERS WITH THE LINK DISPLAYED IN FAMILY PRACTICE AND PEDIATRICIAN OFFICES. THE ANDROSCOGGIN GLEANERS WERE ABLE TO INCREASE THEIR CAPACITY AND COLLECTED ALMOST 17,000 LBS. OF FRESH PRODUCE, EQUALING ABOUT 70,700 SERVINGS, WHICH WERE DISTRIBUTED THROUGHOUT ANDROSCOGGIN COUNTY.THE LET'S GO PROGRAM OFFERED GRANTS TO PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS WITH AN AIM AT ADDRESSING HEALTHY EATING AND ACTIVE LIVING. SOME WAYS IN WHICH GRANTS WERE USED BY THESE ORGANIZATIONS INCLUDED INDIVIDUAL SUPPLIES FOR EACH CHILD (SUCH AS WATER BOTTLES); PHYSICAL ACTIVITY EQUIPMENT LIKE LAWN GAMES, BALLS, AND JUMP ROPES; ACTIVITY BAGS TO TAKE HOME; AND FRUIT INFUSION SYSTEMS FOR WATER PITCHERS.THE SUBSTANCE USE AND TOBACCO PREVENTION SERVICES PARTNERED WITH LOCAL COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS, THE OFFICE OF REFUGEE RESETTLEMENT/CATHOLIC CHARITIES OF MAINE, AND THE IMMIGRANT LEGAL RESOURCE CENTER TO EDUCATE ASYLUM AND REFUGEE COMMUNITY MEMBERS ON CANNABIS USE AND THE FEDERAL LAW, SUBSTANCE MISUSE AMONG YOUTH, AND RESOURCES FOR PARENTS. HEALTHY ANDROSCOGGIN PROVIDED EDUCATION ON AN ASSORTMENT OF TOPICS TO A VARIETY OF AUDIENCES INCLUDING THE LEWISTON AREA METROPOLITAN CHAMBER OF COMMERCE, LOCAL MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOLS, AND THE 2021 COMMUNITY ANTI-DRUG COALITIONS OF AMERICA NATIONAL FORUM. IN ADDITION, HEALTHY ANDROSCOGGIN ASSISTED IN CREATING AND/OR UPDATING SMOKE AND TOBACCO-FREE POLICIES AT THE DEMPSEY CENTER, MULTI-UNIT HOUSING COMPLEXES, ONE SCHOOL DISTRICT, AND TWO CHILDCARE/PRE-SCHOOL SETTINGS.HEALTHY ANDROSCOGGIN (HA) SHARED INFORMATION ON HOW WE ACCESS LOCAL LEAD DATA AND IMPLEMENT OUR LEAD WORKPLANS WITH RIVER VALLEY HEALTHY COMMUNITY COALITION, RUMFORD HOSPITAL, AND THE TOWN OF RUMFORD COMMUNITY AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT STAFF. HA SHARED POISONING, SCREENING, AND HOUSING DATA FROM THE EPH TRACKING NETWORK SPECIFIC TO RUMFORD AND OXFORD COUNTY AND DISCUSSED HOW TO ADDRESS LEAD IN THEIR COMMUNITIES. HA PROVIDED THE CITY OF LEWISTON WITH SUGGESTIONS FOR PERMITTING LANGUAGE THAT REQUIRES OR ENCOURAGES THE LEAD RENOVATION, REPAIR, AND PAINTING PROGRAM (RRP) CERTIFICATION NUMBER TO BE SUPPLIED ON PERMIT APPLICATIONS, AS WELL AS A PROCESS FOR CITY STAFF TO DISTRIBUTE INFORMATION TO PROPERTY OWNERS ON THE RRP RULE AND LEAD PREVENTION AS PART OF UNIT TURNOVER. A PRINT AND SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN (NEWSPAPER ADS, BUS ADS, AND FACEBOOK POSTS) WAS CONDUCTED IN THE SPRING OF 2021 TO RAISE AWARENESS OF LEAD POISONING PREVENTION, HOME RENOVATION REQUIREMENTS, LEAD DUST TESTING RESOURCES, AND LEAD BLOOD TESTING FOR CHILDREN. HEALTHY ANDROSCOGGIN (HA) SUPPORTED THE LAUNCH OF THE GOOD FOOD BUS AT CENTRAL MAINE MEDICAL CENTER, CREATED A POWERPOINT TO USE FOR TRAINING CLINICAL AND NON-CLINICAL STAFF AT RUMFORD HOSPITAL ON ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES, AND EXPANDED HUNGER VITAL SIGNS TO ADDITIONAL OUTPATIENT PHYSICIAN OFFICES. FINALLY, HA CREATED, STREAMLINED, AND IMPROVED AN ONBOARDING PROCESS FOR CLINIC VOLUNTEERS TO WORK AT SHIFTS AT COMMUNITY COVID-19 VACCINE CLINICS.
reason: The summary focuses on health, nutrition, and community support activities without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: Grantmaking. Maine Community Foundation (MaineCF, the Foundation) envisions a Maine that is a vibrant and equitable place where people and communities thrive. MaineCF strives to achieve this vision throughout all of its programs and services. MaineCF partners with donors to accomplish their philanthropic goals in Maine by connecting them and their resources to opportunities in nonprofits, investments, and partnerships that strive to build a better Maine. The Foundation also works with nonprofit organizations, communities, and government and private sector leaders to address the significant issues that are important to people in Maine. (Continued on Schedule O)Specifically, MaineCF holds more than 450 donor advised funds, 700+ scholarships, nearly 300 funds invested on behalf of nonprofits, and 19 competitive grant programs all with the goal of meeting our vision of a vibrant and equitable Maine.In 2023, the Foundation provided more than $58 million in grants supporting organizations to address several charitable initiatives including, but not limited to, climate, housing, economic opportunity, and equity. The $58 million in grants awarded in 2023 includes $3 million in scholarships awarded to over 1,300 recipients for professional development, and undergraduate and graduate studies. It also included 200 grants totaling $1.67 million from the Maine Community Foundation Community Building program, which engages communities across Maine to provide resources to nonprofits from the Foundation's endowed county funds. Furthermore, grants given directly from donor advised funds through MaineCF's Giving Together program added 72 more grants and $533,263 to MaineCF's largest single competitive grant program.
reason: The summary focuses on grantmaking and philanthropic activities without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: IN 2018, THE READFIELD UNION MEETING HOUSE MADE CONTINUED PROGRESS TOWARD ITS GOAL OF COMPLETE RESTORATION WITH THE NEXT DECADE. MOST IMPORTANTLY, WE COMPLETED RECONSTRUCTION OF THE FLOOR SUPPORT STRUCTURE, CAPPING 5 YEARS OF WORK. MANY, MANY INDIVIDUALS, BUSINESSES, AND CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS SUPPORTED THIS WORK AT A TOTAL COST OF MORE THAN 300,000. DURING THE YEAR, WE ALSO UPGRADED THE MEETING HOUSE'S WATER AND ELECTRICAL SYSTEMS, AND MODERNIZED OUR BATHROOM FACILITIES. IN THE FALL OF THE YEAR, WE BEGAN AN IMPORTANT 21-MONTH PROJECT TO CONSERVE THE BEAUTIFUL PLASTER CEILING WITH ""TROMPE L'OEIL"" PAINTING. THE REBUILT FLOOR PERMITTED THE MEETING HOUSE TO BE OPENED TO THE PUBLIC WITH ITS FULL 300+ SEATING CAPACITY. THE BOARD USED THE FACILITY ITSELF, ALONG WITH MORE PUBLIC OUTREACH, TO ATTRACT MORE COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND VISITORS TO THE BUILDING. A RANGE OF EDUCATIONAL, SOCIAL, AND ENTERTAINMENT PROGRAMS THROUGH THE SPRING AND SUMMER PROVIDED A CHANCE FOR NEIGHBORS TO MEET NEIGHBORS WHILE SURROUNDED BY THE FAMOUS 150-YEAR-OLD MURALS ON WALLS AND CEILING. IN LATE 2018, PLANS WERE LAID FOR AN EXPANDED SCHEDULE OF EVENTS IN 2019. OUR BOARD OF DIRECTORS NETTED AN INCREASE OF ONE PERSON IN 2018, WITH ONE RESIGNATION AND TWO ADDITIONS. AN ENTHUSIASTIC GROUP OF VOLUNTEERS IS HELPING THE BOARD TO IDENTIFY AND SUPPORT NEEDS WITHIN THE TOWN THAT CAN BE SERVED BY THE MEETING HOUSE FACILITIES, INCLUDING AN ADJACENT ""VESTRY"" BUILDING. WE ARE FORTUNATE TO HAVE A HARD-WORKING TEAM OF PEOPLE TO HELP WITH THE DUAL GOALS OF ""RESTORING AND MAINTAINING THE MEETING HOUSE"" WHILE IT ""BENEFITS THE COMMUNITY"".
reason: The summary focuses on the restoration and community use of a meeting house without mentioning religious activities or concepts.

mission: Since 2002, HCI has offered Family Visitation Services in safe, supportive environments for DHHS sponsored families and for private pay clients. Children who are place in the states custody have the right to see their parents and other family members with court approval. Visits are arranged at HCI sites or in the community in six counties throughout mid-coast and central Maine. Since 1985, Home Base Family Services HBFS has offered intensive, short-term counseling designed to help families provide safe home environments for their children and family. Geared toward children with behavioral or emotional difficulties, this program also offers community reintegration services for children being released from residential, correctional, or foster care placement. Since 1999, HCI has been providing Alternative Response services. Individualized case management is provided for families who have been reported to the Maine DHHS with allegations of child abuse or neglect. Case managers and families work together for up to four months to develop strategies and plans that strengthen and enhance the lives of families in situations where a childs safety may be at risk.

mission: Holocaust and Human Rights Center of Maine (the Center) is a nonprofit organization located in Augusta, Maine. The Center uses the lessons of the Nazi Holocaust and other genocides to combat prejudice and discrimination in Maine and beyond. The Center encourages individuals and communities to reflect and act upon their ethical and moral responsibilities in the modern world. The Center offers a wide range of free educational outreach, compelling programming, and rotating exhibition to the community. The Center is supported primarily by donor contributions and a strong force of volunteers.

mission: Residential treatment programs - for people with severe and persistant mental illness. 20 adults with severe and persistant mental illmness received round the clock, clinically supervised, personal support in a home-like and safe residential environment which included their own private bedroom and a daily treatment program tailored to their specific needs. The focus was on reducing their mental illness symptoms and also assisting them on their road to recovery. Services were delivered in Eastport Residential Facility (14 beds) and Milbridge Residence (6 beds) both facilities are dully licensed through the DHHS Assisted Living Program and the Office of Mental Health and Substance Abuse. Home support programs - support approximatly 20 adults with intellectual disabilities. Individuals receive clinically supervised support services delivered in their own homes (or in small agency supported homes) designed to help recipients improve and maintain their ability to live as independently as possible. Services included primarily habilitative training, personal assistance with activities of daily living, instrumental activities of daily living and development and personal well being. Services are offered thoughout all of Washington County, Maine. Childrens services - services approximately 40 children with significant intellectual, emotional or behavioral disabilities. Providing home and community based treatment, rehabilitative and commmunity support or child day treatment programs. Services include counseling, therapy, teaching, socialization and applied behavioral analysis. All services were individually tailored to assist children to reach their full potential, to increase their inclusion in the community and to sustain them in their family living situation of their choice. Services are provided thoughout Washington County, Maine. Community Support Programs - Support approximately 50 people with intellectual disabilities with services designed to help them remain in their communities and prevent their institutionalization. Induvidually designed services were delivered by direct support professionals, tailored to increase each recipients ability to successfully engage in inclusive social community relationships and to maintain and develop skills that support health and well-being. The focus is on community inclusion, personal development and supporting areas of daily living skills as necessary. Services were delivered in the communities surrounding Calais, Machias and Cherryfield Maine.
reason: The summary focuses on mental health and community support services without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: The Coastal Children's Museum's mission to discover, explore and learn through play was supported by our continued growth. This year, over 8,338 visitors walked through our doors and 133 families have become members of the museum.We continued our community outreach by having a collaborative science program with the Project Puffin, an Audubon affiliated program in Rockland, Maine. We also participated in Rockland's Summer Solstice celebration, joined the local animal shelter, Pope Memorial Humane Society, for their Kid's Day and their Whisker Walk fund-raiser. With the help of children visitors, we built a mobile sculpture and raced it in the 1st annual Rockland Sculpture Race. Our mobile touch tank brought lobster and other ocean critters to Merryspring Nature Center, a local non-profit, to educate campers about tidal zones and the animals that live along the local shoreline. We hosted 165 workshops, including; family paint nights, magic lessons, children's yoga, and music, science, and art workshops. With the help of high school volunteers, we started a Making Memories program series where kids and their parents are encouraged to create something together. We helped celebrate 27 birthday parties.In the spirit of the holidays and in honor of community service, we participate annually in the AIO Food Pantry Back Pack program. We present two free admission passes, along with a healthy snack, to each child. This year we gave over 620 passes to the program. In addition to the Back Pack Program, we collect food and goods for the AIO Food Pantry. Our Spring Children's Fair, sponsored the Rockland Kiwanis Club, helps us offer a free admission morning at the Museum, 226 people attended. In honor of the Museum's June anniversary, we offer a $1.00 admission day and have special activities. These and other special admission days help us reach and be accessible to an important portion of our community.A special grant was awarded to us, which allowed us to donate Library passes to two local libraries, which library members can check out for the day and grants admission for up to 6 people to visit the museum without cost.
reason: The summary focuses on educational and community outreach activities without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: DEFY Child Care includes the Moore Early Learning Center, the Beechland Early Learning Center, The Island of Imagination Early Learning Center, Camp Discovery, and Hancock Grammar School Afterschool. In all, DEFY Child Care provides services to over 500 families each year. DEFY Child Care is the largest child care provider in Hancock County, and one of the only centers to provide care from 6 weeks through 6th grade. More than 30% of our families receive some level of assistance for childcare services. Our centers collaborate with State agencies, local non-profits, and local schools to provide excellent care and transitional support for children needing special services. The Wiggins YMCA is focused on improving healthy living, youth development, and social responsibility for the City of Ellsworth and surrounding communities. The YMCA offers a broad range of programs and services to a diverse population. The Aquatics department provides instructional swim lessons and competitive swimming for all ages, aquatic aerobics for adults and seniors, Special Olymic programming, and aquatic therapy. The Fitness department provides a wide range of programming for all ages, including a collaboration with Northern Light Hospital to provide cardiac rehabilitation phase 3 to over 40 seniors. More than 300 adults and seniors take advantage of fitness equipmnet and our indoor track for their fitness. The YMCA also acts as the recreation department for the City of Ellsworth. More than 500 youth paticipated in our recreational sports and afterschool programming. Scholarships are provided to qualifying individuals ensuring that all can be served. The Blue Hill YMCA is focused on improving healthy living, youth development, and social responsibility for the communities on and around the Blue Hill Peninsula. The YMCA offers a broad range of programs and services to a diverse population. The Aquatics department provides instructional swim lessons and competitive swimming for all ages, aquatic aerobics for adults and seniors, Special Olympic programming, and the States first water safety program specifically for middle school-aged lobstermen. The Fitness department provides a wide range of programming for all ages, including the collaboration with Northern Light Hospital to provide Cardiac Rehabilitation Phase 3 to over 30 seniors. More than 250 adults and seniors take advantage of fitness programming each week, and an additional 300 adults and seniors take advantage of fitness equipment and our indoor track for their fitness. The Y also acts as the recreation department for much of the Peninsula. The Bucksport YMCA is focused on improving healthy living, youth development, and social responsibility for the Town of Bucksport. The YMCA offers a broad range of programs and services to a diverse population. Through a collaboration with the Town of Bucksport, the Y provides year-round recreational sports and programming for kids from age 3 to 18. More than 350 youth participated in activities ranging from cheering to soccer, basketball, swim lessons and football. The Young Bucks Summer Camp provides child care services for families during the summer. More than 120 families enrolled in 2023, 30% of whom received scholarships. In the summer, the Y manages an outdoor pool, open to the public at no cost. More than 150 individuals take advantage of the pool each day during the summer. The Y provides a small fitness room and adult fitness programs throughout the year. Scholarships are provided to qualifying individuals ensuring that all can be served.
reason: The summary focuses on child care, fitness, and recreational programs without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: PROVIDING INDIRECT AND DIRECT NON-MEDICAL CARE FOR CLIENTS AND FAMILIES WHICH CAN TAKE PLACE IN THE HOME, HOSPITAL OR NURSING HOME. PROVIDING ON CALL SERVICE FOR PATIENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES NEEDING SUPPORT AT THE MAYO REGIONAL HOSPITAL. PROVIDING RESPONSE TO TRAUMATIC COMMUNITY EVENTS. PROVIDING BEREAVEMENT SUPPORT FOR CHILDREN, ADULTS AND FAMILIES. PINE TREE HOSPICE RECEIVES NO STATE OR FEDERAL FUNDING, AND NO PAYMENTS FROM INSURANCE COMPANIES. IN MAINE, STATE REGULATIONS DICTATE THAT A VOLUNTEER HOSPICE PROGRAM IS DEFINED AS A HOSPICE PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES ALL DIRECT PATIENT CARE AT NO CHARGE. AS SUCH A VOLUNTEER HOSPICE AND BEREAVEMENT PROGRAM WE ARE NOT ALLOWED TO BE A FEE FOR SERVICE ORGANIZATION. OUR FINANCIAL VIABILITY IS DEPENDENT SOLELY UPON THE GENEROSITY RECEIVED FROM GRANTS, FUNDRAISING, STRONG COLLABORATIVE SUPPORT AND DONATIONS OF FOUNDATIONS. PINE TREE HOSPICE, AS A VOLUNTEER HOSPICE, PROVIDES ALL ITS DIRECT CARE THROUGH THE SERVICE OF OVER 100 TRAINED VOLUNTEERS. AS MOST AGENCY PROGRAMMATIC COSTS CONSIST PRIMARILY OF WAGES AND BENEFITS, PINE TREE HOSPICE WILL HAVE AN INORDINATELY LOWER PERCENTAGE OF PROGRAMMATIC COSTS THAN IS TYPICAL. THIS CAN PORTRAY A MISLEADING HIGH PERCENT OF G&A BUT IN ACTUALITY PINE TREE HOSPICE HAS THREE CONTRACTED PART-TIME EMPLOYEES AND ONE CONTRACT EMPLOYEE THAT WORKS THIRTY FIVE HOURS PER WEEK TO OVERSEE THE DELIVERY OF ITS MISSION. OUR BIGGEST ASSET IS NOT REFLECTED IN DOLLARS AND CENTS, IT IS MEASURED IN THE HOURS FOUND IN THE 100-PERSON VOLUNTEER BASE THAT WE HAVE BUILT.
reason: The summary focuses on providing non-medical care and support services without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: HOMEOWNERSHIP PROGRAM: HOUSEHOLDS IN NEED OF A DECENT PLACE TO LIVE BUILD SAFE AND AFFORDABLE HOMES IN PARTNERSHIP WITH US. HABITAT HOUSES ARE MODESTLY SIZED. THEY ARE LARGE ENOUGH FOR THE HOUSEHOLD'S NEEDS BUT SMALL ENOUGH TO KEEP CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE COSTS AFFORDABLE. BY USING THE LABOR OF VOLUNTEERS AND PROSPECTIVE HOMEOWNERS, EMPLOYING EFFICIENT BUILDING METHODS, KEEPING HOUSE SIZES MODEST, USING DONATED CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS AND APPLIANCES, AND ISSUING AFFORDABLE LOANS, HABITAT MAKES ITS HOUSES AFFORDABLE FOR LOW-INCOME HOUSEHOLDS TO PURCHASE. AFFORDABLE HOMEOWNERSHIP HELPS CREATE CONDITIONS THAT FREE INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES FROM INSTABILITY, STRESS AND FEAR AND ENCOURAGE SELF-RELIANCE AND CONFIDENCE. STUDIES SHOW THAT STRONG AND STABLE HOUSEHOLDS ARE FOUNDATIONAL TO CHILD DEVELOPMENT AND GROWTH. WHEN A HOME FOSTERS, INSTEAD OF HINDERS, HEALTH AND SAFETY, PEOPLE CAN FLOURISH. OWNING AN AFFORDABLE HOME ALSO ALLOWS HOMEOWNERS TO LIFT UP THEIR ENTIRE FAMILY BY SAVING FOR THEIR FUTURES AND INVESTING IN EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, BOLSTERING JOB OPPORTUNITIES AND CAREER GROWTH. DURING FISCAL YEAR 2024, HABITAT FOR HUMANITY YORK COUNTY SERVED 1 HOUSEHOLD THROUGH ITS LONG-TERM HOME OWNERSHIP PROGRAM AND BEGAN CONSTRUCTION OF TWO ADDITIONAL HOMES. RESTORE - PROVIDE THE PUBLIC WITH NEW AND USED QUALITY FURNITURE, BUILDING SUPPLIES, APPLIANCES AND OTHER HOUSEHOLD GOODS. THE RESTORE SUPPORTS THE BASIC HABITAT MISSION BY RAISING ADDITIONAL FUNDING FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF NEW AFFORDABLE HOUSING. THE HFHYC RESTORE WILL RECYCLE AND PROMOTE SUSTAINABLE BUILDING PRACTICES THROUGHOUT YORK COUNTY BY HELPING TO DIVERT CONSTRUCTION AND BUILDING MATERIALS FROM LANDFILLS. AGING IN PLACE PROGRAM: WE PARTNER WITH FAMILIES, COMMUNITIES, AND LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS TO HELP OLDER ADULTS IMPROVE THEIR HOMES AND THEIR QUALITY OF LIFE SO THAT THEY CAN FLOURISH WHERE THEY LIVE. THIS PERSON-CENTERED APPROACH TAILORS THE PROCESS TO EACH HOMEOWNER'S NEEDS. THESE ASSESSMENTS, WHICH CONSIDER EVERYTHING FROM THE RESIDENT'S LIFESTYLE TO THEIR TYPE OF HOME, ALLOW US TO ADDRESS OLDER ADULTS' NEEDS HOLISTICALLY, IMPROVING THE LIKELIHOOD THAT THEY CAN AGE IN PLACE. DURING FISCAL YEAR 2024, HABITAT FOR HUMANITY YORK COUNTY HAS IMPROVED APPROXIMATELY 20 HOMES TO HELP OLDER ADULTS MANEUVER MORE EFFICIENTLY.
reason: The summary focuses on providing affordable housing and improving the quality of life for individuals and families, without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: COMMUNITY SERVICE - THE MAINE MIGRANT HEALTH PROGRAM IS A 330G MIGRANT VOUCHER PROGRAM. HOWEVER, IT DOES NOT OPERATE OUT OF A FIXED SITE OR ""BRICKS AND MORTAR"" HEALTH CENTER BUT THROUGH 4 MOBILE MEDICAL UNITS. MMHP'S SERVICES ARE PROVIDED WHERE THEY ARE MOST NEEDED, WHERE FARMWORKERS LIVE AND WORK. . MOBILE MEDICAL CLINICS, CARE COORDINATION, PESTICIDE SAFETY TRAININGS, HEALTH EDUCATION SESSIONS, ETC. ALL TAKE PLACE IN FARMWORKER COMMUNITIES - THEIR CAMPS, HOMES, AND WORK PLACES. THESE SERVICES ARE THE CORNERSTONE OF MIGRANT VOUCHER PROGRAMS ACROSS THE COUNTRY AND PROVIDE A STRONG BASE OF SUPPORTIVE SERVICES THAT CREATE ACCESS. MMHP'S EXISTING SERVICE AREA IS THE ENTIRE STATE OF MAINE (33,215 SQ M) WITH MAJOR HARVEST AREAS IN AROOSTOOK, HANCOCK, WASHINGTON, AND ANDROSCOGGIN COUNTIES. BOTH WASHINGTON AND AROOSTOOK QUALIFY AS ""VERY RURAL"", THEIR POPULATION DENSITY BEING 14.0/SQ M AND 11.6/SQ M, RESP. AROOSTOOK COUNTY HAS THE DISTINCT HONOR OF BEING THE ONLY COUNTY EAST OF THE MISSISSIPPI THAT QUALIFIES AS A FRONTIER DESIGNATED AREA. IN ADDITION, PARTS OF THESE MAJOR HARVEST AREAS HAVE BEEN CLASSIFIED AS HEALTH PROFESSIONAL SHORTAGE AREAS, MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED AREAS, OR AS HAVING A MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED POPULATION. UNFORTUNATELY, THEY ARE HOME TO MENTAL HEALTH AND DENTAL SHORTAGE AREAS AS WELL. MAINE STATE DEMOGRAPHICS ONLY ADD TO THE DIFFICULTIES MSFWS FACE. ADD TO THIS INADEQUATE TRANSPORTATION, GEOGRAPHIC ISOLATION, UNFAMILIARITY WITH LOCAL RESOURCES AND SYSTEMS, AS WELL AS THE INABILITY TO ARRANGE TIME OFF FROM WORK. THESE ARE THE BARRIERS MMHP'S COMMUNITY SERVICES ARE DESIGNED TO BRIDGE AND/OR ELIMINATE, THEREBY INCREASING ACCESS TO CARE. THESE COMMUNITY SERVICES ARE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH OUTREACH SERVICES INCLUDING HEALTH EDUCATION, CARE COORDINATION, PRESCRIPTION ASSISTANCE, TRANSPORTATION, ELIGIBILITY ASSISTANCE, MEDICAL INTERPRETATION, AND REFERRAL SERVICES TO LOCAL NETWORK PROVIDERS. STAFF ALSO SPEND TIME SCOUTING FOR NEW CREWS AND WORKERS TO ENSURE ALL WHO NEED SERVICES HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO ACCESS THEM. THUS, COMMUNITY SERVICES ARE AN INTEGRAL COMPONENT IN MMHP'S SUCCESS IN MEETING MIGRANT AND SEASONAL FARMWORKER NEEDS AND IN FULFILLING ITS MISSION TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH STATUS OF MAINE'S SEASONAL WORKERS AND THEIR FAMILIES. MEDICAL SERVICES - MMHP'S DIRECT MEDICAL SERVICES INCLUDE COMPREHENSIVE MOBILE CARE, ACCESS TO REFERRAL SERVICES, EMERGENCY ROOM CARE, AND COVERAGE FOR LABORATORY AND RADIOLOGY TESTING. MMHP BRINGS SERVICES DIRECTLY INTO WORKER CAMPS, COMMUNITIES, AND WORK SITES, AS WELL AS UTILIZING ITS STATEWIDE REFERRAL (VOUCHER) NETWORK OF MEDICAL PROVIDERS. THIS UNIQUE COMBINATION OF DIRECT CLINICAL CARE AND VOUCHER ARRANGEMENTS WITH LOCAL PROVIDERS ENSURES THAT MAINE'S MIGRANT AND SEASONAL FARMWORKERS HAVE ACCESS TO CARE THAT IS APPROPRIATE, TIMELY, AND COST-EFFECTIVE. THIS MODEL ALSO ENSURES GREATER RESPONSIVENESS TO FARMWORKERS' NEEDS, DESIGNED WITH AN INHERENT LEVEL OF FLEXIBILITY TO ACCOMMODATE EVER-CHANGING CIRCUMSTANCES AFFECTING FARMWORKER AND CARE. DENTAL AND PHARMACY SERVICES - DENTAL AND PHARMACY SERVICES ARE BOTH PROVIDED SOLELY UNDER VOUCHER ARRANGEMENT AS MMHP'S MOBILE MEDICAL UNITS (MMUS) ARE NOT EQUIPPED OR STAFFED TO PROVIDE THEM DIRECTLY ON-SITE. A NUMBER OF DENTISTS AND PHARMACIES PARTICIPATE IN MMHP'S PROVIDER NETWORK IN THE COMMUNITIES WHERE WORKERS LIVE AND WORK. OVER THE PAST TWO YEARS, MMHP SUCCESSFULLY ADDED A NUMBER OF DENTAL PRACTICES TO ITS PROVIDER NETWORK. SOME PRACTICES BRING STAFF AND EQUIPMENT OUT INTO THE FIELD TO PROVIDE SERVICES ON-SITE, ALSO OPENING DOORS AFTER HOURS SOLELY FOR MSFWS. THESE TECHNIQUES HAVE RESULTED IN STEADILY INCREASING ACCESS TO DENTAL SERVICE EACH YEAR. MOBILE MEDICAL UNITS - AS DISCUSSED, PART OF MAINE MIGRANT'S UNIQUE MODEL OF SERVICE DELIVERY IS DIRECT DELIVERY OF CARE AT WORKER CAMPS, IN COMMUNITIES, AND AT WORK SITES. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS, MMHP OPERATES A FLEET OF VEHICLES DESIGNED AND UTILIZED AS MOBILE MEDICAL CENTERS. THESE MOBILE MEDICAL UNITS (MMUS) ARE STAFFED BY CLINICAL STAFF AND BILINGUAL STAFF WHO ENSURE THAT CLINICS RUN SMOOTHLY AND EFFICIENTLY AND THAT FARMWORKER NEEDS ARE IDENTIFIED CORRECTLY AND TREATED APPROPRIATELY CONTRACTED INTERPRETATION SERVICES ARE UTILIZED WHEN WORKER LANGUAGES ARE NOT SPOKEN BY STAFF. CLINICS ARE GENERALLY SCHEDULED AFTER HARVEST WORK HOURS. WHEN NECESSARY, ARRANGEMENTS ARE MADE AND ASSISTANCE PROVIDED FOR ANY REFERRALS TO LOCAL NETWORK VOUCHER PROVIDERS. EXPENSES 94,959 INCLUDING GRANTS OF 0. REVENUE 0 BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES - DUE TO AN OVERWHELMING DECLARATION OF NEED BY MIGRANT AND SEASONAL FARMWORKERS, BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES WERE INTEGRATED INTO MMHP'S CORE SERVICES IN 2009. THESE SERVICES WORK HAND-IN- HAND TO SUPPORT AND ENHANCE THE PROVISION OF QUALITY PRIMARY, PREVENTIVE, AND CHRONIC HEALTH CARE SERVICES TO SEASONAL WORKERS ACROSS THE STATE. BEHAVIORAL SERVICES CURRENTLY INCLUDE MENTAL HEALTH AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE COUNSELING WITH REFERRAL FOR TREATMENT. . BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE IS PROVIDED DIRECTLY ON THE MMUS AS WELL AS THROUGH A NUMBER OF VOUCHER (REFERRAL) PROVIDERS. EXPENSES 20,760 INCLUDING GRANTS OF 0. REVENUE 77
reason: The summary focuses on healthcare services for migrant workers and does not mention any religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: Support over 100 chapters and a dozen national projects through training, website, enews, newsletters, social media, database management, member organizing, & facilitating an annual convention. Engage in public and decision maker education by creating media, direct engagement and supporting hundreds of local actions carried out by chapters and independent members. VFP builds veteran and ally communities that reject war culture and global militarism and takes action to expose the true cost of war. Direct services also include advocating for the repatriation of deported veterans, providing clean drinking water and addressing long term health impacts to war recovering regions like Iraq and Viet Nam, and overturning the privatization of the VA so military veterans receive proper health care.
