mission: CLINICAL TRIALS ARE DESIGNED TO DEVELOP NEW DEVICES, EVALUATE NEW MEDICATIONS, IMPROVE MATERIALS AND SYSTEMS, AND IMPROVE SURGICAL PROCEDURES. AT THE PRESENT TIME, THE ORTHOCAROLINA RESEARCH INSTITUTE IS FACILITATING THIRTY FDA-CONTROLLED CLINICAL TRIALS THAT SERVE AND SUPPORT THE PUBLIC IN PROVIDING STATE-OF-THE-ART SURGICAL AND NON-SURGICAL TREATMENT OPTIONS. SCIENTIFIC OUTCOMES STUDIES ARE DESIGNED TO PROVIDE DATA AND INFORMATION SUPPORTS, AND/OR OPPOSES, NEW METHODS OF TREATMENT, AND DETERMINES NEW TECHNOLOGY IN ORDER TO PROVIDE THE BEST TREATMENT OPTIONS FOR PATIENTS. CLINICAL RESEARCH STUDIES ALLOW PHYSICIANS TO PROVIDE IMPROVED PATIENT CARE, EVALUATE THE RESULTS OF NEW PROCEDURES, INSURE THAT THE TREATMENTS PROVIDED ARE THE BEST AVAILABLE, PROMOTE COST EFFECTIVE TREATMENT PROGRAMS, AND DOCUMENT PATIENT SATISFACTION AND QUALITY OF LIFE.ALL CLINICAL TRIALS AND SCIENTIFIC OUTCOMES STUDIES ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY THE INSTITUTE'S RESEARCH ADVISORY COMMITTEE (RAC), THE INSTITUTIONAL REVIEW BOARD (IRB) AT CAROLINAS HEALTHCARE SYSTEM (CHS) OR CHARLOTTE ORTHOPEDIC HOSPITAL (COH) PRIOR TO IMPLEMENTATION. STRINGENT PROTOCOLS ARE REQUIRED TO ENSURE THE SAFETY OF ALL PARTICIPATING INDIVIDUALS AND TO MAKE CERTAIN THAT PARTICIPATING SURGEONS FOLLOW THE SAME STUDY PROCEDURES AND GUIDELINES. THE ORTHOCAROLINA RESEARCH INSTITUTE HAS HOSTED THE OSCAR MILLER DAY SYMPOSIUM FOR OVER 30 YEARS. THIS CONTINUING MEDICAL EDUCATION EVENT HOSTS 300 TO 450 ORTHOPEDIC PROVIDERS AND ALLIED HEALTH PROFESSIONALS ANNUALLY. THE ACCREDITED ONE DAY SYMPOSIUM IS PRICED ONLY TO COVER COSTS AND ROTATES ORTHOPEDIC SUB-SPECIALTIES EACH YEAR. THE PROGRAM INVITES GUEST SPEAKERS FROM ACROSS THE COUNTRY WHO ARE KNOWN LEADERS IN THE FIELD OF ORTHOPEDICS TO HIGHLIGHT NEW TRENDS, TECHNIQUES AND RESEARCH. THE EVENT IS MARKETED TO THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES. THE IPASS (INJURY PREVENTION ACROSS SPORTS WITH SCIENCE) CHARITY EVENT ORIGINATED IN 2013. THIS EVENT IS MEANT TO BE A FUNDRAISER BUT MORE IMPORTANTLY AN AVENUE TO EDUCATE THE LAY COMMUNITY ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF INJURY PREVENTION AND ORTHOPEDIC RESEARCH. THE EVENT INCLUDES A SILENT AUCTION, SEATED DINNER, GUEST CELEBRITY TABLE HOSTS, AND A PROGRAM FULL OF EDUCATIONAL PRESENTATIONS HIGHLIGHTING THE IMPORTANCE OF ORTHOPEDIC RESEARCH AND ADVANCEMENT.
reason: The summary focuses on clinical trials, medical research, and orthopedic education, with no mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: RSTTA SUMMER CAMP: RSTTA'S EIGHT-WEEK SUMMER TENNIS & ENRICHMENT CAMP INCLUDES TENNIS, LIFE SKILLS, EDUCATION, AND COMMUNITY ACTIVITIES. EACH DAY, STUDENTS RECEIVE A HEALTHY BREAKFAST AND LUNCH, PARTICIPATE IN TENNIS DRILLS AND GAMES, AND ENGAGE IN LIFE SKILLS ACTIVITIES. DURING THE AFTERNOON, STUDENTS RECEIVE ACADEMIC SUPPORT FROM OUR TUTORS AND PARTICIPATE IN AN ARTS CURRICULUM. IN ADDITION, OUR STUDENTS HEAR FROM GUEST SPEAKERS AND GO ON FIELD TRIPS TO LEARN MORE ABOUT THEIR COMMUNITY AND THEMSELVES. DURING OUR SUMMER CAMP, WE WERE ABLE TO ANALYZE DATA FROM THE ONLINE IXL TO SHOW THAT STUDENTS MADE PROGRESS IN 227 COMMON CORE MATH SKILLS AT ALL GRADE LEVELS. THROUGH OUR TENNIS COMPONENTS, WE MEASURED BOTH TENNIS SKILLS AND FITNESS LEVELS. OF THE STUDENTS ASSESSED, 82% WERE ABLE TO MAINTAIN OR IMPROVE PERFORMANCE IN 7/8 STROKES. 58% OF STUDENTS IMPROVED IN AT LEAST 4 OF THE 5 FITNESS ACTIVITIES TESTED, WHICH INCLUDED AN ENDURANCE JOG, SIT-UPS, PLANK, RUN-BEEP TEST, AND A SHUTTLE RUN. COMMUNITY-BASED: RSTTA CURRENTLY RUNS TWO COMMUNITY PROGRAMS FROM SEPTEMBER - MAY EACH YEAR. THE RISING ALL-STARS PROGRAM SERVES 2ND - 12TH GRADE STUDENTS FOUR DAYS A WEEK. STUDENTS START EACH AFTERNOON WITH A HEALTHY SNACK AND HOMEWORK HELP. TUTORS PROVIDE INDIVIDUAL AND SMALL GROUP INSTRUCTION TO STRENGTHEN READING, MATH, AND LANGUAGE ARTS COMPREHENSION. STUDENTS THEN TAKE PART IN PHYSICAL FITNESS EXERCISES, LIFE SKILLS ACTIVITIES, AND TENNIS. RSTTA'S TENNIS INSTRUCTORS USE SHORTER NETS, SMALLER RACKETS AND LOW-COMPRESSION BALLS, WHICH BUILDS CONFIDENCE IN OUR YOUNG PLAYERS. THE PATH TO SUCCESS PROGRAM SERVES INTERMEDIATE AND ADVANCED LEVEL MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS. STUDENTS TAKE PART IN INTENSIVE TENNIS AND LIFE SKILLS CLINICS ONCE EACH WEEK. STUDENTS IN OUR PATH TO SUCCESS PROGRAM ARE INVITED TO JOIN US DURING THE WEEK TO WORK ON PRE-SAT AND SAT PREPARATION, COLLEGE APPLICATIONS, OR DAY-TO-DAY ASSIGNMENTS. THIS PAST YEAR, WE HAD 100% OF OUR SENIORS GRADUATE ON TIME AND ATTEND THE FOLLOWING SCHOOLS: UNIVERSITY OF DELAWARE, DELAWARE TECHNICAL COMMUNITY COLLEGE, AND RENSSELAER POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE. SCHOOL SITES: THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVES OF RSTTA'S SCHOOL SITES PROGRAM ARE TO (1) DEVELOP POSITIVE LIFE SKILLS THAT WILL HELP STUDENTS SUCCEED IN AND OUTSIDE OF SCHOOL; (2) FOSTER STUDENTS' APPRECIATION OF AND COMMITMENT TO TENNIS, HEALTH, AND NUTRITION; AND (3) PARTNER WITH EACH SCHOOL TO EXPAND THE SUPPORTIVE COMMUNITY THAT ENCOURAGES THE GROWTH AND SUCCESS OF EACH STUDENT. WE WORK WITH EACH SCHOOL TO CREATE A MODEL THAT BEST FITS THE NEEDS OF THEIR STUDENTS. THIS PROGRAM WAS LAUNCHED IN NOVEMBER 2016 WITH TWO LOCAL SCHOOLS AND HAS SEEN IMPROVEMENT IN STUDENTS' COMPREHENSION OF CRITICAL LIFE SKILLS).
reason: The summary focuses on secular activities such as tennis, life skills, education, and community programs without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: NutritionBSRI exists to promote the well-being and enhance the quality of life for all senior adults, 60 years of age and older, in Brunswick County, North Carolina. It advocates for programs and delivers services encouraging and sustaining independence and continued participation in the community. Brunswick County has designated BSRI as its lead agency for senior services. Current operations are diverse and fall under the broad categories of congregate nutritional services, home-bound meals on wheels, senior center and senior site operations, case management, in-home aide services and general transportation. For the year ended June 30, 2014, BSRI delivered 54,034 meals to homebound residents, provided 41,047 meals in a congregate setting and provided 6,482 units of general and medical transportation. Senior Center OperationsBSRI operates multi-purpose senior centers in Leland, Shallotte and Southport as well as six nutrition sites situated across the county. The organizations administrative offices are located in Shallotte. Case ManagementBSRI provided 768 prescriptions for 1,367 clients, saving Brunswick County Seniors an estimated $1,493,000 in out-of-pocket expenses.
reason: The summary focuses on providing nutritional and support services for senior adults without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: To provide In-Home supportive services for the Community of Mono county in California. These services include but are not restricted to the operation of registeries to screen providers before they go into senior citizens homes so that abuse and neglect is reduced. Additionally, providers are screened for alcohol and drug use, and any prior history of elderly abuse. Providers give services to low income seniors and disabled so that they may stay in their homes and not go to Nursing homes. We chair and facilitate the IHSS Advisory Committee in Mono County for the purposes of making recommendations to the Board of Supervisors about efficient delivery of countywide services to IHSS consumers, program implementation, program updates, and distribution of program service materials.We administer the USDAs SNAP-Ed nutrition education program in Mono, Alpine, and Inyo Counties. Through this program, we provide nutrition education and physical activity interventions to residents who utilize, or are likely eligible, for food stamps (SNAP). We teach nutrition and physical activity lessons to students in K-12 schools; host taste tests of fruits and vegetables at schools and food banks; and strategize with school administration and county partners to create healthier schools and communities through policy, systems, and environmental changes. We administer the Reentry Coordination Program for the Mono County Sheriffs Department. We meet with inmates at the County Jail during their incarceration and create individualized plans for inmates to assist with their transition back into society. We set up services for counseling, substance abuse treatment, domestic violence classes, DUI classes, housing, employment assistance, and other essential services. We also help inmates enroll in health insurance and food stamps. We established and maintain the In-Home Supportive Service Provider Registry in Mono County to assist the elderly and disabled in finding in-home care. We investigate the qualifications and background of potential providers; make referrals of IHSS providers to recipients; provide training and ongoing education to providers and recipients on how to provide services, mandated reporting, and compliance with State regulations.We implemented and administer the IHSS Quality Assurance programs for Mono County and Alpine County to enhance the quality of services received by IHSS recipients. We create policies and procedures for County staff to implement the program; perform desk audits of case files, as well as home visits, to ensure program compliance and prevent fraud.
reason: The summary focuses on providing in-home supportive services, nutrition education, and reentry coordination for inmates, which are secular activities without any mention of religious or faith-based motivations.

mission: Public Outreach includes responding to public information requests and social media outreach to inspire more to register as donors. As of June 30, 2018, the Facebook page had more than 12,000 followers. Donate Life uses Facebook to reach constituents and others who have an interest in organ, eye and tissue donation. DMV Outreach - Focuses on educating Division of Motor Vehicles Examiners and State-level leaders about the important partnership between the NC Donor Registry and Donate Life NC. We also provide information and volunteers through the DMV offices to educate the public as they get ready to be asked whether they want to register as a donor when they get their driver's license. There are 600 DMV Examiners and we trained about 200 new ones this past year. We have 60-75 volunteer DMV Ambassadors who have visited those offices quarterly, updating materials and sharing data on office donor designation rates. By the end of June 2018, more than 5.1 million North Carolina donors were registered through the DMV. Minority Outreach - Increasing awareness of organ donation and address myths and misconceptions within minority communities across North Carolina. A major initiative of this program is our Historically Black College and University Champions program, which develops sustainable relationships with the 15 HBCU campuses across North Carolina, and hosted active donor registration programs on 8 of the 15 HBCU campuses in Fiscal Year 2018.
reason: The summary focuses on organ donation outreach and education, which are secular activities without any religious or faith-based motivation.

mission: Stepping Stones Project currently has eight Coming of Age groups that serve 50 middle schoolers, grades 6-8, and two groups that serve 11 high schoolers, grades 9 and 10. We have 12 paid group leaders who are paid for 10 hours per month, 4 that are paid on average 3 hours per month, one half-time staff member who works 20 hours per week and one quarter time staff member who works 10 hours per week. The Coming of Age groups meet on average two times per month, with a total average of six hours of face time per month. During the groups the youth participate in activities, council, and sometimes nature hikes. The groups go on a 2-3 day backpacking trip each summer. Each pair of group leaders has a mentor that they consult with one hour per month, and all leaders attend a two-hour peer consultation meeting twice every quarter.

mission: OUTREACH / EDUCATION PROGRAMIN 2007, THE FINANCIAL PLANNING COMMITTEE OF DBG PRESENTED A MARKETING PLAN TO THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS. IT ALSO WAS INTENDED TO INCREASE AWARENESS OF THE GARDENS AND THEIR UNIQUE CONTRIBUTION TO DUNSMUIR AND SOUTHERN SISKIYOU COUNTY. IN 2011, THE DBG HAS WORKED TO EXPAND THE EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH TO THE IDENTIFIED TARGET MARKETS: CHILDREN, OTHER SOUTHERN SISKIYOU COUNTY COMMUNITIES, AREA BUSINESSES, TRAVELERS AND DUNSMUIR CITIZENS.WEBSITE:DBG CONTINUES TO MAINTAIN AND DEVELOP THE WEBSITE FOR THE PROMOTION OF THE ORGANIZATION'S MISSION AND ACTIVITIES. THE BROCHURE IS PROFESSIONALLY DESIGNED AND WIDELY DISTRIBUTED IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA, SOUTHERN OREGON AND DUNSMUIR.PHOTO CONTEST:AGAIN, WE HELD THE ANNUAL PHOTO CONTEST OF THE DUNSMUIR BOTANICAL GARDENS ENDING WITH A GALLERY SHOWING IN NOVEMBER. VISITORS TO THE PHOTO GALLERY IN THE WEEKS LEADING UP TO THE SHOWING AND RECEPTION ARE ASKED TO VOTE FOR THEIR FAVORITE PHOTO FOR THE PEOPLE'S CHOICE AWARD. THE DIVISION WINNERS RECEIVE $50.00 AND THE PHOTOS ARE USED FOR MARKETING AND PROMOTION OF THE GARDENS.DOGWOOD DAZE:THE DBG JOINED OTHER COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS BY PRTICIPATING IN THE CITY-WIDE ""DOGWOOD DAZE"" CELEBRATION AND PROVIDED GUIDED TOURS OF THE BOTANICAL GARDENS' NATIVE DOGWOOD COLLECTION. SHASTA, REDDING AND MEDFORD WERE LED BY GARDENS' VOLUNTEERS DURING THE YEAR.OWL WORKSHOP:A WORKSHOP TO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC OF THE CONTRIBUTIONS OWLS MAKE IN NATURE WAS WELL ATTENDED. THE EVENT WAS PLANNED IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE ROAD SCHOLARS (A GROUP OF GRANDPARENTS AND THEIR GRANDCHILDEN WHO SPEND A WEEK TOGETHER IN A UNIQUE SETTING IN THE DUNSMUIR AREA) VISIT TO THE GARDENS. A LOCAL FALCONER PRESENTED THE INFORMATION AND MEMBERS OF THE BOTANICAL GARDENS SERVED THEM DINNER.VOLUNTEER FAIR:THE OBJECTIVE OF THE VOLUNTEER FAIR IS TO PROVIDE A NEW SOURCE OF COMMITTED GARDEN VOLUNTEERS WHOSE RESPONSIBILITY WOULD BE TO DEVELOP AND MAINTAIN THE GARDENS, REDUCE THE RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE GARDENS HORTICULTURALIST AND DEFINE AND FORMULATE THE INDIVIDUAL VOLUNTEER RESPONSIBILITES AND SPECIFIC JOB DESCRIPTIONS FOR THE GARDENS VOLUNTEERS.THE DUNSMUIR BOTANICAL GARDENS VOLUNTEER FAIR WAS THE KICK-OFF FOR THE FORMATION OF THE BOTANICAL GARDENS STEWARD PROGRAM. THIS TEAM OF GARDENS VOLUNTEERS WILL ASSIST THE GARDENS HORTICULTURALIST AND PART-TIME GARDENER, PARTICIPATE IN ON-GOING GARDENS' PROGRAMS BY PROVIDING GUIDED TOURS OF THE GARDENS, MONITORING THE HEALTH OF THE GARDENS ON A WEEKLY BASIS, PARTICIPATING IN THE SPRING PLANTING, ORGANIZING AND PRESENTING EDUCATION WORKSHOPS AND ASSISTING WITH PUBLIC RELATIONS ACTIVITIES.

mission: COMMUNICATIONS & PUBLICATIONS - GEO RAISES AWARENESS THAT WILL CATALYZE CHANGE IN THE FIELD OF PHILANTHROPY. WE ENGAGE IN ONGOING FIELD-WIDE COMMUNICATION EFFORTS TO ACCOMPLISH THIS. IN 2017, GEO DREW ATTENTION TO GRANTMAKING PRACTICES THAT SUPPORT NONPROFIT RESULTS THROUGH MEDIA OUTREACH, PRESENTING AT CONFERENCES, PRODUCING PUBLICATIONS, AND USING ONLINE TOOLS SUCH AS THE GEO WEBSITE, SOCIAL MEDIA OUTLETS, MEMBER LIST-SERVES, AND E-NEWSLETTERS. CONFERENCES - GEO CONFERENCES EDUCATE AND INSPIRE ACTION. IN 2017, WE HOSTED TWO SMALLER, MORE INTIMATE CONFERENCES IN THE SPRING AND THE FALL. KNOWING THAT LEARNING FOR IMPROVEMENT IS AT THE CENTER OF EFFECTIVE GRANTMAKING, WE CONVENED 300+ PARTICIPANTS IN CHICAGO FOR OUR BIENNIAL LEARNING CONFERENCE SO THEY CAN GO BEYOND BASICS, THINK CRITICALLY ON HOW GRANTMAKERS CAN BETTER LEARN WITH THEIR PARTNERS AND GRANTEES AND TAKE HOME TOOLS THAT WILL HELP TURN LEARNING INTO ACTION. IN THE FALL, 200+ GRANTMAKERS TRAVELED TO PITTSBURGH TO LEARN HOW TO LEAD CHANGE. PARTICIPANTS LEARNED FROM EXPERTS AND PEERS ON HOW THEY CAN EQUIP THEMSELVES WITH THE TOOLS, SKILLS AND FRAMEWORKS TO IMPLEMENT CHANGE IN THEIR ORGANIZATION THAT WILL RESULT IN BETTER SUPPORT FOR GRANTEES. MEMBER PROGRAMS - GEO IS A DIVERSE COMMUNITY OF MORE THAN 600 GRANTMAKING ORGANIZATIONS REPRESENTING MORE THAN 6,000 GRANTMAKERS WORKING TO RESHAPE THE WAY PHILANTHROPY OPERATES. GRANTMAKERS ADDRESSED SHARED CHALLENGES IN GRANTMAKING THROUGH GEO'S PEER LEARNING PROGRAMS - WEBINARS, MEMBER CALLS AND REMOTE LEARNING SERIES. OTHER MEMBER PROGRAMS INCLUDE ACTIVITIES UNDER THE LEADING CHANGE IN PHILANTHROPY INITIATIVE WHICH FOUND NEW WAYS FOR MEMBERS TO COME TOGETHER TO ADDRESS THE BARRIERS TO ADOPTING GRANTMAKING PRACTICES THAT SUPPORT GRANTEE SUCCESS. THESE OPPORTUNITIES ALLOW MEMBERS TO TALK ABOUT THE CHALLENGES THEY ARE FACING, AND WORK THROUGH COMPLEX CHANGES WITHIN THEIR ORGANIZATION AND ADVOCATE FOR THOSE PRACTICES ACROSS THE FIELD. EVALUATION & LEARNING - LEARNING FOR IMPROVEMENT IS A KEY COMPONENT OF OUR CHANGE AGENDA AND WE STRIVE TO ""WALK THE TALK"" INTERNALLY. WE DO NOT JUST COLLECT DATA-WE PURPOSELY STOP TO MAKE MEANING OUT OF IT THROUGH ALL-STAFF DISCUSSIONS, BEFORE/AFTER ACTION REVIEWS, DEBRIEFS AND HUMAN-CENTERED DESIGN EXERCISES TO GET AT THE HEART OF MEMBER NEEDS. GEO REGULARLY ENGAGES IN INTERNAL LEARNING AND EVALUATION, SOLICITING FEEDBACK FROM PARTICIPANTS AFTER EACH PROGRAM TO LEARN WHAT IT TAKES TO INSTITUTE CHANGES IN THEIR ORGANIZATIONS. WE ALSO ASSESS GEO'S IMPACT THROUGH OUR MEMBER SURVEY AND FIELD STUDY WHICH PROVIDES SNAPSHOTS INTO THE WAYS GRANTMAKERS SUPPORT NONPROFIT SUCCESS AND HOW GEO MEMBERSHIP IMPACTED THEIR ABILITY TO DO SO.
reason: The summary focuses on philanthropy, grantmaking practices, and organizational learning without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: CENTER RIDGE OUTPOST: Summer CampsKAMP KALEIDOSCOPE - This is Mississippi's only sleepover camp for children with autism ranging in age from 7 to 17. The camp offers children with autism the opportunity to experience a real summer camp, an opportunity they might not have otherwise. During the summer of 2012 the Outpost hosted a total of 154 campers in this age range. CAMP WALAPEI - This is a summer camp for graduates of Kamp Kaleidoscope ages 18 and over. The program includes a strong emphasis on music, arts and crafts, horseback riding and making friends. Program offers an age appropriate option for older campers. During the summer of 2012 the Outpost hosted a total of 36 campers. In addition to the 190 campers that were served in the Summer of 2012, the Outpost also hosted a total of 130 volunteers ages 14 and up. Annual Autism Palooza 5K Mud Run and Fun Day - An Autism Awareness Mud Run was held to heighten awareness of autism in Mississippi. Participants came from across the state to have fun and learn about autism spectrum disorders. All were invited to gather new information about services surrounding autism by walking down information alley where more than 25 vendors had their products and services on display. Approximately 400 people participated in the day.Meridian Awareness 5K Run - This event is the Organization's East Central Mississippi installment of the same program above, without the mud. This program is heavily supported by the Navy base at Meridian. Approximately 300 people participated in the day.Coast Awareness Walk - This annual event was held in Biloxi, MS and is a sister program to the 5K Run. This format is held around a walk only venue. Approximately 200 people participated in the day.Trivia Night - This annual event was held in Ocean Springs, MS. All participants competed in a trivia contest. There was also an auction and silent auction to help raise money.Zombie 5K Autism Awareness Run - This first time event was held at the same location of the 5K Mud Run. All participants dressed as their favorite ghoul and ran the mud course. Approximately 125 runners participated in this event.Annual Crawfish Boil - An Autism Awareness event featuring a crawfish boil was held that attracted approximately 300 participants. All had fun and many were exposed to autism and the challenges that families face. RETREAT PROGRAMS: Spring and FallADVENTURES IN RECREATION FOR ALL YOUTH (ARAY) - This is an adventure based program for youth ages 12 to 20. This program is a series of weekend retreats that are theme driven and focus on introducing new and exciting opportunities to learn, have fun and make friends. Four program events were held in 2012. ADVENTURES WITHOUT BOUNDARIES - This program is for young adults and adults ages 18 and up. It is the companion program to ARAY for those focused on more adult based outdoor programs. One program event was held in 2012. FAMILY TRAINING RETREATS - This program provides training to families in developing a life plan and gives families one-on-one access to leading professionals in the field. It provides direction to plan for a lifetime not just the moment. One program event was held in 2012. SELF-ADVOCACY RETREAT - This program provides opportunities for building self-esteem and creates a network for individuals to find support and friends. Training is offered to help empower individuals toward a life of independence. One program event was held in 2012.
reason: The summary focuses on summer camps and events related to autism awareness and does not mention any religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: SCHOOL PROGRAM ACCOMPLISHMENTS: NASHOBA LEARNING GROUP, INC. (NLG) OPERATES A FULL-YEAR DAY SCHOOL PROGRAM (THE SCHOOL PROGRAM) THAT PROVIDES OUTSTANDING, COMPREHENSIVE, INDIVIDUALIZED EDUCATION, TRAINING, AND INTERVENTION SERVICES FOR STUDENTS AGED 3 THROUGH 21 WITH AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDERS (ASD). AS OF THE END OF THE FISCAL YEAR THE NUMBER OF STUDENTS SERVED WAS 101. THE SCHOOL PROGRAM IS BASED ON THE SCIENTIFICALLY VALIDATED PRINCIPLES OF APPLIED BEHAVIOR ANALYSIS (ABA), DELIVERED BY HIGHLY TRAINED AND SUPERVISED TEACHING STAFF, AND CUSTOMIZED FOR EACH STUDENT IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE FAMILY. PROGRAM SERVICE FEE REVENUE, WHICH COMPRISES THE ORGANIZATION'S PRIMARY REVENUE SOURCE, IS DERIVED PRIMARLY FROM MASSACHUSETTS SCHOOL DISTRICTS. IN JULY 2015, THE SCHOOL PROGRAM EXPANDED OPERATIONS TO ACCOMMODATE 40 ADDITIONAL STUDENTS, BRINGING THE NEW CAPACITY TO 130 STUDENTS. THE ORGANIZATION ANTICIPATES IT WILL REACH THIS NEW CAPACITY OVER APPROXIMATELY THREE YEARS. ADULT PROGRAM ACCOMPLISHMENTS: IN MARCH 2013, THE ORGANIZATION STARTED OPERATING AN ADULT DAY PROGRAM (THE ADULT PROGRAM) WITH A MAXIMUM CAPACITY OF 50 MEMBERS TO PROVIDE ONGOING DAY HABILITATION, JOB AND COMMUNITY SUPPORT TO ADULTS AGED 22 AND OLDER WITH AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDERS.THE ADULT PROGRAM TARGETS CONTINUED SKILLS DEVELOPMENT AND BEHAVIOR SUPPORT USING THE PRINCIPLES OF ABA FOR THE MEMBERS WITH THE GOAL OF INCREASING INDEPENDENCE AND GRADUALLY REDUCING THE NEED FOR TRAINED SUPERVISION OVER TIME. ADULT PROGRAM SERVICE FEE REVENUE IS DERIVED FROM MASSHEALTH FOR DAY HABILITATION SERVICES AND THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF DISABILITY SERVICES (DDS) FOR JOB TRAINING , EMPLOYMENT AND COMMUNITY SERVICES.
reason: The summary focuses on educational and support services for individuals with autism spectrum disorders, with no mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: In 2020 MLKCC continued with sponsoring the series of community events in observance of the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Holiday. The community events included a gospel musical community worship service MLKCC banquet parade & rally and poster & essay contest for students. Additionally pre-program activities were initiated for a virtual 2021 celebration. Virtual Learning Assistance - To assist students with virtual classroom learning due to school closure because of the Covid-19 pandemic 20 chromebooks were purchased and donated to students. The students were identified through a screening process done by the non-profit organization Hope For Tomorrow. A grant was awarded to the Boys and Girls Club of Brazoria County to assist with providing a place for children of essential workers to stay during the day to do virtual learning. Covid-19 Assistance. MLKCC prepared 500 covid-19 protective kits to distribute to individuals in the Freeport Angleton,Brazoria and Clute communities. The kits contained hand sanitizer and soap antibacterial wipes gloves masks kleenex and information on preventing the spread of the Covid-19 virus. An additional 100 hand sanitizer kits were prepared and distributed in the Sweeny community. To assist families with food purchases due to loss of jobs or reduced working hours because of businesses having to close because of the rising number of Covid-19 case in the county gift cards purchased from local grocery stores were purchased and randomly distributed to shopper at the stores the cards were purchased from. The target population was senior citizens and families with children.
reason: The summary mentions a 'gospel musical community worship service' and emphasizes community events in observance of the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Holiday, which reflects a faith-based motivation.

mission: THE FOUNDATION WAS ESTABLISHED IN FEBRUARY 2002 TO CONTINUE THE TRADITION OF CARING FIRST INSTILLED BY DR. WARREN EDWARD MILLER, WHO ESTABLISHED THE FIRST 12-PATIENT HOSPITAL IN WHITEVILLE IN 1935. THE FOUNDATION'S GOAL IS TO STRENGTHEN OUR MEDICAL RESOURCES RIGHT HERE AT HOME.THE FOUNDATION IS A NOT-FOR-PROFIT ORGANIZATION GOVERNED BY A VOLUNTEER BOARD OF DIRECTORS. THROUGH CHARITABLE GIFTS, THE FOUNDATION HELPS MEET THE DEMAND FOR MODERN EQUIPMENT AND SERVICES THAT BUILD UPON THE COMMUNITY'S HEALTH RESOURCES.THE FOUNDATION IS CHARGED WITH RAISING AND ADMINISTERING FUNDS THAT WILL BE USED TO FURTHER CHARITABLE, EDUCATIONAL AND HEALTHCARE OBJECTIVES OF THE COLUMBUS REGIONAL HEALTHCARE SYSTEM, AS WELL AS DEVELOP AND ADMINISTER FUNDRAISING CAMPAIGNS TO HELP CRHS MEET ITS SHORT- AND LONG-RANGE GOALS. AS MORE AND MORE STATE AND FEDERAL GOVERNMENT AND PRIVATE INSURERS CONTINUE TO CUT AND RESTRICT REIMBURSEMENT PAYMENTS TO HOSPITALS, THE FOUNDATION IS ONE WAY TO ASSIST IN COMPENSATING FOR THIS LOSS IN REVENUE.
reason: The summary focuses on healthcare and charitable activities without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: IN 2019, PRESERVATION CHICAGO PLAYED A DECISIVE ROLE IN THE EFFORT TO SAVE THE SUPERIOR STREET ROWHOUSES FROM IMMINENT DEMOLITION WHICH, AGAINST ALL ODDS, SAVED THESE BUILDINGS AND PROACTIVELY PROTECTED OVER A DOZEN OTHER THREATENED TOWNHOUSE BUILDINGS THROUGH THE CREATION OF A NEW CHICAGO LANDMARK DISTRICT. WE HELPED TO ENSURE HIGH-QUALITY PRESERVATION RESTORATION AT CHICAGO UNION STATION AND GENERATED PRESSURE TO ENCOURAGE THE RENOVATION OF THE LONG-VACANT FRED HARVEY SPACE. WE SUPPORTED PRESERVATION EFFORTS AT COOK COUNTY HOSPITAL, OLD MAIN POST OFFICE, AND THE POTENTIAL RESTORATION OF THE UPTOWN THEATRE.ADDITIONALLY, IN 2019 PRESERVATION CHICAGO PLAYED AN ACTIVE ROLE IN HELPING TO BRING ABOUT PRESERVATION-SENSITIVE OUTCOMES REGARDING THE PILSEN PRELIMINARY LANDMARK DISTRICT, RAMOVA THEATER, PATIO THEATER, CLARENDON PARK FIELD HOUSE, THE JEFFERSON PARK FIREHOUSE, 226 W. JACKSON, HARTMAN BUILDING/BENNETT BROTHERS BUILDING, 29 S. LASALLE STREET, WEST SIDE DUNCAN YMCA/YWCA, THE NEW ROOF AT THE SHRINE OF CHRIST THE KING, PULLMAN NATIONAL MONUMENT, SEARS STORE ON LAWRENCE, 5TH CHURCH OF CHRIST SCIENTIST/SHILOH BAPTIST CHURCH, FULLERTON STATE BANK, VON HUMBOLDT SCHOOL, MOTLEY ELEMENTARY SCHOOL, HOLLANDER WAREHOUSE, MARK TWAIN SRO HOTEL, CADILLAC WAREHOUSE BUILDING ON MOTOR ROW, ART DECO BRIDGE HOUSE RENOVATIONS ON FRANKLIN DELANO ROOSEVELT MEMORIAL BRIDGE, LOGAN SQUARE BOYS AND GIRLS CLUB/FORMER TEMPLE BETH-EL, ""EAGLES BUILDING"" AT BROADWAY AND SHERIDAN, VILLAGE THEATER FACADE, 3244-3250 W. BRYN MAWR FACADE, WLS STUDIOS BUILDING AT 1230 W. WASHINGTON, CHURCH OF THE EPIPHANY, FIRST CHURCH OF DELIVERANCE, MUDDY WATERS' HOME, AND ADDITIONAL PROTECTION ORDINANCE FOR PILSEN HOMEOWNERS AGAINST PREDATORY BROKERS AND DEVELOPERS.WE WORKED BEHIND THE SCENES TO CREATE THE NECESSARY CIRCUMSTANCES AND THEN TESTIFIED IN SUPPORT OF THE CHICAGO LANDMARK DESIGNATIONS FOR TRUMBULL SCHOOL (INCLUDING INTERIOR FEATURES), MIES VAN DER ROHE'S PROMONTORY APARTMENTS, MT. PISGAH MISSIONARY CHURCH/SINAI TEMPLE, BLACKWELL-ISRAEL SAMUEL A.M.E. ZION CHURCH, CLAREMONT COTTAGES, JOHN NUVEEN HOUSE, AND THE SUPERIOR STREET ROWHOUSES/NEAR NORTH LANDMARK DISTRICT. WE PLAYED AN ESSENTIAL ROLE IN A PRESERVATION WIN FOR THE PERKINS-NORDINE HOUSE IN 2020.BUILDINGS LOSSES IN 2019 THAT PRESERVATION CHICAGO WORKED TO PREVENT INCLUDE CRAWFORD POWER STATION (CHICAGO 7 2014 & 2019) BY GRAHAM, ANDERSON, PROBST AND WHITE, 16 W. MAPLE, 2932 W. NORTH AVENUE, HEARTLAND CAFE, GATELY'S PEOPLES STORE IN ROSELAND DUE TO A DEVASTATING FIRE, THE AMERICAN TAXI SERVICE BUILDING, WACHOWSKI-RAY HOUSE IN JEFFERSON PARK, ST. JAMES TEMPLE/ST. NICHOLAS CHURCH IN ROSELAND DUE TO EMERGENCY DEMOLITION, THE 800 BLOCK OF WEST FULTON MARKET, COMED SUBSTATION AT 626 E. 40TH STREET (CHICAGO 7 2018), TRUC LAM TEMPLE/PAUL REVERE LODGE, 3726 N. LAKE SHORE DRIVE, TERRA COTTA FACADE AT 1315 W. LOYOLA AVENUE, 1517 W. BARRY AVENUE AND DOZENS OF HISTORIC HOME AND SMALL RESIDENTIAL BUILDING DEMOLITIONS THROUGHOUT CHICAGO'S NEIGHBORHOODS. AFTER A TOUGH, WELL-PUBLICIZED EFFORT INCLUDING A PETITION WITH OVER 6,000 SIGNATURES, THE CHICAGO TOWN AND TENNIS CLUB/UNITY CHURCH (CHICAGO 7 2020) WAS DEMOLISHED IN SPRING 2020. OUR EDUCATIONAL COMMUNITY OUTREACH HAS ALLOWED US TO MORE PROACTIVELY ENGAGE STAKEHOLDERS IN THEIR OWN NEIGHBORHOODS TO HELP TO CREATE THE CONDITIONS TO PROMOTE HEALTHY COMMUNITIES BY LEVERAGING THE POWER OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION. WHILE WE REMAIN ACTIVE IN ALL PARTS OF CHICAGO, THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF OUR COMMUNITY OUTREACH EFFORT HAS BEEN COMMUNITIES OF DISINVESTMENT AND COMMUNITIES OF COLOR. OUR EFFORTS IN ROSELAND TO LEVERAGE HISTORIC PRESERVATION TO PROMOTE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT WILL PROVIDE BENEFITS TO THE RESIDENTS OF ROSELAND. OUR EFFORTS TO RAISE THE PROFILE OF ROSELAND INCLUDED ITS PARTICIPATION IN THE OPEN HOUSE CHICAGO PROGRAM. WE CREATED A 4-MINUTE VIDEO WHICH DISCUSSED ROSELAND'S PAST, PRESENT AND FUTURE. WE SPONSORED A ONE-HOUR PANEL DISCUSSION WITH ROSELAND COMMUNITY LEADERS, ATTENDED BY APPROXIMATELY 250 PEOPLE WITH WIDE DISTRIBUTION THROUGH OUR SOCIAL MEDIA. REACHING A WIDE AUDIENCE WHICH IS IMPORTANT TO CHANGE NEGATIVE NEIGHBORHOOD PERCEPTIONS. THE PRIMARY DELIVERABLE FROM OUR CHICAGO 7 PROGRAM IS THE CHICAGO 7 BOOK. IT IS APPROXIMATELY 100 PAGES IN LENGTH WITH BEAUTIFUL PHOTOGRAPHY AND ORIGINAL RESEARCH AND WRITING. THE BOOK INCLUDES A LIBRARY OF CONGRESS NUMBER. THE CREATION, PRINTING AND DISTRIBUTION OF THE BOOK IS ESSENTIAL TO ALLOW DECISION MAKERS TO APPRECIATE THE VALUE OF ENDANGERED HISTORIC RESOURCES AND PROVIDES SPECIFIC STRATEGIES FOR HOW TO SAVE THEM.DURING OUR EXTENSIVE RESEARCH AND WRITING OF THE CHICAGO 7 MOST ENDANGERED BOOK, WE WRESTLED WITH ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT STRATEGIES TO ALLOW ROSELAND TO BENEFIT FROM THE HERITAGE TOURISM THAT THE PULLMAN NATIONAL MONUMENT WILL GENERATE. AFTER A LENGTHY EFFORT, WE IDENTIFIED A ""HERITAGE BRIDGE"" STRATEGY TO POWERFULLY DRAW PULLMAN HERITAGE TOURIST (AND THEIR HERITAGE TOURISM DOLLARS) TO ROSELAND'S MICHIGAN AVE. THERE ARE MANY BEAUTIFUL AND SIGNIFICANT PARK, SCHOOL, AND CHURCH BUILDINGS IN ROSELAND CLUSTERED AROUND PALMER PARK BY CHICAGO'S MOST CELEBRATED ARCHITECTS WITH STRONG AND DIRECT PULLMAN CONNECTION. THANKS TO OUR EFFORTS, THE CITY OF CHICAGO IS PLANNING TO PREPARE A LANDMARK DISTRICT RECOMMENDATION.

mission: ANGEL COVERS (AC) IS A VOLUNTEER RUN ORGANIZATION DEDICATED TO CARING FOR ORPHANED AND DESTITUTE CHILDREN AROUND THE WORLD. ANGEL COVERS BELIEVES THAT EVERY CHILD IS INVALUABLE AND DESERVES TO HAVE THEIR BASIC NUTRITION, HOUSING, MEDICAL AND EDUCATIONAL NEEDS MET SO THEY CAN GROW INTO THEIR POTENTIAL. BREAKING THE CYCLE OF POVERTY AND EMPOWERING CHILDREN TO BECOME SELF-SUFFICIENT ADULTS IS OUR GOAL.OUR ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS ARE LESS THAN 6% AND WE HAVE PROVIDED THOUSANDS OFVOLUNTEER HOURS THROUGH THE COMMITTED EFFORTS OF MORE THAN 25 VOLUNTEERS.DIRECTORS IN CHARGE OF MONITORING AND OVERSEEING PROGRAMS WORK MORE THAN 40 HOURS A WEEK TO ENSURE THE BEST POSSIBLE PROGRAMS FOR THE CHILDREN WE SERVE. EVERY DOLLAR DONATED TO ANGEL COVERS IS USED TO PROVIDE PROGRAM SERVICES TO ORPHANS AND CHILDREN.MORE THAN 100 CHILDREN IN CHINA AND KENYA ARE SPONSORED AND RECEIVE EDUCATION, MEALS, SHELTER, AND MEDICAL CARE. ANOTHER 1,500 CHILDREN HAVE RECEIVED ONGOING SUPPORT FROM ANGEL COVERS IN THE FORM OF BLANKETS, MEALS, BASIC MEDICAL CARE, AND SCHOOL SUPPLIES IN OUR 16 YEAR HISTORY. FOR EXAMPLE, THE HUMBLE HEARTS SCHOOL IN NAIROBI, KENYA, WITH MORE THAN 400 CHILDREN, RECEIVED FUNDS FOR TEACHERS SALARIES, TEXTBOOKS, FOOD, CONSTRUCTION NEEDS, AND SCHOOL SUPPLIES.FORM 990-EZ, PART III, LINE 28 - STATEMENT OF PROGRAM SERVICE ACCOMPLISHMENTSTHOUGHOUT 2017, INDIVIDUALS ACROSS THE COUNTRY DONATED TO BENEFIT ORPHAN SCHOOLS. TOYS, BLANKETS, VITAMINS, AND SCHOOL SUPPLIES WERE COLLECTED AND were taken TO KENYA IN November 2017. THANKS TO BLANKET SALES THROUGH OUR WEBSITE AND IN-KIND DONATIONS, AND ADDITIONAL 98 BLANKETS WERE DONATED TO ORPHANAGES IN CHINA. ANGEL COVERS WORK WITH ORPHANED AND DESTITUTE CHILDREN IN KENYA IS EXTENSIVE. IN 2017, ANGEL COVERS CONTINUED TO EXTENSIVELY SUPPORT THE HUMBLE HEARTS SCHOOL. THE DEDICATION OF THE TEACHERS IS SEEN EVERY DAY. TEACHERS FREQUENTLY STAY FOR SEVERAL HOURS PAST THE END OF THE SCHOOL DAY IN ORDER TO TUTOR STUDENTS, CREATE LESSON PLANS, OR LEAD AFTER SCHOOL CLUBS. CHILDREN CONTINUE TO RECEIVE A QUALITY EDUCATION AS DEMONSTRATED BY INCREASED TEST SCORES, LOW TEACHER TURNOVER, AND CONSISTENT ATTENDANCE. EXTENSIVE CONSTRUCTION HAS BEEN DONE ON THE SCHOOL. In 2017, BATHROOMS CONTINUED TO BE RENOVATED, AND PERMANENT CONCRETE WALLS INSTALLED TO REPLACE THE PREVIOUS TIN SHEETS. THE LIBRARY WAS RENOVATED WITH NEW CALLS, A PERMANENT CEILING, AND NEW FURNITURE. EREADERS CONTINUE TO BE A VITAL PART OF PROVIDING QUALITY EDUCATION TO THE SECONDARY STUDENTS AT HUMBLE HEARTS, PROVIDING THEM WITH A LIBRARY IN THEIR HANDS OF MORE THAN 200 TEXTBOOKS AND STORY BOOKS. INCREASED TEST SCORES AND A GREATER DESIRE TO READ FOR FUN ARE ONLY SOME OF THE BENEFITS OF THIS PROGRAM. OF THE APPROXIMATELY 400 STUDENTS ATTENDING HUMBLE HEARTS IN 2017, 125 CURRENT LIVE AT HUMBLE HEARTS ALSO, PROVIDING THEM A BOARDING SCHOOL COMPLETE WITH TUTORING AND THREE NUTRITIOUS MEALS A DAY.BECAUSE OF THE BOARDING POSSIBILITIES, THE NUMBER OF DEAF STUDENTS LIVING ATHUMBLE HEARTS/ANGEL COTTAGE CONTINUES TO INCREASE. HUMBLE HEARTS CONTINUES TO HAVE A REPUTATION THROUGHOUT KENYA AS ONE OF THE TOP SCHOOLS FOR THE DEAF, AND FAMILIES ARRIVE WEEKLY FROM HOURS AWAY HOPING TO ENROLL THEIR CHILDREN. NOW, DEAF CHILDREN WHO WOULD NOT OTHERWISE RECEIVE AN EDUCATION ARE ATTENDING SCHOOL, HAVE GUARANTEED MEALS EACH DAY, AND ARE LEARNING THEY HAVE UNLIMITED POTENTIAL. WORK CONTINUES AT HUMBLE HEARTS TO DEVELOP ON-GOING INCOME GENERATING PROJECTS.IN 2017, LAND WAS LEASED TO GROW CORN AND BEANS, WHICH PRODUCED FOOD FOR THE CHILDREN OF HUMBLE HEARTS. IN CHINA AT THE HUAIBEI SWI, MORE THAN 40 INFANTS AND TODDLERS RECEIVE VITAMINS SUPPLIMENTS AND FORMULA EACH WEEK TO PROVIDE AN ADDED BOOST OF NUTRITION THEY MIGHT NOT OTHERWISE RECEIVE. IN THE AUTONOMOUS TIBETAN PREFECTURES, ANGEL COVERS IS INVOLVED WITH SEVERALORPHANAGES AND POOR RURAL SCHOOLS. MORE THAN FITY HIGH SCHOOL AND COLLEGE AGE GIRLS ATTENDED SCHOOL IN 2017 THANKS TO KANGDING AND MACHIK PROGRAMS AND THE GENEROSITY OF SPONSORS. BECAUSE OF THESE PROGRAMS, GIRLS HAVE A CHANCE TO BREAK THE CYCLE OF POVERTY, AVOID ARRANGED MARRIAGES, AND DEVELOP SKILLS FORINDEPENDENT LIVING. YAKS WERE PURCHASED AGAIN IN 2017 AND CONTINUE TO PROVIDE MILK AND BUTTER ON A WEEKLY BASIS TO MANY OF THE GIRLS THIS PROGRAM PROGRAM, AS WELL AS NUMEROUS OTHER RURAL SCHOOLS. YAKS PURCHASED IN YEARS PAST CONTINUE TO THRIVE AND PROVIDE A STRONG NUTRITIONAL BASE FOR HUNDREDS OF STUDENTS.A SMALL GRASS-ROOTS ORGANIZATION, ANGEL COVERS MADE A POSITIVE IMPACT IN THE LIVES OF MORE THAN 600 CHILDREN IN 2017. CHILDREN AROUND THE WORLD NOW HAVE BEDS TO SLEEP IN, TOYS TO PLAY WITH, MEDICAL CARE, AND MOST OF ALLHOPE FOR FUTUREFORM 990-EZ, PART V - REGARDING TRANSFERS ASSOCIATED WITH PERSONAL BENEFIT CONTRACTS(A) DID THE ORGANIZATION, DURING THE YEAR, RECEIVE ANY FUNDS, DIRECTLY ORINDIRECTLY, TO PAY PREMIUMS ON A PERSONAL BENEFIT CONTRACT? . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . mission: GCLF provides loans and technical assistance to low-income community development projects in rural Georgia. There is a special focus on working with groups of low-income residents of manufactured home communities, to assist them in forming nonprofit organizations and purchasing and operating their own communities. This provides low-income residents with increased security in their homes through cooperative land ownership rather than renting land from investor community owners. Our current largest project is working with Athens based ""People of Hope"". This nonprofit organization of residents is working to construct their own community on land they purchased after over 100 families were evicted from their homes in 2002.

mission: THE SAN FRANCISCO FOUNDATION, THROUGH THE GENEROSITY OF DONORS AND CORPORATE PARTNERS, PAST AND PRESENT, FUNDS APPROXIMATELY 3,300 NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS IN THE SAN FRANCISCO BAY AREA AND THROUGHOUT THE COUNTRY EACH YEAR IN RESPONSE TO EVER-CHANGING DEMOGRAPHICS AND NEEDS OF OUR COMMUNITIES. AS A FUNDER AND CIVIC LEADER, THE FOUNDATION'S CHALLENGE IS TO ENSURE THAT EVERYONE IN THE BAY AREA CAN THRIVE AND REACH THEIR FULL POTENTIAL. THE FOUNDATION WANTS TO ENSURE THAT EVERYONE HAS A GOOD JOB, LIVES IN A SAFE AND AFFORDABLE HOME, HAS A STRONG POLITICAL VOICE, AND CAN LIVE IN A COMMUNITY THAT PROVIDES REAL ACCESS TO OPPORTUNITY. AT THE CENTER OF THIS MISSION IS THE NEED TO ADVANCE GREATER RACIAL AND ECONOMIC INCLUSION THROUGHOUT THE REGION. TO REACH THIS GOAL, THE FOUNDATION FOCUSES ON THREE INTERRELATED PATHWAYS: 1) PEOPLE: EXPANDING ACCESS TO OPPORTUNITY BY REMOVING SYSTEMIC BARRIERS, 2) PLACE: ANCHORING COMMUNITIES OF BELONGING SO THAT ALL RESIDENTS CAN LIVE, WORK, THRIVE, AND CREATE AND 3) POWER: NURTURING EQUITY MOVEMENTS TO ENSURE A STRONG POLITICAL VOICE FOR ALL. THE FOUNDATION SUPPORTS EQUITY-FOCUSED EFFORTS THROUGH GRANTS, CIVIC LEADERSHIP, ADVOCACY AND PROGRAM-RELATED INVESTMENTS.
reason: The summary focuses on civic leadership, economic inclusion, and community support without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: DURING THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2022, WE CONTINUED TO PROVIDE PRIMARY CARE, COUNSELING, AND EYE CARE SERVICES BASED OUT OF OUR CLINIC IN FAIRFIELD, ALABAMA. THE PATIENT POPULATION CONTINUED TO CONSIST LARGELY OF THE ELDERLY, DISABLED, AND/OR UNINSURED. PRIMARY HEALTH CARE, WHICH IS PROVIDED BY OUR TWO BOARD-CERTIFIED MEDICAL DOCTORS, ACCOUNTED FOR ABOUT 2,800 PATIENT ENCOUNTERS IN FY 2021-22. IN THE PRIOR FISCAL YEAR, WE HAD ABOUT 2,700 PRIMARY CARE ENCOUNTERS PLUS ALMOST 600 COVID-19 VACCINATIONS. OUR LICENSED COUNSELOR CONTINUED TO WORK REMOTELY DUE TO COVID-19. SHE PROVIDED INDIVIDUAL COUNSELING SESSIONS ABOUT 1-1/2 DAYS PER WEEK AND A WEEKLY GROUP BIBLE STUDY. WE CONTINUED TO OFFER AFFORDABLE EYE CARE SERVICES ABOUT TWO AFTERNOONS A MONTH USING A THIRD-PARTY PROVIDER WHOSE MISSION IS COMPLEMENTARY WITH OUR MISSION. OTHER SIGNIFICANT ACTIVITIES IN THE FAIRFIELD COMMUNITY INCLUDED DISTRIBUTION OF ABOUT 125 THANKSGIVING BASKETS, OUR NINTH ANNUAL CHRISTMAS SHOP, AND FREE PRE-K STUDENT HEALTH SCREENINGS. MEDICAL MISSION TRIPS TO HAITI AND COTE D'IVOIRE REMAINED SUSPENDED DUE TO COVID-19 AND/OR POLITICAL UNREST IN THOSE COUNTRIES. HOWEVER, WE WERE ABLE TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FOR PROJECTS LED BY OUR MINISTRY PARTNERS IN THOSE LOCATIONS. IN ADDITION, OUR EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR AND A BOARD MEMBER MADE A TRIP TO EXPLORE MEDICAL MINISTRY OPPORTUNITIES AT THE BORDER WITH MEXICO WITH A MINISTRY THAT HAS A COMPLEMENTARY MISSION. FINALLY, WE HAVE REACHED A DEFINITIVE AGREEMENT TO TRANSFER SUBSTANTIALLY ALL OUR NON-FINANCIAL ASSETS TO A LARGER MEDICAL PRACTICE WITH A COMPLEMENTARY MISSION. WE EXPECT THE ASSET TRANSFER TO OCCUR DURING THE FIRST QUARTER OF CALENDAR YEAR 2023, SUBJECT TO BOTH PARTIES MEETING THEIR OBLIGATIONS UNDER THE AGREEMENT. A SEVERAL MONTH PERIOD OF WINDING DOWN FINANCIAL MATTERS WILL FOLLOW. ANY REMAINING FINANCIAL ASSETS ARE EXPECTED TO BE TRANSFERRED TO A DONOR ADVISED FUND TO SUPPORT ON-GOING MINISTRY OPPORTUNITIES.
reason: The summary mentions 'Bible study' and 'ministry partners', indicating a religious context and activities.

mission: AT PHOTOALLIANCE WE CONTINUED TO REBUILD OUR PROGRAMS THIS YEAR WITH CAREFUL CONSIDERATION OF THE CONTINUED COVID PANDEMIC. WE SUCCESSFULLY RELAUNCHED OUR IN-PERSON LECTURE SERIES IN SEPTEMBER 2021, WITH MASK REQUIREMENTS, SAFETY-QUESTION CHECK INS, AND PROOF OF VACCINATION REQUIRED. THE LECTURE SERIES CONTINUED MONTHLY, IN-PERSON, THROUGH MAY 2022, WITH ONE ONLINE LECTURE IN JANUARY WHEN THE COVID19 LEVELS SURGED IN OUR AREA. WE WERE PROUD TO PRESENT EVENTS IN A SAFE MANNER, THOUGH THE EXTRA STAFFING AND REDUCED CAPACITY MEASURES MADE IT MORE COSTLY. ALONG WITH OUR IN-PERSON LECTURES, WE CONTINUED TO PRODUCE AN ONLINE PROGRAM: ""FEATURED PHOTOGRAPHER"" WHICH PROVIDES WEBSITE AND SOCIAL MEDIA COVERAGE TO AN ONGOING, MONTHLY ROTATION OF CONTEMPORARY PHOTOGRAPHERS FROM DIVERSE BACKGROUNDS. WE PRODUCED TWO PHOTOGRAPHY WORKSHOPS, IN AUG 2021 AND JAN 2022, LED BY ARTIST/EDUCATORS LINDA CONNOR AND SARAH CHRISTIANSON. WE ALSO PRODUCED OUR FIRST EVER ECO-ART EARTH DAY EVENT ON APRIL 23, 2022, A ONE DAY, FREE, PUBLIC SYMPOSIUM OF PHOTOGRAPHY ARTISTS AND EDUCATORS PRESENTING WORK ABOUT THE ENVIRONMENT. MOST SIGNIFICANTLY, WE BROUGHT BACK OUR BIGGEST ANNUAL EVENT, THE PORTFOLIO REVIEW, IN MARCH 2022, AFTER A 2 YEAR HIATUS. WE HAD A SUCCESSFUL EVENT SERVING APPROX. 100 ARTISTS AND ARTS PROFESSIONALS, WHICH WAS PRODUCED WITH INCREASED SAFETY MEASURES INCLUDING MASKS, PROOF OF VACCINATION, AND AT REDUCED CAPACITY. EMPLOYEE HEATHER SNIDER CHANGED POSITION TITLE FROM INTERIM TO EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR. THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS REMAINED THE SAME. IN FY 2021-22 WE PRODUCED 9 PUBLIC LECTURES, A FREE ONE-DAY SYMPOSIUM IN CELEBRATION OF EARTH DAY 2022, TWO EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS, AND ONE 4-DAY PORTFOLIO REVIEW.
reason: The summary focuses on arts and educational programs, specifically photography events and workshops, without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: DIRECTORS' INSTITUTE - THE FORUM'S ANNUAL DIRECTORS' INSTITUTE TOOK PLACE IN SAN DIEGO ON JANUARY 28-30, 2020. THE PROGRAM EXPLORED ISSUES DIRECTORS FACE USING A CASE STUDY APPROACH. mission: DUE TO COVID-19, ALL PROGRAMS FOR 2020 WERE SEVERLY CUT BACK. LUCKY RIDERS: THERAPEUTIC RIDING AND ACTIVITIES SERVING CLIENTS WITH PHYSICAL, COGNITIVE, LEARNING DELAYS, SPEECH/HEARING, LOW SELF-ESTEEM, VISION IMPAIRED, AUTISM, CEREBRAL PALSY, BUILDING CONFIDENCE, ANGER MANAGEMENT, ATTENTION DEFICIT DISORDER, ATTENTION DEFICIT HYPERACTIVITY DISORDER, OPPOSITIONAL DEFIANT DISORDER TO NAME A FEW. EQUINE ASSISTED LEARNING: WELL TRAINED STAFF, WITH EXTENSIVE QUALIFICATIONS IN EDUCATION AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT, OUTDOOR RECREATION, AND THERAPEUTIC SERVICES, PROVIDE DIRECT LEARNING EXPERIENCES FOR KINDERGARTENERS TO SENIORS FROM A VARIETY OF DIFFERENT SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC BACKGROUNDS. EACH OF THE EXPERIENCES CONTAINS CLASS SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES, OPPORTUNITIES FOR SELF-ASSESSMENT, TEAM BUILDING, CAREER EXPLORATION, POSITIVE PEER-PRESSURE, AND MUCH MORE. TEAM THUNDER: OUR TEAM OF MINIATURE HORSES VISIT HOSPICE CENTERS, SENIOR CITIZEN LOCATIONS, AND PUBLIC EVENTS BRINGING SMILES AND COMFORT TO ALL THEY MEET. THEY ARE SPECIFICALLY TRAINED TO ENTER BUILDINGS, ELEVATORS, AND AT BEDSIDES. OUR TEAM OF MIN HORSES HAVE PROVIDED HOURS OF MOTIVATION THROUGH THERAPY VISITS. VOLUNTEER PROGRAM: SERENITY FARM VOLUNTEERS TRAIN FOR THEIR SPECIFIC ROLE AT THE NON-PROFIT. FROM BOARD OF TRUSTEES, FUNDRAISING AND DEVELOPMENT, FURTHERING HORSEMANSHIP SKILLS, AND SPECIFIC CLIENT-ORIENTED SKILLS, OUR VOLUNTEERS COMMIT TO LONG-TERM SERVICE AT SERENITY FARM. THEY ARE VITAL TO THE SUCCESS OF THE FARM.

mission: Watershed Restoration Projects: Expenses included design engineering permitting and construction expenses associated with three stream restoration projects in the Conewago Creek Watershed. These were all funded with government grants. In addition expenses were incurred in purchasing 350 tree tubes for forest riparian buffer tree planting throughout the watershed also funded with a grant. Education: Expenses included costs of website domain renewal table top display for the Earth2Etown educational event a postcard mailing to all watershed residents and development and installation of six educational signs along the Conewago Recreational Trail.

mission: THE MISSION OF STEP BY STEP IS TO OFFER A CENTER OF EXCELLENCE FOR INTEGRATED HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES IN THE CARE OF INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES WITH MENTAL HEALTH AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISORDERS TO BE ABLE TO LIVE, WORK AND THRIVE IN THEIR COMMUNITY. FIFTEEN YEARS AGO STEP BY STEP BEGAN PROVIDING SERVICES TO NINE KIDS BY PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL AND BEHAVIOR SUPPORT SERVICES. THE PAST YEAR OVER 500 SERVICES A MONTH HAVE BEEN RENDERED TO HUNDREDS OF CHILDREN AND YOUNG ADULTS WITH MENTAL HEALTH CHALLENGES AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISORDERS, AND THEIR FAMILIES. THE OUTPATIENT CLINIC EMPLOYS A PASSIONATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY TEAM WHO STRIVE TO POSITIVELY IMPACT AND IMPROVE THE LIVES OF THOSE TO WHOM THEY PROVIDE SERVICES.

mission: The Crisis Nursery is a not for profit organization which provides short term care to healthy children up to age 17 whose family or caregiver is experiencing a temporary crisis situation. The facility opened and began providing services on June 12, 2006. The facility provides emergency childcare 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, and 365 days per year. Services were provided under The Center For Youth Services, Inc. during the 2012-2013 fiscal year.

mission: 4th Street Basement Boutique opened in 2002 to provide an outlet to sell excess clothing donated to Dress for Success Cincinnati that was not appropriate for suiting with the goal of providing affordable clothing to lower-income women. 4th Street Basement Boutique has grown into a resale boutique that sells a range of clothing, including high-end items, at thrift store prices which permits it to provide financial support to Dress for Success Cincinnati. 4th Street Basement Boutique's customers include clients of Dress for Success Cincinnati, other lower-income women and other member of the public at large. Its support allows Dress for Success Cincinnati to offer interview clothing and work attire to clients as well as one-on-one career development and job retention programs. Since its formation, it has returned over $500,000 to Dress for Success Cincinnati. In August, 2014, 4th Street Basement Boutique began doing business as Portaluca. Portaluca sells a range of clothing, including new and gently used women's clothing, shoes and accessories at affordable prices. Weekly specials, monthly events, unique designer sales and personable staff and volunteers make Portaluca a wonderful place to shop. Through increased sales, Portaluca was able to transfer $45,000 to Dress for Success Cincinnati to support its programs for women who are entering or re-entering the workforce.
reason: The summary focuses on providing affordable clothing and career support for women, with no mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: CHILDREN'S PROGRAMS:1. KIDS CLUB - A HIGH-ENERGY CHILDREN'S PROGRAM THAT GOES INTO LOCAL NEIGHBORHOODS WITH RESOURCES AND PROGRAMING FOR CHILDREN, AS WELL AS BRINGS CHILDREN TO THE DREAM CENTER FOR WEEKLY BREAKFAST, ACTIVITIES, MUSIC, AND INSPIRING LIFE LESSONS.2. THE WELL KIDS - A SPECIAL SPACE FOR KIDS DURING OUR WEEKLY BREAKFAST THAT OFFERS KIDS A MEAL, AS WELL AS FOCUSED TEACHING, GAMES, AND CRAFTS.(CONTINUED ON SCHEDULE O)3. LIGHTHOUSE EXTREME IS AN AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAM, FACILITATED BY LIGHTHOUSE MINISTRIES, THAT PROVIDES SUPERVISION AND ACTIVITIES TO ELEMENTARY-AGED CHILDREN.4. CIRCLE ""J"" SUMMER CAMPS - A SERIES OF WEEK-LONG SUMMER DAY CAMPS AT A NEARBY PROPERTY, WITH AN OUTDOOR CONSTRUCTED WESTERN-THEMED TOWN. THIS PROVIDES INNER-CITY CHILDREN WITH FIVE DAYS OF FUN, LIFE-BUILDING LESSONS, VIA A WESTERN SHOW AND SMALL GROUP MENTORING, AND ACTIVITIES, PLUS DAILY BREAKFAST, AND LUNCH, AND CONCLUDING WITH A BIG CARNIVAL AND PRIZES. TEEN PROGRAMS:1. RISK CLUB - EVERY TUESDAY EVENING, AN EXPERIENCED TEACHER AND HIS TEAM BRING INCREDIBLE RESOURCES FOR SUCCESS TO THE STUDENTS. THE STUDENTS ARE TAUGHT MANY AREAS OF FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT, HOW TO APPLY FOR A JOB, AND THE PATHS TO FOLLOW TO SUCCEED IN COLLEGE.2. LEVERAGE STUDENT MINISTRIES - A WEEKLY MENTORING PROGRAM FOR TEEN BOYS FOCUSING ON THOSE WHO HAVE BEEN INCARCERATED OR HAVE BEEN PART OF THE PROBATION SYSTEM.3. EXTREME TEAM - A TEEN MENTORING PROGRAM THAT USES LARGE AND SMALL GROUP MEETINGS TO CONNECT WITH AREA TEENS AND INVOLVES THEM IN MENTORING AND LEADERSHIP FOR CHILDREN IN OUR KIDS CLUB PROGRAM.4. THE ROCK BASKETBALL LEAGUE - EACH WEEK, TEEN BOYS ARE PLACED ON TEAMS WITH ADULT MENTORS WHO COACH THEM. THE COACH'S PRIME DIRECTIVE IS TO FOSTER HEALTHY, POSITIVE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN PARTICIPANTS AS THEY BUILD STRUCTURE THROUGH AN ORGANIZED LEAGUE.5. YOUNGLIVES IS A DIVISION OF THE INTERNATIONAL YOUNG LIFE PROGRAM THAT MEETS MONTHLY AT THE DREAM CENTER. THIS IS A TEEN MOM MENTORING PROGRAM THAT ENCOURAGES GIRLS AND YOUNG WOMEN TO BREAK THE STRONGHOLDS IN THEIR LIVES AND CHANGE THEIR FAMILY LEGACY.ADULT & FAMILY PROGRAMS:1. THE WELL - A SUNDAY MORNING BREAKFAST GATHERING FOR PEOPLE OF ALL AGES, WITHIN THE INNER-CITY COMMUNITY, OFFERING HOPE, CARE, AND ENCOURAGEMENT.2. GAME ON! IS A WEEKLY FELLOWSHIP GROUP, FACILITATED BY LUKE 14 EXCHANGES, THAT PLAYS BOARD GAMES AND BINGO WHILE MINISTERING TO THE SPECIAL NEEDS COMMUNITY.3. VIDA NUEVA IS A SPANISH LANGUAGE BIBLE STUDY THAT MEETS TWICE A WEEK AT THE DREAM CENTER TO BRING THE WORD TO OUR SPANISH-SPEAKING NEIGHBORS.4. BIBLE STUDY IS OFFERED ON THURSDAY EVENINGS, BY OUR MINISTRY PARTNERS AT CORRIDOR CHURCH, IN GENDER-SPECIFIC CLASSES.5. MONEY MANAGEMENT CLASSES ARE HELD THROUGHOUT THE YEAR, INCLUDING AN EVERY-OTHER-SEMESTER DAVE RAMSEY PROGRAM, TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL LITERACY TO THE ADULTS IN OUR COMMUNITY.6. PREGNANCY CARE CENTER - PARTNERING WITH ""OPTIONS FOR WOMEN,"" THIS FREE, WEEKLY PREGNANCY AND TESTING CLINIC IS OFFERED AT THE DREAM CENTER. THIS PROGRAM IS FACILITATED BY PROFESSIONAL, TRAINED NURSES WHO PROVIDE CARE AND COUNSELING TO THE WOMEN IN NEED.7. ADULT LIFE CLASSES - THESE MONDAY AND WEDNESDAY CLASSES ADDRESS TOPICS SUCH AS PERSONAL FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT, COMPUTER SKILLS, PERSONAL INTEGRITY, ANGER MANAGEMENT, PARENTING, AND MORE.8. FOOD & HOUSEHOLD GOODS DISTRIBUTION - SEVERAL TIMES A WEEK, WE OFFER DISTRIBUTION OF FOOD ITEMS, CLOTHING, AND HOUSEHOLD GOODS.9. mission: INDEPENDENT RESEARCH FAUNALYTICS COMPLETED EIGHT ORIGINAL STUDIES AND ANALYSES ON TOPICS INCLUDING THE ANIMAL AGRICULTURE INDUSTRY'S PERSPECTIVE ON ADVOCATES & CAGE-FREE REFORMS, REFORMING ANIMAL AGRICULTURE SUBSIDIES, A GUIDE FOR ADVOCATES; BRINGING BACK FORMER VEGANS AND VEGETARIANS, AN OBSTACLE ANALYSIS; SUPPORT FOR FARMED ANIMAL WELFARE LEGISLATION IN TEN KEY U.S. STATES, COMPARING U.S. GROUPS OPENNESS TO PRO-ANIMAL ACTIONS; JURORS REFLECTIONS ON THE SMITHFIELD PIGLET RESCUE TRIAL, UNDERSTANDING INDUSTRY COSTS FOR CHICKEN, EGG, AND FISH PRODUCTS IN THE UNITED STATES, BRAZIL, AND CHINA AND AN UPDATE TO OUR ANIMAL PRODUCT IMPACT SCALES. WE PROVIDED SUPPORT TO 103 ADVOCATES AND ORGANIZATIONS, OFFERING GUIDANCE ON RESEARCH DESIGN, STRATEGY, AND DATA-DRIVEN ADVOCACY. WE HOSTED FAUNA CONNECTIONS, A RESEARCH SYMPOSIUM DESIGNED TO CONNECT ACADEMICS AND ADVOCATES WORKING ON ANIMAL ISSUES, WITH OVER 560 ADVOCATES IN ATTENDANCE. IN 2023, THE FAUNALYTICS RESEARCH ADVICE CENTER REACHED OVER 3,400 ANIMAL PROTECTION ADVOCATES.

mission: DURING 2010, IMH MINISTRIES INTERNATIONAL INC SPONSORED 12 SERVICE PROJECTS IN 7 DIFFERENT COMMUNITIES AROUND THE USA AND SPONSORED 1 PROJECT IN QUITO, ECUADOR. WE HAD TEAM MEMBERS FROM 8 DIFFEENT STATES. OUR DOMESTIC SERVICE PROJECTS LAST A DURATION OF 6 DAYS. OUR INTERNATIONAL SERVICE PROJECTS SERVE A DURATION OF BETWEEN 9 AND 10 DAYS BASED ON TRAVEL AND EXPENSE. WE SERVED FOR THE FIRST TIME THROUGH A HISPANIC CHURCH IN SAN ANTONIO, TEXAS. WE AS WELL SERVED WITH A LOCAL CHURCH IN MISSOURI THAT SERVES A LARGE PHYSICALLY CHALLENGED POPULATION. WE ARE A VOLUNTEER DRIVEN COMMUNITY OUTREACH SEVICE AGENCY. DONATIONS FOR OUR SERVICE PROJECTS COME FROM INDIVIDUALS, BUSINESSES AND CHURCHES. ALL GIFTS AND PROCEEDS GO TO SERVE THE COMMUNITIES THAT ARE DESIGNATED. IN 2010, WE WERE ABLE TO BUILD 3 FOOD AND CLOTHING PANTRIES, ASSIST THE POOR AND UNDERPRIVILEGED IN HOME REPAIRS AND CLEANING AND ENCOURAGEMENT PROGRAMS. WE PARTICIPATED IN PREPARING AND SERVING 2100 PLUS MEALS IN THE COMMUNITIES WE SERVED. SPECIAL ATTENTION WAS PAID TO SINGLE MOTHERS, ONE PARENT FAMILIES, SENIORS AND THOSE IN NEED OF SPECIAL ASSISTANCE. IN EACH COMMUNITY WE SERVE, WE ALWAYS PARTNER WITH EXISTING SOCIAL AGENCIES, CHURCHES AND COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS TO BE SURE OUR EFFORTS ARE REACHING THOSE MOST IN NEED. WE ALAYS CONDUCT ONE PROJECT THAT BENEFITS EVERYONE IN THE COMMUNITY, SUCH AS PARK AND ROADSIDE CLEAN UP EFFORTS. EACH SERVICE TEAM BRINGS FOOD AND CLOTHING TO SUPPORT THE SERVICE AGENCIES ON LOCATION. WE ALSO MAKE A DIRECTED EFFORT TO PURCHASE ALL SERVICE PROJECT SUPPLIES FROM LOCAL COMMUNITY MERCHANTS, THEREBY IMPACTING THE LOCAL ECONOMY IN A POSITIVE WAY. IMH MINISTRIES INTERNATIONAL INC. ACCEPTS SERVICE PROJECTS ON RECOMMENDATIONS FROM LOCAL COMMUNITY LEADERS WITHOUT BIAS TOWARD AGE, RACE, RELIGION, NATIONAL ORIGIN, SEXUAL ORIENTATION OR POLITICAL VIEWPOINT. THIS YEAR, WE OPENED A SATELLITE OFFICE AND WORK WITH AN INDEPENDENT CONTRACT WORKERS TO EXPAND OUR SERVICE OUTREACH.
reason: The summary mentions 'church' and describes service projects that are conducted in partnership with churches, indicating a religious motivation.

mission: In 2013 FCSOA equipped more than 2,000 teacher trainers and teachers of character education throughout North America with schoolsite and conference workshops. The trainers represented many educational organizations including the Association of Middle Level Educators, California School Counselor Association, American School Counselor Association, CharacterPlus, Character Education Partnership, National Service Learning Partnership, Character Counts!, John Lounsbury School of Education, Schools to Watch, and many more schools, districts, and conferences. In 2013, the Elementary Grade Character Education Series was distributed by FCSOA free of charge to more than 300 teachers, counselors and administrators. The effectiveness of this series, used in conjunction with school-wide character education programs, has been exceptionally positive.Also in 2013, FCSOA Collection for Catholic Elementary Youth Faith Formation was completed and distributed free of charge to more than 250 Catholic religious educators focusing on Catholic cathacetics, ethical mindfulness and ecumenical engagement. Student and educator response has been exceptional.FCSOA developed two pilot programs in 2013. The first was developed in coordination with the Episcopal Armed Services and Federal Ministries with a focus on using Hollywood films clips designed to stimulate empathy and engagement in marriage counseling. The second focuses on the use of film clips to introduce key concepts in science and math. The National School to Watch Program, featuring successful school administrators, educators, and students who serve as mentors to low performing schools, partnered with FCSOA in 2013 to provide their mentors with more than 100 FCSOA collections that are currently serving schools in need with effective tools to simulate self-esteem, critical thinking , and empathtic relations with others.

mission: EDUCATION Silk Road Rising continued to provide Chicago communities with innovative storytelling programs. We provided 18 residencies through our EPIC (Empathic Playwriting Intensive Course) program in Chicago schools and community organizations during the 2021 calendar year (9 in the spring and 9 in the fall) and served 434 participants. This year we also relaunched an education program for young learners (grades 2-5) called Myths to Drama. THEATRE Silk Road Rising had been optimistic about our long-awaited return to live theatre, however, we ultimately canceled our live fall production of Christmas Mubarak due to the uncertainties of new COVID-19 variants and the rise in cases. Prior to making this decision, we had already cast the show, began production meetings, and even created a panel of expert scholars.Last year we employed 58 artists and arts professionals, 76% of whom are BIPOC artists with 40% of Silk Road backgrounds (24% White, 19% Black, 17% Asian/Pacific Islander, 16% Middle Eastern/North African, 10% Latinx, 7% South Asian, 5% bi- or multiracial, and 2% Indigenous). COMMUNITY ARTS We are excited to share that we produced a new video project, The COVID Monologues, and continued to reach immigrant and refugee communities in Chicagos West Ridge neighborhood through our EPIC for English Language Learners program. Our goal was to help West Ridge residents reconcile their experiences from the pandemic and to provide innovative storytelling programming that will build greater cohesion. Other Program
reason: The summary focuses on education and arts programs without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: The Children's Nutrition Education & Physical Activity Expo is a year round outreach program providing onsite services at community health fairs and after school programs. C.H.O.I.C.E.S. participated in 29 events reaching 3,045 children and adults. The Let's Move DeKalb Back To School Expo event is held annually to provide nutrition education, health information and school supplies to families. C.H.O.I.C.E.S. provided 1,500 people with 30,000 pounds of food and gave 1,050 children backpacks filled with school supplies. The Cooking with C.H.O.I.C.E.S. is a free 3-week program for underserved families. The program teaches families how to prepare healthy meals on a budget using seasonal foods. C.H.O.I.C.E.S. provided 35 cooking classes which educated 254 participants and 740 secondary family members. The Thanksgiving Turkey Basket and Food Giveaway is held annually to provide food to underserved families for the holiday and school break. C.H.O.I.C.ES. provided 600 people with 10,000 pounds of food which served 1,763 secondary family members. The C.H.O.I.C.E.S. Community Teaching Kitchen is currently under renovation and projected to open in the Spring of 2019. The primary purpose of the kitchen is to be a hub for community health education using cooking classes and educational workshops. The secondary purpose of the kitchen is to be a resource for other health minded non-profit organizations in Metropolitan Atlanta. C.H.O.I.C.E.S. Community Teaching Kitchen is a teaching hub where we host healthy cooking clases and workshops to help fight against chronic diseases related to obesity. Our culinary team, kitchen, along with the attached 3000sq.ft. event space, is also available for private events to teach healthy cooking recipes and methods. Community Outreach events, Camp Divas and Turkey Basket giveaway

mission: In previous years, the Florida Breast Cancer Foundation has held free education conferences based in hotels with an average registration of approximately 100 persons. During 2015-16 the focus on education changed from conferences to one-on-one and small group contacts in communities that are medically underserved and/or have a higher level of late stage diagnosis of breast cancer than the average in the state of Florida. This resulted in the creation and funding of the CARES Project. During 2015-16, more than 8,000 women and men were contacted with many of them referred for breast cancer screenings. Also during 2015-16 the Foundation began discussions on another education program with outreach primarily to the African American communities. That program will begin in January 2017. The Florida Breast Cancer Foundation awards grants for Educaton and Research Programs statewide. The Florida Breast Cancer Foundation is working to better the lives of those facing breast cancer in the Florida community. Education awards grants have previously been awarded in support of innovative projects in the areas of breast health and breast cancer education, outreach, and support targeted services not otherwise available to the medically underserved populations of Florida. Education grants are awarded in support of innovative projects in four priority areas: Educate women in the areas where they need to become proactive advocates for their own breast health through education workshops; Provide education to breast cancer survivors, their families and advocates on life after or with cancer, including the ""transition phase"" from active treatment to survivorship; Provide education on breast health to young women and men with a focus on Middle School, High School and College ages; and Create and provide a method of education, on late stage breast cancer diagnosis, that will help reduce the percentage of these diagnoses , in the areas that exceed the state of Florida average. Scientific Research grants are awarded to institutions in the state of Florida who submit proposals on innovative research projects that have the potential to make a significant impact on breast cancer. The grants must be in one of 5 areas of research: basic, clinical, and translational breast cancer research; epidemiological studies of breast cancer; research on possible links between breast cancer and the environment; psychoimmunological research; and innovative awards and idea grants. In 2015-16, 5 research grants of approximately $200,000 each were approved and funded with a grant project period of July 1, 2016 to June 30, 2018. During 2015-16, an RFA was announced with 21 applications received. The Education Committee rcommended the funding of 11 grants. The recommendation was not considered by the Board until July, 2016. The mission of the Florida Breast Cancer Foundation is to end Breast Cancer through advocacy, education and research. Aside from research and education grants and the Education Conference, the work of the Foundation is accomplished not by holding events, but by working with resources throughout Florida. We attend health fairs and conferences providing breast health, breast cancer, and survivorship information to advocates, families, and those with breast cancer. We provide speakers at events and at educational opportunities. We respond to more than 300 contacts each year from those seeking information and/or direction on where to go, who to see, or what to do. We help make the connections to those local resources who in turn can provide the services or provide the appropriate local resource that can help. In addition for those interested in obtaining more formal education through breast conferences, whether scientific or advocacy, we provide scholarships that can cover part of the cost of attending the conferences.
reason: The summary focuses on healthcare education and support related to breast cancer, with no mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: ORGANIZATION FACILITATED ENROLLMENT IN MEDIATION EDUCATION CLASSES FOR DIVORCE OR DECREE MODIFICATIONS IN THE 6TH JUDICIAL DISTRICT. ABOUT ONE-THIRD DID SO; 15.5 PERCENT OF THE TOTAL TOOK THE CLASSES ON LINE. OF 1,765 DISSOLUTION CASES, PARTIES MEDIATED IN 825 CASES, AND MEDIATOR STATUS REPORTS WERE FILED IN 217 CASES. THE DISTRICT HAS 40 FAMILY MEDIATORS, 32 OF WHOM ARE ATTORNEYS. MSEI ALSO ADMINISTERS THE JOHNSON COUNTY SMALL CLAIMS MEDIATION PROGRAM. VOLUNTEER MEDIATORS REPORTED DATA FROM 30 CASES, WITH AGREEMENTS REACHED IN 10 OF THE CASES. ONE-THIRD OF THE CASES INVOLVED LANDLORD/TENANT ISSUES, 20 PERCENT WERE DEBTOR/CREDITOR CASES, 20 PPERCENT WERE GOODS/SERVICES CASES AND 7 PERCENT WERE PROPERTY CASES. MSEI ALSO OVERSEES THE JOHNSON COUNTY RESTORATIVE JUSTICE CONFERENCING PROGRAM. MEDIATORS BRING JUVENILES REFERRED BY THE COUNTY ATTORNEY TOGETHER WITH PEOPLE AFFECTEED BY THEIR ACTIONS AND GIVE THEM A CHANCE TO DISCUSS WHAT HAPPENED AND POSSIBLY COME TO AN AGREEMENT ABOUT REPAIRING ANY HARM.

mission: Chicago Tap Theatre's largest program service is the production and presentation of tap dance performances. The performances present tap dance artists, choreographers, and musicians. CTT produced live performances in Chicago on Feb. 19, 2022 and June 16-18, 2022. Chicago Tap Theatre brings its performances to Chicago and states throughout the US when contracted by presenters and festival organizers. In 2022, CTT performed at Chicago's Navy Pier, festivals including the Andersonville Midsommarfest, and the Spring to Dance Festival in St. Louis, MO. Chicago Tap Theatre has educational programming that brings tap dance to students of all ages. CTT's intensives are multi-day events and include guest teachers. CTT held intensives in Chicago on June 20-22, 2022 and July 12-15, 2022. Chicago Tap Theatre collaborates with a tap dance organization, M.A.D.D. Rhythms, as well as the wider Chicago tap dance community. Collectively known as the Chicago Tap Allstars, the mission of CTA is to audaciously amplify the excellence of Chicago tap dance by creating an equitable, healing, and inclusive community through education, performances, and advocacy. Events were held May 21-25, 2022.
reason: The summary focuses on tap dance performances and educational programming without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: THE ORGANIZATION PROVIDES A VARIETY OF LONG-TERM NURSING SERVICES AT THREE LOCATIONS IN WISCONSIN. BETHEL CENTER IS A 111 BED NURSING FACILITY LOCATED IN ARPIN, WISCONSIN. THESE FACILITIES PROVIDE SERVICES WITHOUT CHARGE, OR AT AMOUNTS LESS THAN ESTABLISHED RATES, TO PATIENTS WHO MEET THE CRITERIA OF ITS CHARITY CARE OR UNINSURED POLICIES. mission: SUSTAINABLE PACKAGING COALITION:GREENBLUE HAS CONVENED A COALITION OF MAJOR STAKEHOLDERS IN THE PACKAGING INDUSTRY WHOSE MISSION IS TO: 1) ADVOCATE AND COMMUNICATE A POSITIVE, ROBUST ENVIRONMENTAL VISION FOR PACKAGING, AND 2) LEVERAGE INNOVATIVE, FUNCTIONAL PACKAGING MATERIALS AND SYSTEMS THAT SUPPORT ECONOMIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH. THIS ACTIVITY IS EXECUTED IN THE FORMS OF RESEARCH, EDUCATION, COMMUNICATIONS, AND EVENTS. MEMBERSHIP IS COMPRISED OF APPROXIMATELY 550 COMPANIES, ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS, LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, AND GOVERNMENT AGENCIES.RESEARCH: WE CONDUCT IN-HOUSE RESEARCH, COMMISSION EXTERNAL RESEARCH STUDIES, AS WELL AS EVALUATE RESEARCH BY RESPECTED THIRD PARTIES ON A MYRIAD OF TOPICS INCLUDING SUCH EXAMPLES AS: CONSUMER RECYCLING COLLECTION ACCESS, COMPOSTABLE PACKAGING, RESPONSIBLE SOURCING OF FIBER FOR PACKAGING, ETC. THIS RESEARCH BECOMES THE FOUNDATION FOR OUR EDUCATIONAL OFFERINGS, LIVE EVENT SEMINARS, TRAININGS, AND WORKSHOPS, AS WELL AS COMMUNICATIONS CONTENT TO INFORM A LARGE AUDIENCE INTERESTED AND CONCERNED ABOUT PACKAGING SUSTAINABILITY. (HTTPS://SUSTAINABLEPACKAGING.ORG/RESOURCES/)EDUCATION: GREENBLUE'S SPC PRODUCES AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM CALLED THE ESSENTIALS OF SUSTAINABLE PACKAGING (ESP) THAT EXPLORES THE CRITICAL AREAS OF PACKAGING SUSTAINABILITY. TOPICS INCLUDE E-COMMERCE, CHEMICAL RECYCLING, REUSABLE PACKAGING, AND MORE. THE ESP'S ARE UPDATED REGULARLY AND DELIVERED LIVE AS WELL AS ASYNCHRONOUSLY VIA A LEARNING MANAGEMENT SYSTEM TO BROADEN OUR REACH (HTTPS://SUSTAINABLEPACKAGING.ORG/PROJECTS/ESP/)COMMUNICATIONS: THE COMMUNICATIONS TEAM MANAGES ACTIVE EMAIL, SOCIAL MEDIA, AND WEBSITES. (HTTPS://SUSTAINABLEPACKAGING.ORG/)EVENTS: THE SPC PRODUCES MULTIPLE EVENTS ON TOPICS ASSOCIATED WITH PACKAGING SUSTAINABILITY WHERE SEMINARS, TRAININGS, AND WORKSHOPS ARE CONDUCTED TO FURTHER THE EDUCATIONAL MISSION OF THE ORGANIZATION (HTTPS://DASHBOARD.SUSTAINABLEPACKAGING.ORG/EVENTS) HOW2RECYCLE:HOW2RECYCLE IS A STANDARDIZED LABELING SYSTEM THAT CLEARLY COMMUNICATES RECYCLING INSTRUCTIONS TO THE PUBLIC. THE PROGRAM HAS REVIEWED AND ASSESSED APPROXIMATELY 7,000 UNIQUE RECYCLABILITY LABEL REQUESTS, DEVELOPED AN ON-PACKAGE LABEL FOR USE, AND ISSUED THE LABELS TO THE PACKAGE DESIGNERS. AS A PART OF THIS ACTIVITY THE HOW2RECYCLE TEAM HAS ISSUED TENS OF THOUSANDS OF ON PACK LABELS FOR CONSUMER-PACKAGED GOODS TO INFORM THE CONSUMER HOW BEST TO RECYCLE THE PACKAGE. ADDITIONALLY, THE TEAM HAS MADE OVER 30,000 RECOMMENDATIONS TO IMPROVE RECYCLABILITY TO PACKAGE DESIGNERS AS A PART OF THEIR LABEL REQUESTS. THE PROGRAM CONDUCTS EXTENSIVE ONGOING RESEARCH REVIEWS TO INFORM LABEL ASSIGNMENTS AND IS DESIGNED TO FOLLOW THE US FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION AND COMPETITION BUREAU CANADA'S GUIDANCE. (HTTPS://HOW2RECYCLE.INFO/) RECYCLED MATERIALS STANDARD:THE RECYCLED MATERIAL STANDARD (RMS) IS A STANDARD THAT ESTABLISHES REQUIREMENTS NECESSARY TO ASSURE ACCURACY AND TRANSPARENCY OF CLAIMS WITH THE SUPPORT OF A ROBUST THIRD-PARTY CERTIFICATION SYSTEM. THE RMS SERVES IS A VOLUNTARY, MARKET-BASED TOOL TO ADDRESS SOME OF THE CHALLENGES THAT BRANDS, THEIR SUPPLIERS, AND THE RECYCLING INDUSTRY FACE IN TRYING TO INCORPORATE HIGHER AMOUNTS OF RECYCLED CONTENT INTO PACKAGING OR FINISHED PRODUCTS. THE RMS IS INTENDED TO PROVIDE CONTINUITY FOR CONSUMERS AND BRANDS WHILE MEETING THE NEEDS OF THE INDUSTRY AND ENABLING NEW MECHANISMS TO ENCOURAGE THE USE OF RECYCLED CONTENT. (HTTPS://WWW.RMSCERTIFIED.COM/)THE STANDARD: THE RECYCLED MATERIAL STANDARD IS THE CORE OF THE RMS PROGRAM. THE STANDARDS HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED THROUGH A MULTI-STAKEHOLDER CONSENSUS PROCESS, FOCUSING ON CLEAR RULES, DEFINITIONS, AND GUIDELINES TO CREATE AN EVEN PLAYING FIELD AMONG COMPETITORS AND A STRONG ASSURANCE MECHANISM FOR BRANDS AND CONSUMERS. CERTIFIED PARTICIPANTS WILL PLAY A KEY ROLE IN ADVANCING THE USE OF RECYCLED MATERIALS. AS THE RMS PROGRAM IS IN EARLY STAGES OF DEVELOPMENT, MANY DOCUMENTS ARE PENDING RELEASE. INTERESTED COMPANIES ARE ENCOURAGED TO SIGN UP ON OUR CONTACT FORM AND TO REVISIT THIS SITE FOR UPDATES.(HTTPS://WWW.RMSCERTIFIED.COM/ABOUT/STANDARD/)CERTIFICATION & THE LABEL: THE RECYCLED MATERIAL STANDARD (RMS) PROGRAM IS BASED ON A THREE PARTY SYSTEM (OFTEN REFERRED TO AS THIRD-PARTY CERTIFICATION). THE THREE PARTIES INVOLVED ARE: GREENBLUE DEVELOPED AND MAINTAINS THE RECYCLED MATERIAL STANDARD. THESE ARE THE RULES FOR PARTICIPATION. PARTICIPANT A COMPANY WITHIN THE SUPPLY CHAIN THAT MEETS THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE STANDARD AND GETS CERTIFIED. CERTIFICATION BODY AN ACCREDITED THIRD PARTY CARRYING OUT THE AUDITING FUNCTIONS REQUIRED FOR CERTIFICATION. THE ""CBS"" MAKE SURE PARTICIPANTS ARE FOLLOWING THE RULES IN ORDER TO MAINTAIN THEIR CERTIFIED STATUS. (HTTPS://WWW.RMSCERTIFIED.COM/ABOUT/CERTIFICATION/)ARC CERTIFICATES: THE RMS HAS DEFINED A NEW ENVIRONMENTAL COMMODITY WHICH WE REFER TO AS THE ATTRIBUTES OF RECYCLED CONTENT CERTIFICATES, OR SIMPLY ARCS. THE ARC TRADING SYSTEM HAS BEEN MODELED AFTER OTHER PROGRAMS SUCH AS RENEWABLE ENERGY CERTIFICATES OR CARBON OFFSETS. WITHIN THE RMS, AN ARC IS DEFINED AS A CLAIM ASSOCIATED WITH ONE METRIC TON OF OUTPUT PRODUCED FROM RECYCLED INPUT MATERIALS. THE ARC IS GENERATED AT THE PROCESSOR LEVEL AND EACH ARC IS TRACKED THROUGH AN ONLINE REGISTRY SYSTEM TO ASSURE NO DOUBLE COUNTING. ARCS CAN BE PURCHASED BY ANY ENTITY IN THE VALUE CHAIN BUT MOST LIKELY BRANDS, UNIVERSITIES OR GOVERNMENTS AIMING TO MEET ESTABLISHED COMMITMENTS. THE ARC SYSTEM IS FOCUSED ON PROVIDING A FINANCE MECHANISM TO ADVANCE TECHNOLOGY INVESTMENT IN BOTH MECHANICAL AND CHEMICAL RECYCLING FACILITIES. TO MOVE RECYCLING BEYOND BUSINESS AS USUAL, THE STANDARD INCLUDES A ROBUST SET OF CRITERIA MODELED AFTER ADDITIONALITY TESTS ESTABLISHED FOR CARBON TRADING. COMPANIES PURCHASING ARCS WILL BE ABLE TO DEMONSTRATE THEIR SUPPORT FOR INVESTMENTS IN RECYCLING TECHNOLOGY. CLEANGREDIENTS:CLEANGREDIENTS IS A DATABASE OF CHEMICAL INGREDIENTS USED PRIMARILY TO FORMULATE RESIDENTIAL, INSTITUTIONAL, INDUSTRIAL, AND JANITORIAL CLEANING PRODUCTS THAT HAVE BEEN PRE-APPROVED TO MEET THE U.S. EPA'S SAFER CHOICE STANDARD. CLEANGREDIENTS IS AN INDISPENSABLE PURCHASING RESOURCE FOR FORMULATORS WHO ARE SEEKING SUPPLIERS OF CHEMICAL INGREDIENTS THAT WILL HELP THEM TO OBTAIN THE SAFER CHOICE LABEL. USING CLEANGREDIENTS HELPS FORMULATORS REDUCE RISK TO THEIR BUSINESS, SAVE MONEY, AND GET THEIR PRODUCTS TO MARKET FASTER.
reason: The summary focuses on environmental sustainability and packaging industry initiatives without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: SAFE GENERATIONS- SG (RESTORATIVE SERVICES): SAFE GENERATIONS RESTORATIVE STAFF ENGAGES IN NUMEROUS WAYS TO INTERVENE IN FAMILY CRISES FOR THE PURPOSE OF RESTORING HOPE, SKILLS AND RELATIONSHIPS IN HURTING FAMILIES. THROUGH COUNSELING, THERAPY AND UNIQUE PARTNERSHIPS WITH FAMILIES THE CG STAFF SERVED APPROXIMATELY 60 FAMILIES IN FAIRLY INTENSIVE MANNERS DURING 2015. RS SERVICES ARE OFFERED ON A ""SUGGESTED DONATION"" BASIS, OR AT AN HOURLY RATE THROUGH VARIOUS COUNTIES OR THROUGH CONTRACT COVERAGE WITH BLUE CROSS BLUE SHIELD OF MINNESOTA AND PREFERRED ONE.SG STAFF ALSO OFFER TRAINING FOR CHILD WELFARE PROFESSIONALS ACROSS NORTH AMERICA. THE TRAINING FOCUSES ON A RIGOROUS, BUT GRACE-FILLED METHOD OF WORKING WITH FAMILIES IN CRISIS CALLED ""SIGNS OF SAFETY"" MODEL. THE TEAM ESTABLISHED ONGOING TRAINING/CONSULTING RELATIONSHIPS WITH FIVE COUNTIES.DURING 2015, THE SG RESTORATIVE STAFF COMPLETED 244 TRAINING DAYS FOR OVER 4300 CHILDREN'S WELFARE PROFESSIONALS ACROSS THE US AND CANADA, IMPACTING AN ESTIMATED 215,000 FAMILIES, REPRESENTING OVER 537,500 CHILDREN. CONNECTED FAMILIES- CF: (COMBINED WITH RESTORATIVE AMOUNTS) THE GOAL OF DEVELOPMENT SERVICES IS TO BE PROACTIVE IN EQUIPPING FAMILIES WITH TOOLS NEEDED TO STAY STRONG AND GROW STRONGER. THE PRIMARY ACTIVITIES RELATED TO CF WAS THE MOBILIZATION OF MINISTRY STAFF TO PREACH IN THE FAITH COMMUNITY, TEACH IN THE GENERAL COMMUNITY AND TRAIN SMALL GROUP LEADERS TO USE THE CONNECTED FAMILY CURRICULUM.THE MINISTRY STAFF ALSO PRESENTED 130 PUBLIC BIBLICALLY BASED PRESENTATIONS THROUGHOUT THE YEAR IN FAITH, COMMUNITY, AND GENERAL COMMUNITY SETTINGS. THESE PRESENTATIONS WERE ATTENDED BY APPROXIMATELY 5000 PARENTS, REPRESENTING APPROXIMATELY 8000 CHILDREN.CF HAS ALSO DEVELOPED AN ONLINE SOCIAL MEDIA PRESENCE THAT WAS A RESOURCE FOR 20,000 FOLLOWERS, GENERATING OVER 700,000 WEBSITE USERS. THIS PRESENCE INCLUDES NUMEROUS FREE RESOURCES INCLUDING DAILY ENCOURAGEMENTS, TOPICAL TEACHING, AND VIDEO-CASTS.CF STAFF ALSO CONDUCTED COACHING SESSIONS, USING THE BIBLICLY BASED COACHING WORKBOOK FOR 124 CLIENTS ON AN AVERAGE OF 3 SESSIONS EACH OR A TOTAL OF 372 COACHING SESSIONS WITH CF PARENT COACHES.

mission: THE FUND CLOSED FIVE ADDITIONAL TRANSACTIONS, ALL OF WHICH WERE SMALL SITES PROGRAM LOANS TO MISSION ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AGENCY (""MEDA""). THE FUND ALSO FOCUSED ON DIVERSIFYING ITS NETWORK OF BORROWERS, AND HOSTED SEVERAL WORK SESSIONS REGARDING SAN FRANCISCO'S PRESERVATION EFFORTS AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR BORROWERS ACTIVE AND POTENTIALLY ACTIVE IN SMALL SITES PROPERTIES ACQUISITION AND REHABILITATION. THE FUND ALSO APPROVED AN EXTENSION FOR ITS FIRST SMALL SITES PROGRAM LOAN TO MEDA (1411 FLORIDA), EXTENDING THE PREVIOUS MATURITY DATE OF MAY 1, 2018, TO OCTOBER 31, 2018. THE FUND'S LOAN PORTFOLIO TOTALED $36,474,558, AS FOLLOWS: BRIDGE HOUSING: 4840 MISSION $9,000,000 MEDA: 1411 FLORIDA $3,332,000 MEDA: 305 SAN CARLOS $5,730,987 MEDA: 60 28TH STREET $2,941,844 MEDA: 2093 MISSION $8,848,195MEDA: 65 WOODWARD $3,043,720 MEDA: 654 CAPP STREET $3,577,812 THE FUND'S CAPITALIZATION INCLUDED:1. $10,000,000, 0% 20 YEAR SUBORDINATE LOAN FROM THE CITY OF SAN FRANCISCO. 2. $5,000,000, 7 YEAR MEZZANINE LOAN FROM DIGNITY HEALTH. 3. $950,000, 10 YEAR MEZZANINE LOAN FROM THE SAN FRANCISCO FOUNDATION, OF WHICH $250,000 WAS DISBURSED AT CLOSING, (THE REMAINING $700,000 WAS DISBURSED ON APRIL 17TH). 4. $40,000,000, SENIOR SECURED COMMITMENT FROM CITIBANK, AVAILABLE FOR THE FUND TO DRAW ON AS PROJECT LOANS ARE ORIGINATED. 5. $6,200,000, SENIOR SECURED COMMITMENT FROM BENEFICIAL STATE BANK. AS PART OF THIS AGREEMENT, BENEFICIAL SIGNED A JOINDER WITH THE FUND AND CITIBANK (ACTING AS ADMINISTRATIVE AGENT), ALLOWING THE FUND TO DRAW ON CAPITAL AS PROJECT LOANS ARE ORIGINATED. 6. $3,000,000, SENIOR TERM LOAN FROM FIRST REPUBLIC BANK, AVAILABLE TO BE DRAWN DOWN DURING A THREE YEAR PERIOD FROM THE CLOSING DATE (SEPTEMBER 29, 2017). AFTER THE THREE YEAR PERIOD, THE LOAN WILL AMORTIZE OVER A TWO YEAR PERIOD. 7. $6,000,000 SENIOR TERM LOAN FROM AMALGAMATED BANK, (A SUCCESSOR BY MERGER TO NEW RESOURCE BANK), AVAILABLE TO BE DRAWN DURING AN 18-MONTH PERIOD FROM THE CLOSING DATE (MARCH 9, 2018). AFTER THE FUNDS ARE FULLY DRAWN, THE LOAN WILL AMORTIZE OVER A FIVE-YEAR SCHEDULE.DURING THE REPORTING PERIOD, THE FUND ALSO CONTINUED TO DEVELOP A NEW PRIVATELY FUNDED SUPPORTIVE HOUSING MODEL IN PARTNERSHIP WITH TIPPING POINT COMMUNITY, A NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION THAT FIGHTS POVERTY IN THE BAY AREA. THIS EFFORT, FOCUSED ON DELIVERING FASTER AND MORE COST EFFICIENT PRODUCTION OF SUPPORTIVE HOUSING FOR FORMERLY HOMELESS INDIVIDUALS IN SAN FRANCISCO, IS THE FOCUS OF THE FUND'S NEW SUBSIDIARY FORMED DURING THE CURRENT PERIOD, THE HOMES FOR THE HOMELESS FUND LLC, OF WHICH SFHAF HAS FULL OWNERSHIP AND MANAGEMENT RIGHTS.

mission: WORKING IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE COUNTY OF ESSEX, THE ORGANIZATION PROVIDES ADVICE ON THE RESTORATION AND REHABILITATION OF BRANCH BROOK PARK AND ASSISTS THE COMMUNITY FOUNDATION OF NEW JERSEY (CFNJ) IN OVERSEEING CARE OF THE PARK POWERED BY JERSEY CARES.
