mission: State Conference & Workshops: PALS provides the organization and financial support to offer a conference for parents, students, and professionals working with individuals with Autism. One of the major conferences that PALS supports is the Annual Statewide Conference which is a three day event. The number of attendees for this conference in the year 2020 was 950. . In conjunction with the above conference, PALS offer a comprehensive 2-day workshop called ""The Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule (ADOS-2)."" ADOS-2 has become the standard instrument for assessing autism and PDD (Pervasive Developmental Disorder) across age, developmental level, and language skills. For the 2020, 64 psychologists/psychaitrists and therapeutic professionals were certified to administer the ADOS 2. . Summer Camp Program: PALs provides support for Camp Two Can, which is a summer day camp program for children with and without ASD (Autistic Syndrome Disorder)in various Central Florida locations. Camp provides campers with natural environments to help build friendships, learn and use social skills, explore nature, make arts and crafts, participate in swimming/sports/games, and use various functional skills. Small groups of children are supervised by adults who are experienced in working with children with Autism. In 2020, the camp two can was cancelled due to COVID Pandemic. PALS provided 3 unique online virtual summer craft/games and learning about self camps in the month of July. Virtual Camp for 8-12 year olds supported 56 kids from all counties, while Camp introception, a camp for children ages 8-18 (broken into 2 groups) and for those that may require more supoort ran through the month of July, meeting 2-3 times a week hosted 375 participanbts from all counties supported by PALS. PALS also provided a Teen online craft/game camp in week intervals through July with a total of 56 attending. . Social Programs: PALS provides opportunities for interacton of individuals with autism diagnosis in general community settings with support of facilitators. These programs are separated by age appropriateness (ages) are called Aspire (+18), U13 (8-12), Teen Time (13-17) and AEIOU (2-7). Typically, participants select to register for events at low to no cost such as bowling, picnics, bingo, corn mazes, miniature golf, karaoke, dancing, chat seessions, dinners, board game night, and trivia. These events are typically hosted at community vanues with PALS facilitators supporting individuals with autism to be successful in the community. Due to pandemic shutdowns in March, all PALS programs were foreced to move online. Online events consisted of movie days, luch and chats, or dinner and chats, Trivial Kahoot, Pictionary, Jeopardy, Charades, Name that Emoji, Sleuth Games, Bingo, Deserted Island, Scavenger Hunts, and Dance Offs. PALS facilitators still provided social input to assist with social skill growth. Any or all membership/software was purchased to make such programs continue. For 2020, the social programs PAL provided 169 unique events with a total of 984 participants. . Family Events: PAlS provides family events for the entire family to attend. It is an opportunity for tpical siblings to meet others and parents network while individuals with ASD to work on social skills, being in groups, enhance communications skills and work on sensory issues along with behaviors. The COVID pandemic forced us online for such events and provided new challenges. PALS hosted 8 family events in 2020 with a total attendance of 300. The first family event in February was a bowling event with 33 attending. After February events consisted of virtual Bingo with 20 attendees, Scavenger Hunt with 5 attendees, PALS Got Talent Show with 57 attendees, in July a PALS Fair where kids shared their inventions with 18 attenddes, and Virtual Resouirce Fair with 113 attendees. October family event online had 34 attendees and 2020 December Family Holiday online event had 20 attendees. . ASPIRE (Asperger's Syndrome Pursuing Interests, Recreation, and Entertainment) is a 18+ adult social community group typically meets 1- 2 times a week at various community vanues for social interactions hosted by PALS facilitators. Participants have a choice to select which activities they wish to participated in. In 2020, PALS offered 91 unique ASPIRE events with 750 participants. . Teen Time is a group for individuals with autism between the ages of 13-17 to practice social skill enhancement in a safe, welcoming, supportive environment with PALS facilitators as support. Teen time meets typicall during the summer months and or school breaks and provided various activities listed above virtually. In 2020, PALS hosted 35 unique Teen Time events with 279 participants. . U13 is a group of individiduals with autism between the ages of 8-12 to practice social skills enhancement in a safe, welcoming, supportive environment with PALS facilitators as support. In 2020 we moved virtual by March and hosted 32 events with 132 participants. . AEIOU (Autism Early Intervenion Opportunities and You) is for individuals ages 2-7 with a diagnosis of autism to practice social skill enhancement in a safe, welcoming, supportive environment with PALS facilitators that incorporate play and meeting new friends. In 2020, PALS provided11 AEIOU events with 25 participants. . Community Collaboration Programs: PALS collaborates with local community venues offering sports/dance and exercise programs for typical peers by providing autism awareness training, basic behavioral intervention techniques and facilitator support during programs. Programs PALS collabrated with was XL Soccer, Judo, and Martial Arts. PALS collaborated with XL soccer with 42 unique events and 373 participants; Judo collabration hosted 19 events and 138 participants; Marshall arts had 4 unique events with a total of 20 participants. Dance had 101 participants for a total of 32 unique events for 2020. This was the hardest hit of programs for PALS during the pandemic. . Didactic Social Enhancement Programs are programs designed to teach social skills to individuals with ASD. These programs are active in the spring and fall for 16 weeks with 1.5-2 hour weekly sessions with instructors teaching social skill, cognitive emotional regulations, executive functioning skills, life skills, annd basic behavioral strategies, along with bully and self-advocacy. Currently PALS provides to age groups of 8-12 (Eight-12), and 13-18 (TAG) year old group. In 2020, PALS provided 158 unique TAG sessions with a total 1753 participants, and 124 Eight-12 sessions with 891 participants. TAG is hosted in Volusia, Seminole, Orange, Osceola and Lake counties. Eight-12 is hosted in Orange, Seminole, and Volusia counties. . Didactic Program Orientation Workshop is provided in Spring and Fall for parents of children participating in PALS didactic social enhancement programs to overview the program, expectations on parents and children for participation. For 2020, PALS hosted 2 program orientations and had 209 parents participate in Spring and 236 in Fall. . Training and Convention programs In 2020 when the pandemic hit, PALS conducted a virtual Resource Fair for families. The platforms were named Champions and Super Hero, and each contained virtual exhibitor booth,live 3-5 minutes on stage, logo on stage carousel, live chat with attendees, etc. We also conducted Empower PALS to help finance the gifts to activity attendees, as well as in-house staff training to supervise and conduct all the activities.
reason: The summary focuses on programs and activities for individuals with Autism, emphasizing social skills, community interaction, and support without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: Pro bono Legal Services: The Volunteer Lawyer Program of Northeast Indiana, Inc. is a 501(c)3 nonprofit legal aid organization whose mission is to cultivate a culture of pro bono service within the community dedicated to meeting the legal need of low-income families and individuals.In 2023, 137 volunteer attorneys donated 2,022 hours of legal assistance to low income residents. These legal services saved our low income residents in excess of $400,000 in legal charges that attorneys customarily bill for services in their private practices.Please see Schedule O for additional information. Housing Stability Services: VLP attorneys provide eviction assistance in the nine-county region of Northeast Indiana. Advice, representation in rent and damages hearings, and on-site courthouse clinics opening in seven of the nine counties represented gave rural residents access to eviction assistance services. By partnering with social service agencies within the various counties, and attorney staffed legal-aid services, VLP was able to use its resources to make a difference in 2023. Funding was made available to staff a volunteer coordinator for the housing stability program along with a part-time navigator (paralegal referral specialist for housing/eviction assistance). During 2023, over 200 individuals were assisted by this program. Adult Guardianship Services: The VLP established 53 new guardianships for incapacitated people during 2023. Family guardianship days in Allen Superior Court is an efficient and streamlined system that allows for up to ten hearings to take place on a single court day.

mission: TO UTILIZE SWIMMING AS A TOOL TO MOLD YOUNG PEOPLE INTO BECOMING OUTSTANDING CITIZENS. DEKALB AQUATICS SWIM TEAM , INC ""DAQ""IS A COMPETITIVE SWIM TEAM, WHICH RECEIVED IT'S DETERMINATION LETTER RECOGNIZING IT AS TAX-EXEMPT UNDER SECTION 501(C) (3)OF THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE OF 1986, AS AMENDED DATED DECEMBER 18, 2001. DAQ IS BASED IN DECATUR, GEORGIA AND CURRENTLY SERVES APPROXIMATELY 160 YOUTH SWIMMERS. DAQ'S PURPOSE IS TO TRAIN STUDENT ATHLETE THROUGH HIGH SCHOOL TO PARTICIPATE IN LOCAL, STATE, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL SWIMMING COMPETITIONS IN ACCORDANCE WITH GUIDELINES ESTABLISHED BY USA SWIMMING, THE NATIONAL GOVERNING BODY FOR THE SPORT OF SWIMMING. IN ADDITIONS TO THE ABOVE, DAQ'S GOAL IS TO USE SWIMMING AS A TOOL TO MOLD, SUPPORT, AND MENTOR YOUNG PEOPLE INTO BECOMING OUTSTANDING CITIZENS. IN SUPPORT OF THAT GOAL, DAQ OFFERS PROGRAMS TO SUIT EVERY AGE (BEGINNING AT AGE 4) AND SKILL LEVEL SO THAT ANY CHILD INTERESTED IN JOINING THE TEAM CAN DO SO. THE TEAM CONTINUES TO ACCOMPLISH ITS PURPOSE BOTH IN AND OUT OF THE POOL BY TAKING PART IN AND EXCELLING AT LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL COMPETITIONS AND BY REQUIRING AND ASSISTING EVERY TEAM MEMBER TO DEMONSTRATE BEHAVIORAL EXCELLENCE AND ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT. DAQ HAS ALSO CONTINUED TO ENCOURAGE GENDER ( 54% FEMALE) AND RACIAL (39% MINORITY) DIVERSITY. DAQ SERVES 210 SWIMMERS. WE HAD 47 STATE QUALIFIERS 53 LAST YEAR. TOP 12 STATE 14 & UNDER AND SENIOR STATE. NO NATIONAL QUALIFIERS. 3 SENIORS ONE WILL SWIM IN COLLEGE.

mission: THE ORGANIZATION PROVIDES COMPREHENSIVE TOBACCO USE PREVENTION AND CESSATION PROGRAMS IN ALLEGHENY COUNTY, PA. ALLEGHENY COUNTY, PA HAS HISTORICALLY HAD ONE OF THE WORST RATES OF MATERNAL SMOKING IN THE COUNTRY. THE ORGANIZATION'S GOALS ARE TO RAISE AWARENESS OF THIS ISSUE AND PROVIDE PROGRAMS TO ASSIST PEOPLE IN QUITING AND PREVENT NON SMOKERS FROM STARTING TO SMOKE.SUBCONTRACTOR MERCY BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PROVIDED CESSATION SERVICES TO ALLEGHENY COUNTY; IN 2013, THEY SERVED APPROXIMATELY 1,500 PATIENTS IN VARIOUS AREAS, INCLUDING MENTAL HEALTH PATIENTS, THE INCARCERATED, AND LOW SOCIO-ECONOMIC POPULATIONS, THAT WOULD FIND IT DIFFICULT TO FIND CESSATION SERVICES ELSEWHERE. ST. CLAIR HOSPITAL PROVIDED CESSATION SERVICES IN ALLEGHENY COUNTY, WITH A CONCENTRATION ON PREGNANT WOMEN AND MATERNAL HEALTH. THEY WORKED WITH FEDERALLY QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTERS TO ESTABLISH SMOKING CESSATION PROGRAMS AND TO TRAIN FQHC EMPLOYEES IN SMOKING INTERVENTIONS. SUBCONTRACTOR ADDICTION MEDICINE SERVICES WORKED IN BOTH PREVENTION AND EDUCATION. IN 2013, THEY HELPED 19 SCHOOL DISTRICTS THROUGHOUT ALLEGHENY COUNTY STRENGTHEN TOBACCO POLICIES, AS WELL AS OTHER PREVENTION PROJECTS IN THE REMAINING 24 DISTRICTS, SERVING ALLEGHENY COUNTY'S SCHOOL AGE POPULATION, ROUGHLY 200,000 STUDENTS.

mission: Melton Direct and Leadership Curriculum - In Person Network of community-based schools offering adults the opportunity to acquire Jewish literacy in an open, trans-denominational, intellectually stimulating learning environment. In addition the offering of MELTON ONLINE allows students who do not live in an area with a Melton School the opportunity to learn from home with a personal computer or mobile device. This technology allows students to see and hear all participants in virtual classrooms. Study with learners and faculty from across North America and around the world and experience the most successful pluralistic, sequential, and comprehensive adult Jewish learning program ever developed.The Leadership Curriculum Program is focused on practical leadership skill development that includes Jewish texts to frame and inspire the conversation. Utilizing case studies and other leadership exercises, it is designed to give lay leaders a focused time to learn, network and be challenged in the presence of like-minded individuals who can help them reflect on their own leadership obstacles and opportunities. Melton Travel Seminars and Kallah - Adult education programs to provide the most comprehensive and multi-layered touring seminars in the Jewish world. With texts in hand, explore the sites and landscapes of Jewish life in Israel and other locations in order to gain new insight and a deeper understanding of the Jewish past, present and future. They provide an insight into the challenges of building a sovereign Jewish state in our ancient homeland while reflecting and responding to Jewish tradition and history, and allow for discussing, interpreting and absorbing the rich culture of both the people and the land. Meetings - represent the International Directors Conference and New Faculty Orientation Programs. The International Directors Conference is a meeting and Convention For directors of all local sites and staff to share ideas, provide updates and to keep communication open between local sites.The new Faculty Orientation Program was established to allow all new faculty members an opportunity to interact with one another and obtain an understanding of the course curriculum they will teach.
reason: The summary emphasizes Jewish literacy and education, which are rooted in religious tradition and texts, indicating a faith-based motivation.

mission: IN 2020 THERE WAS AN ESTIMATED 3.5 MILLION CUBIC FEET OF SUPPLIES AND MATERIALS THAT WAS COLLECTED FROM THE LOCAL COMMUNITY, DIVERTED FROM THE LANDFILL AND REDISTRIBUTED OUT TO TEACHERS, THEIR STUDENTS AND THE COMMUNITY. THESE SUPPLIES AND MATERIALS MADE THEIR WAY TO OVER 2500 TEACHERS AND 75,000 STUDENTS TO USE FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES. THE MATERIALS DISTRIBUTED WERE DOWN ABOUT 25% COMPARED TO 2019 DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. WE CLOSED BOTH OF OUR LOCATIONS AND HAD TO PUT A PAUSE ON OUR MOBILE PROGRAM. MATERIALS ARE SOLD FOR A NOMINAL COST IN ADDITION TO BEING FREE TO THE TEACHERS WE SERVE. OUR STORE IS OPEN 5 DAYS A WEEK. A TOTAL OF 75 INDIVIDUAL VOLUNTEERS PROVIDED ALMOST 4100 HOURS OF SERVICE TO OUR ORGANIZATION. IN ADDITION, 500 HOURS OF VOLUNTEER SERVICE WAS PROVIDED BY GROUPS. THE EXPENSES FOR OUR SERVICES ARE REFLECTED IN PAYROLL, TRUCK EXPENSES (GAS AND INSURANCE) AND FACILITY EXPENSES. IN 2020, TREASURES 4 TEACHERS CONTINUED TO OPERATE ITS SATELLITE LOCATION IN THE WEST VALLEY ON THE CAMPUS OF THE PENDERGAST SCHOOL DISTRICT. TREASURES 4 TEACHERS IS ALSO AN AFFILIATE OF THE KIDS IN NEED FOUNDATION WHERE WE ARE PROVIDED WITH BRAND NEW SCHOOL SUPPLIES TO GIVE AWAY TO TEACHERS ABSOLUTELY FREE. IN 2020 WE RECEIVED $1,308,325 WORTH OF SUPPLIES FROM THE KIDS IN NEED FOUNDATION. THESE ITEMS INCLUDE SCHOOL AND OFFICE SUPPLIES, CRAFT MATERIALS, CLEANING SUPPLIES, AND BOOKS. THE DONATIONS RECEIVED FROM KIDS IN NEED FOUNDATION WERE ALSO DOWN IN 2020 DUE TO THE PANDEMIC. ALTHOUGH TREASURES 4 TEACHERS WAS SEVERELY IMPACTED BY THE PANDEMIC FINANCIALLY AND WITH OUR PROGRAMMING, WE WERE STILL ABLE TO PROVIDE SERVICES TO THE TEACHERS AND STUDENTS REQUESTING IT. WE PROVIDED ""DRIVE-THRU GIVEAWAYS"", AND WE PARTNERED WITH OTHER NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS SUCH AS, ICAN, LUTHERAN SOCIAL SERVICES, AND UNITED WAY. THROUGH THESE PARTNERSHIPS WE PROVIDED 6480 AT-HOME LEARNING KITS FOR STUDENTS THAT DESPERATELY NEEDED SUPPLIES AND ACTIVITIES TO DO AT HOME.

mission: To meet the individual needs of abused and neglected children. Our goal is to stabilize children by developing custom family plans and teaching foster families and biological parents how to develop coping skills and resources necessary for families to remain safe and healthy in their community. Our program delivery uses a Wraparound approach. Wraparound is a philosophy and a planning process which identifies and works to create a custom fit of support and opportunity for the child and their family system. This is accomplished by being client and family centered, needs driven, strength based and flexible. The Wraparound team supports foster children and families through culturally relevant, individualized, community based plans. The family plan is designed to ensure safety in the community and achievement of the child and family's vision and goals for their future.

mission: BUSINESS LOAN FUND: THE WHITE EARTH INVESTMENT INITIATIVE ENGAGES IN COMMUNITY ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT SERVICES, TARGETING RESIDENTS OF THE WHITE EARTH RESERVATION AND OTHER NATIVE AMERICANS STATEWIDE. FOUR MICROLOANS TOTALING $66,336.64 WERE MADE TO MICROENTERPRISES. THE REMAINING TWO REAL ESTATE LOANS TOTALED $188,862.74. THE WHITE EARTH RESERVATION IS IN NEED OF COMMUNITY ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT SERVICES, INCLUDING NEW BUSINESS INVESTMENT. IT HAS A 14.5 PERCENT UNEMPLOYMENT RATE, MEDIAN FAMILY INCOME OF JUST $45,219 AND A POVERTY RATE OF 22.6 PERCENT. CONSUMER LOAN FUND: 107 CONSUMER LOANS TOTALING $746,932.24 WERE CLOSED IN 2013. ALL RECIPIENTS LIVED WITHIN THE BOUNDARIES OF THE WHITE EARTH RESERVATION OR WERE NATIVE AMERICANS LIVING OFF-RESERVATION. COMMON USES OF FUNDS INCLUDED DEBT CONSOLIDATION, CAR REPAIR OR PURCHASE, CHRISTMAS LOANS, HOME HEATING FUEL PURCHASE, AND BILL PAYMENT. CONSUMERS TYPICALLY FACE BARRIERS TO MAINSTREAM CREDIT AND MAY HAVE TOO MUCH DEBT, HAVE DEBT THAT IS POORLY STRUCTURED OR MAY HAVE PROBLEMS MANAGING THEIR DEBT; FAVORABLE TERMS MAY INCLUDE LOWER-THAN STANDARD DOWN-PAYMENT, HIGHER LOAN-TO-VALUE RATIO, ETC. IN 2013, 405 TAX RETURNS WERE FILED FREE OF CHARGE THROUGH THE TAX PREPARATION PROGRAM. SEVENTY-FOUR HOUSEHOLDS RECEIVED FREE HOUSING COUNSELING AND 54 HOUSEHOLDS ALSO PARTICIPATED IN FREE HOMEBUYER EDUCATION, HELPING TO PREPARE THEM FOR ASSET-BUILDING THROUGH HOMEOWNERSHIP.

mission: THE ENHANCING UNIVERSITY RESEARCH AND ENTREPRENEURIAL CAPACITY (""EURECA"") PROGRAM FOCUSES ON SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL COOPERATION BETWEEN RUSSIAN AND AMERICAN UNIVERSITIES AND IS BEING IMPLEMENTED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE RUSSIAN MINISTRY OF EDUCATION AND SCIENCE. THE GOALS ARE TO: (1) DEVELOP A CULTURE OF INNOVATION AND ENTREPRENEURSHIP IN THE FIELDS OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY AMONG FACULTY, STUDENTS, AND RESEARCHERS; (2) CREATE INFRASTRUCTURE TO SUPPORT THE TRANSFER OF TECHNOLOGIES INTO PRODUCTION; (3) ATTRACT INTEREST FROM BUSINESSES AND UNIVERSITIES IN SPONSORING RESEARCH; (4) INTEGRATE RUSSIAN UNIVERSITIES INTO THE INTERNATIONAL SCIENTIFIC AND EDUCATIONAL SPACE AND SUPPORT THEIR ENTRY INTO THE COMMUNITY OF WORLD-CLASS INSTITUTIONS; (5) STRENGTHEN INNOVATION ECOSYSTEMS AND (CONTINUED ON SCHEDULE O) (CONTINUED) THE ROLE OF UNIVERSITIES IN REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND INNOVATION CLUSTERS; (6) DEVELOP STRONG RELATIONSHIPS WITH VENTURE CAPITAL FIRMS TO RAISE START-UP CAPITAL; AND (7) FORM MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN RESEARCH AND BUSINESS COMMUNITIES IN THE U.S. AND RUSSIA. TARGETED GRANTS TO SUPPORT THE ABOVE PURPOSES. PUBLIC POLICY INITIATIVES: THE YEGOR GAIDAR FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM IN ECONOMICS, NAMED IN HONOR OF THE FIRST MINISTER OF FINANCE OF THE RUSSIAN FEDERATION, SUPPORTS THE LONG-TERM DEVELOPMENT OF RUSSIA'S MARKET ECONOMY BY PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR LEADING RUSSIAN ECONOMISTS TO CONDUCT COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH U.S. ECONOMIC EXPERTS. THE PROGRAM'S GOAL IS ""TO STRENGTHEN HUMAN CAPACITY AT RUSSIAN INSTITUTIONS IN DEVELOPING ENTREPRENEURSHIP, ECONOMIC DIVERSIFICATION, TECHNOLOGICAL INNOVATION, AND GLOBALIZATION."" THE YEGOR GAIDAR SUMMER LEADERSHIP PROGRAM, JOINTLY ADMINISTERED WITH THE YEGOR GAIDAR FOUNDATION, WAS DESIGNED AND IS BEING IMPLEMENTED BY PURDUE UNIVERSITY. THE PROGRAM ENABLES YOUNG RUSSIAN LEADERS (THIRD AND FOURTH YEAR UNIVERSITY STUDENTS) FROM (CONTINUED ON SCHEDULE O) (CONTINUED) VARIOUS REGIONS OF RUSSIA TO ACQUIRE THE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE NECESSARY FOR BUILDING A DYNAMIC MARKET ECONOMY. THE FOCUS IS ON ECONOMICS AND ENTREPRENEURSHIP. WORLD TRADE ORGANIZATION (""WTO"") PROGRAM HAS PROVIDED THE HIGHER MANAGEMENT SCHOOL OF THE RUSSIAN PRESIDENTIAL ACADEMY OF NATIONAL ECONOMY AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION WITH HIGH-LEVEL U.S. EXPERTISE IN WTO ISSUES FOR THEIR TRAINING SESSIONS. ENTREPRENEURIAL MUSEUM PROJECT (JOINT PROGRAM WITH THE POTANIN FOUNDATION) TO CONTINUE WITH OUR JOINT PROGRAM IN MUSEUM ENTREPRENEURSHIP. OUR ROLE IS TO HELP IDENTIFY U.S. EXPERTS WHO CAN PARTICIPATE IN A MAJOR CONFERENCE AND MUSEUM EXHIBITION IN MOSCOW. THIS SMALL PROGRAM REPRESENTS AN IMPORTANT STRATEGIC DIRECTION: TO WORK JOINTLY WITH A MAJOR RUSSIAN FOUNDATION IN THE AREA OF SOCIAL ENTREPRENEURSHIP. TARGETED GRANTS TO SUPPORT THE ABOVE PURPOSES. ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND ENTREPRENEURSHIP INITIATIVES: TARGETED GRANTS UNDER $100,000 TO ORGANIZATIONS TO SUPPORT ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND ENTREPRENEURSHIP. MISSION CRITERIA INCLUDE: (1) MULTIPLIER EFFECT; (2) REPLICABILITY ON A REGIONAL OR NATIONAL SCALE; (3) RESULTING SYSTEMIC OR POLICY CHANGE; AND (4) SUSTAINABILITY. RULE OF LAW INITIATIVES: EFFORTS TO SUPPORT THE MODERNIZATION OF THE RUSSIAN LEGAL EDUCATION SYSTEM SO THAT IT CAN PREPARE LAWYERS TO WORK EFFECTIVELY IN A GLOBAL MARKET ECONOMY. LEGAL EXCHANGE (""LEX"") PROGRAM: TO DEVELOP AND STRENGTHEN HUMAN CAPACITY AT RUSSIAN LEGAL INSTITUTIONS AND LAW FACULTIES THROUGH NEW CURRICULA IN THE AREA OF BUSINESS AND COMMERCIAL LAW, INNOVATIVE TEACHING METHODOLOGY BASED ON COMPETENCIES-BUILDING APPROACH, AND INCREASED COLLABORATION BETWEEN RUSSIAN AND U.S. UNIVERSITIES. THE GOALS ARE: (1) TO INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF RUSSIAN LAW FACULTIES TEACHING COMMERCIAL AND BUSINESS LAW TO FULFILL THE NEW STATE EDUCATIONAL STANDARDS INTRODUCING COMPETENCIES-BUILDING APPROACH; (2) ADOPTION BY RUSSIAN LAW FACULTIES OF EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING METHODOLOGY IN TEACHING COMMERCIAL AND BUSINESS LAW; (3) TO ADVANCE COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS BY RUSSIAN UNIVERSITIES TO IMPROVE TEACHING QUALIFICATIONS OF RUSSIAN LAW FACULTY; (4) THE DISSEMINATION OF BEST PRACTICES THROUGH FOUR UNIVERSITIES SERVING AS HUBS; AND (5) TO STRENGTHEN TIES BETWEEN RUSSIAN AND U.S. LAW SCHOOLS. TARGETED GRANTS TO SUPPORT THE ABOVE PURPOSES.

mission: ACADEMIC PROGRAM THE ACADEMIC PROGRAM PROVIDES A COMPLETE MUSIC EDUCATION OF THE HIGHEST QUALITY TO PREPARE STUDENTS FOR PROFESSIONAL CAREERS AS MUSICIANS, MUSIC EDUCATORS, AND LIFELONG ADVOCATES OF CLASSICAL MUSIC. STUDENTS OF THE ACADEMIC PROGRAM MAY CHOOSE TO RECEIVE MUSICAL INSTRUCTION IN PIANO, JAZZ PIANO, VOICE, VIOLIN, VIOLA, ORGAN, TRUMPET, CELLO, CLASSICAL GUITAR, JAZZ GUITAR, FLUTE, CLARINET, AND HARP. MUSICAL INSTRUCTION INCLUDES PRIVATE LESSONS AND VARIOUS CLASSES, SUCH AS THEORY, EAR TRAINING, COMPOSITION, MASTERCLASSES AND PERFORMANCE CLASSES, AS WELL AS STRING ENSEMBLES AND GUITAR ORCHESTRA. ALL STUDENTS WILL HAVE MANY PERFORMANCE OPPORTUNITIES THROUGHOUT EACH SEMESTER. THE PROGRAM HAS APPROXIMATELY 180 STUDENTS DRAWN FROM THE LOCAL AREA. THE PROGRAM WAS CONDUCTED BY 20 EXPERIENCED MUSIC TEACHERS AND TYPICALLY LASTED FOR 30 LESSONS PLUS OPTIONAL INSTRUCTION DURING THE SUMMER MONTHS. DURING 2019 WE RELOCATED DOWNTOWN CAMPUS TO 342 MEETING STREET WE OPENED AN ADDITIONAL CAMPUS IN MT. PLEASANT AT 2612 LARCH LANE, SUITE 111. WE RELOCATED RUSH HOUR CONCERT SERIES TO THE SANCTUARY OF THE 2ND PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH WHICH ALLOWS A MUCH LARGER SEATING SPACE. WE REFRAMED OUR MARKETING PRESENCE BY REDESIGNING THE LOGO, THE WEBSITE, AND THE EMAIL TO ALLOW MORE ONLINE CAPABILITIES FOR OUR CLIENTS, AS WELL AS TO HAVE A MORE PROFESSIONAL AND COMPETITIVE PRESENCE. WE LAUNCHED THE FIRST ANNUAL SONATINA FESTIVAL WHICH IS AN EVENT OPEN TO PIANISTS OF VARIOUS AGES TO COMPETE FOR CASH PRIZES IN PERFORMANCE AND COMPOSITION CATEGORIES BY DEMONSTRATING THEIR TECHNICAL, ARTISTIC, AND ANALYTICAL SKILLS FOR A PANEL OF JUDGES. WE HELD TWO MASTER CLASSES WITH NATIONALLY RECOGNIZED PEDAGOGUES - IN CELLO AND PIANO. WE HELD SUMMER MUSIC FEST, A ONE WEEK LONG EVENT WITH A FULL-DAY OF IN- DEPTH MUSIC ACTIVITIES, SUCH AS CLASSES, LESSONS, AND CHAMBER MUSIC REHEARSALS THAT CULMINATED IN A FINAL PERFORMANCE OPENED TO THE PUBLIC. SEVERAL OF ACADEMY'S STUDENTS ENJOYED STATE-WIDE AND NATIONAL SUCCESS AS THEY ACHIEVED TOP PRIZES IN SUCH COMPETITIONS AS MUSIC TEACHERS NATIONAL ASSOCIATION, STEINWAY YOUNG ARTIST PIANO COMPETITION, SOUTH CAROLINA GOVERNOR'S SCHOOL FOR ARTS AND HUMANITIES YOUNG ARTIST COMPETITION. 7 STUDENTS AUDITIONED AND WERE ACCEPTED INTO CHARLESTON COUNTY SCHOOL OF THE ARTS. IN ADDITION, OUR STUDENTS WERE SHOWCASED IN THE 2019 PICCOLO SPOLETO FESTIVAL SPECIAL PERFORMANCE. FOUR ACADEMY'S FACULTY SERVED ON THE EXECUTIVE BOARD OF THE CHARLESTON MUSIC TEACHERS ASSOCIATION. NEW FACULTY MEMBER WAS HIRED: RYO HASEGAWA AS PIANO INSTRUCTOR. WE CONTINUED OUR MUSIC DISCOVERY CLASSES THAT ARE DESIGNED AS EARLY CHILDHOOD MUSIC EDUCATION PROGRAM FOR 3 AND 4-YEAR OLD STUDENTS TO INTRODUCE THEM TO THE ART OF MUSIC AND ITS BASIC CONCEPTS THROUGH INTERACTIVE GAMES AND EURHYTHMICS. WE ALSO OPENED A SUZUKI PROGRAM FOR 4- YEAR OLD STRING PLAYERS. WE CONDUCTED ORCHESTRA PROGRAM AT MARY FORD ELEMENTARY SCHOOL (TITLE I) AT NO COST TO THE STUDENTS. THEORY AND COMPOSITION CLASSES ALL STUDENTS ARE ENCOURAGED TO ATTEND ONE OF THESE TWO THEORY CLASSES: THEORY AND EAR TRAINING. THIS CLASS IS A FUN AND INTERACTIVE CLASS SUITABLE FOR BEGINNERS AND INTERMEDIATE LEVEL STUDENTS OF ALL INSTRUMENTS, INCLUDING VOICE. NO PREVIOUS EXPERIENCE IS NECESSARY. COMPOSITION AND SONGWRITING. THIS CLASS IS FOR THE STUDENTS TO LEARN TO UTILIZE THEIR MUSICAL KNOWLEDGE AND INSTRUMENTAL SKILLS TO PRODUCE THEIR OWN COMPOSITIONS. TO ATTEND THIS CLASS, NOTE READING ABILITY AND BASIC THEORY KNOWLEDGE ARE REQUIRED. IN ADDITION, STUDENTS ARE ALSO WELCOME TO UTILIZE THE COMPUTER-BASED THEORY LEARNING PROGRAM, AVAILABLE IN OUR LOBBY AT ALL TIMES. STUDENTS MUST FIRST CONTACT THE OFFICE OR THEIR TEACHER TO SET UP AN ACCOUNT, AND THEN PARTICIPATE IN THE SELF-GUIDED PROGRAM. ACCESS TO THE COMPUTER IS ON A FIRST-COME, FIRST-SERVED BASIS. SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM THE ORGANIZATION'S SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM IS DESIGNED FOR STUDENTS WHO ARE SERIOUSLY COMMITTED TO THE MUSICAL TRAINING. THE SCHOLARSHIPS ARE DIVIDED INTO MERIT BASED AND FINANCIAL NEED BASED AWARDS. STUDENTS CAN APPLY FOR THE PROGRAM BY FILLING OUT REQUIRED PAPERWORK, WRITE A PERSONAL STATEMENT AND PROVIDE A LETTER OF RECOMMENDATION FROM A TEACHER. APPLICANTS MUST AUDITION AND/OR PASS INTERVIEW TO BE CONSIDERED FOR AN AWARD. UPON THE RECEIPT OF THE SCHOLARSHIP, STUDENTS SIGN THE CONTRACT COMMITTING TO CERTAIN HOURS OF PRACTICE, REGULAR LESSON AND CONCERT ATTENDANCE, AND VOLUNTEER HOURS. mission: RECYCLING: PROVIDED STABLE, SUCCESSFUL, FULL-SERVICE RECYCLING IN N. CENTRAL WASHINGTON. ENHANCED OUR COLLABORATIVE RELATIONSHIPS, OUR REPUTATION FOR EXCELLENCE WITH RECYCLING BUYERS, AND STRONG PUBLIC SUPPORT. VOLUMES AND VISITOR COUNTS INCREASED 10% OVER PRIOR YEAR. INITIATED PRACTICE OF CHARGING FOR RECYCLING TO IMPROVE PROGRAM SUSTAINABILITY. ESTABLISHED RECYCLING MEMBERSHIP PROGRAM TO PROMOTE PRE-PAY OPTION AND BUILD MORE ENGAGEMENT WITH CONSTINUENTS. DESIGNED AND BEGAN CONSTRUCTION OF A ROOF EXTENSION TO THE DROP-OFF AREA TO INCREASE SAFETY, FUNDED BY A RESTRICTED GIFT. WASTE PREVENTION: CONDUCTED 3 REPAIR CAFES AT WHICH COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS ATTEMPTED TO REPAIR ITEMS CARRIED IN. 5 EVENTS WERE CANCELLED DUE TO THE PANDEMIC. 50 COMMUNITY MEMBERS SERVED, 70 ITEMS FIXED, WITH AN 81% SUCCESS RATE FEATURING MATERIALS REUSE PROGRAM, TAKE IT OR LEAVE IT, DELIVERED REUSE OPPORTUNITY FOR 6,000 RESIDENTS. BUILDING MATERIALS AND HOUSEHOLD ITEMS. INCREASED INVENTORY OF TOOLS VIA OUR TOOL LIBRARY TO OVER 225 TOOLS AVAILABLE FOR ALL RESIDENTS TO SHARE. ALL PROGRAMS ADAPTED TO COVID-19 RESTRICTIONS INCLUDING SANITIZING PRACTICES AND SOCIAL DISTANCING. EDUCATION & OUTREACH: IN-PERSON CONTACT WITH EVERY PERSON ENTERING RECYCLING CAMPUS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION AND ANSWER QUESTIONS ABOUT ALL PROGRAMS. IN-PERSON EDUCATION AND OUTREACH CONVERTED TO ZOOM OR SMALL-GROUP LEARNING PODS AT SCHOOLS. SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASED E-NEWS AND SOCIAL MEDIA PUBLICATION AND ENGAGEMENT AROUND ISSUES, SOLUTIONS, AND INSPIRATION. ADDITIONAL ECO-LEADER COMMUNITY AMBASSADORS TRAINED VIA ZOOM MEETINGS TO AID NEIGHBORS IN RECYCLING CORRECTLY AND PREVENTION OF WASTE. PARTICIPATION IN DEVELOPMENT OF COMMUNITY-WIDE CLIMATE ACTION PLAN TO REPRESENT THE ROLE OF WASTE & CONSUMPTION IN CLIMATE CHANGE. PARTICIPATION IN COUNTY SOLID WASTE ADVISORY COMMITTEE. SPECIAL PROJECTS TO ASSESS FEASIBILITY OF COMMUNITY COMPOST PROGRAM AND IMPROVE SUSTAINABILITY OF RECYCLING PROGRAM.

mission: PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT: THE PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT (PD) DIVISION LEADS NON-CLINICAL, FORMULATION, MANUFACTURING, CHEMISTRY MANUFACTURING AND CONTROLS (CMC), ANALYTICAL, AND MATERIAL PLANNING AND SUPPLY ACTIVITIES FOR IPM'S PRODUCTS. THIS DIVISION IS RESPONSIBLE FOR PRODUCT SUPPLY AND ASSOCIATED ACTIVITIES (INCLUDING PRODUCT MANUFACTURING, PACKAGING, LABELING, DISTRIBUTION, AND STABILITY) AND THE POST-USE TESTING OF DAPIVIRINE RINGS TO SUPPORT ADHERENCE ASSESSMENTS DURING CLINICAL TRIALS. IN 2021, PD'S EFFORTS INCLUDED CONDUCTING CMC ACTIVITIES TO ADDRESS FEEDBACK RECEIVED FROM REGULATORY AGENCIES, INCLUDING THE QUESTIONS RECEIVED FROM THE EMA AS PART OF THE REVIEW PROCESS OF THE MONTHLY DAPIVIRINE RING REGULATORY DOSSIER AND AS A PART OF THE POST-AUTHORIZATION COMMITMENTS TO THE EMA. FOLLOWING THE POSITIVE SCIENTIFIC OPINION FROM THE EMA FOR THE DVR, THE PD TEAM CONTINUED EFFORTS RELATED TO COMMERCIAL MANUFACTURING OF THE DVR. THIS INCLUDED COMPLETING CAPACITY PLANNING WITH CRITICAL VENDORS SUCH AS IPM'S DVR PRODUCT MANUFACTURING PARTNER, IPM'S DAPIVIRINE DRUG SUBSTANCE MANUFACTURING PARTNERS, AND IPM'S SILICONE MANUFACTURING PARTNER. ADDITIONALLY, IPM SUPPORTED THE COMPLETION OF MANUFACTURING SCALE-UP (1X TO 5X) PROCESS VALIDATION. THE 5X PROCESS VALIDATION WAS COMPLETED IN 2022 AND WILL BE USED AS THE DVR MANUFACTURING SCALE GOING FORWARD. FURTHER, THE PD TEAM CONTINUED DEVELOPING THE THREE-MONTH DAPIVIRINE RING AND THE DAPIVIRINE-CONTRACEPTIVE RING. REGULATORY AFFAIRS AND QUALITY ASSURANCE: IPM'S REGULATORY AFFAIRS TEAM OVERSEES THE MONTHLY DAPIVIRINE RING REGULATORY PROCESS, PROVIDING LEADERSHIP IN DOSSIER PREPARATION, FILINGS, AND POST-APPROVAL MAINTENANCE IN EUROPE, THE UNITED STATES, SOUTH AFRICA, AND OTHER TARGET AFRICAN COUNTRIES, WHERE IPM IS PREPARING FOR THE MARKET INTRODUCTION OF THE RING. THIS DIVISION ALSO SUPPORTS ALL REGULATORY EFFORTS FOR OTHER IPM PRODUCTS ON THE PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT PATHWAY; THIS SUPPORT INCLUDES SUBMISSION AND MAINTENANCE OF INVESTIGATIONAL NEW DRUG (IND) DOCUMENTATION AND CONDUCTING REGULATORY AGENCY INTERACTIONS RELATED TO NEW PROTOCOLS FOR UPCOMING CLINICAL TRIALS. IMPORTANTLY, IN 2021, THE REGULATORY AFFAIRS TEAM MANAGED ALL POST-AUTHORIZATION MEASURES RELATED TO THE EMA'S POSITIVE SCIENTIFIC OPINION OF THE MONTHLY DVR. ADDITIONALLY, THE TEAM COMPLETED THE NECESSARY ACTIVITIES TO SECURE WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION (WHO) PREQUALIFICATION (PQ) AND A RECOMMENDATION FROM THE WHO AS AN ADDITIONAL HIV PREVENTION CHOICE FOR WOMEN AS PART OF COMBINATION PREVENTION. THE MONTHLY DVR IS NOW UNDER REGULATORY REVIEW IN AFRICAN COUNTRIES. THESE EFFORTS WERE THEN LEVERAGED, AND THE DVR DOSSIER WAS SUBMITTED TO NUMEROUS AFRICAN COUNTRIES FOR REVIEW AND APPROVAL. BY THE END OF 2021, THE MONTHLY DVR HAD RECEIVED APPROVAL FROM 5 AFRICAN COUNTRIES. THE MONTHLY DVR REMAINS UNDER REGULATORY REVIEW IN ADDITIONAL AFRICAN COUNTRIES.IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE REGULATORY AFFAIRS TEAM, THE QUALITY ASSURANCE (QA) TEAM ENSURES IPM'S PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT AND CLINICAL STUDIES ARE CONDUCTED IN COMPLIANCE WITH ALL APPLICABLE DRUG AND SAFETY LAWS. AUDITS ARE CONDUCTED DURING CLINICAL TRIALS TO ASSURE PROTOCOL COMPLIANCE AND COMPLIANCE WITH AN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON HARMONIZATION OF TECHNICAL REQUIREMENTS FOR REGISTRATION OF PHARMACEUTICALS FOR HUMAN USE (ICH) GUIDELINES, GOOD CLINICAL PRACTICES (GCP), AND ALL APPLICABLE REGULATIONS. VENDOR AUDITS ARE ALSO CONDUCTED WHERE IPM'S CLINICAL, PRECLINICAL, OR CMC WORK IS CONDUCTED. CLINICAL AND MEDICAL AFFAIRS: IPM'S CLINICAL AFFAIRS DEPARTMENT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR QUALITY CONTROL AND COMPLIANCE, MEDICAL SAFETY, PHARMACOVIGILANCE, MEDICAL AFFAIRS, CLINICAL OPERATIONS, BIOMETRICS, PUBLIC AFFAIRS, COMMUNITY PUBLIC AFFAIRS, AND SOCIO-BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES FOR THE CLINICAL TRIALS CONDUCTED ON IPM'S PRODUCTS. KEY ACTIVITIES IN 2021 INCLUDED:- CONTINUED SUPPORT OF THE MONTHLY DAPIVIRINE VAGINAL RING (DVR) CLINICAL TRIALSIPM WORKED WITH ITS CLINICAL TRIAL PARTNER, THE UNITED STATES (US) NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH (NIH)-FUNDED MICROBICIDE TRIALS NETWORK (MTN) ON THE SUBSEQUENT CLINICAL TRIALS OF THE DVR:O MTN-034 (REACH): A PHASE 2A CROSSOVER TRIAL EVALUATING THE SAFETY OF AND ADHERENCE TO A VAGINAL MATRIX RING CONTAINING DAPIVIRINE AND ORAL EMTRICITABINE/TENOFOVIR DISOPROXIL FUMARATE IN AN ADOLESCENT AND YOUNG ADULT FEMALE POPULATIONO MTN-042 (DELIVER): PHASE 3B, RANDOMIZED, OPEN-LABEL SAFETY TRIAL OF DAPIVIRINE VAGINAL RING (VR) AND ORAL TRUVADA USE IN PREGNANCYO MTN-043 (B-PROTECTED): PHASE 3B, OPEN-LABEL, SAFETY AND DRUG DETECTION STUDY OF DAPIVIRINE VAGINAL RING AND ORAL TRUVADA IN BREASTFEEDING MOTHER-INFANT PAIRSFURTHER, THE CLINICAL AND MEDICAL AFFAIRS TEAM SUPPORTED THE REGULATORY AFFAIRS TEAM IN DEVELOPING AND COMPLETING THE CLINICAL MODULES AND POST-APPROVAL AMENDMENTS OF THE DVR DOSSIERS SUBMITTED TO REGULATORY AUTHORITIES. - CLINICAL TRIAL OF IPM'S THREE-MONTH DAPIVIRINE RING BUILDING ON THE PROMISE OF IPM'S MONTHLY DAPIVIRINE RING, IPM DEVELOPED THE THREE-MONTH DAPIVIRINE RING, DESIGNED TO INCREASE CONVENIENCE AND REDUCE ANNUAL COSTS COMPARED TO THE MONTHLY DAPIVIRINE RING. THE CLINICAL AFFAIRS TEAM WORKED ACROSS DEPARTMENTS AND WITH EXTERNAL PARTNERS TO DEVELOP THE PROTOCOL FOR THE BRIDGING TRIAL AND COMPLETE ALL NECESSARY TRIAL PREPARATIONS. THE BRIDGING TRIAL (IPM 054) WAS INITIATED IN Q3 2022.- CLINICAL TRIALS OF THE DAPIVIRINE-CONTRACEPTIVE VAGINAL RING, A MULTIPURPOSE PREVENTION TECHNOLOGY (MPT)THE THREE-MONTH DAPIVIRINE-CONTRACEPTIVE RING IS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE SLOW AND SIMULTANEOUS RELEASE OF THE ANTIRETROVIRAL (ARV) DRUG DAPIVIRINE TO PREVENT HIV AND THE CONTRACEPTIVE HORMONE LEVONORGESTREL TO PREVENT UNINTENDED PREGNANCY. A SECOND PHASE I CLINICAL TRIAL OF THE REFORMULATED MPT RING (IPM 056/CCTN019B) WAS IN THE PLANNING STAGES THROUGHOUT 2021 AND INITIATED IN MID-2022. THIS TRIAL WILL BE CONDUCTED BY THE EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT (NICHD). PROGRAM SUPPORT & ACCESS: IN 2021, IPM CONTINUED TO BUILD AWARENESS GLOBALLY ABOUT MICROBICIDES AND CREATE A FAVORABLE ENVIRONMENT SUPPORTING MICROBICIDE PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT AND INTRODUCTION. THIS IS ACHIEVED BY INFORMING, EDUCATING, AND BUILDING SUPPORT FOR IPM'S WORK THROUGH COMMUNICATION MATERIALS, ADVOCACY, AND DIRECT STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT. IN CONJUNCTION WITH THESE EFFORTS, IPM ALSO CONTINUED WORK TO ENSURE THAT THE DVR CAN QUICKLY REACH WOMEN IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES WHO FACE THE HIGHEST RISK OF HIV. THIS WORK INCLUDES PARTNERING WITH A GLOBAL NETWORK OF ORGANIZATIONS, INCLUDING GOVERNMENT, PHARMACEUTICAL, HEALTH SERVICES, CIVIL SOCIETY, AND ACADEMIC SECTORS, TO STRATEGICALLY PLAN FOR AFFORDABLE ACCESS TO THE DAPIVIRINE RING.
reason: The summary focuses on product development, regulatory affairs, and clinical trials related to a medical product, with no mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: In 2022, our clinic served over 34,000 patients including inpatients and outpatients. We provided funding for rent, health insurance for the Founder, over $5,300 for capital equipment, and $25,000 to fund the Safe Motherhood Busongora program. Additionally, we provided over $350,000 to purchase the new site and begin building the new clinic. We have supported the education of 149 orphans and other vulnerable children from primary school to university. 11 of those students will graduate in the coming year. Additionally, we completed programs to provide dental training for a clinical officer and reconstructive surgery training for the former chief medical officer. We began a new postgraduate physician training program that will help us retain our physicians. Finally, we are poised to expand to new settings and are negotiating with the former chief medical officer who will return to use his skills in sub-Saharan Africa. We look forward to the opportunity to partner with all groups who share our goals and work to educate more displaced orphans and vulnerable children in Uganda and other countries in Africa.

mission: HEALTH HEALING AND HOPE (HHH) IS A 501 (C)(3) NON PROFIT ORGANIZATION ORIGINALY ESTABLISHED AS A MEDICAL RESEARCH STUDY TO RESTORE HEALTH, HEALING AND HOOE TO THOSE BATTLING WITH LYME DISEASE. WE BELIEVE IN OUR BODIES AMAZING ABILITY TO HEAL AND ARE COMMITTED TO PROVIDING THE PERFECT ENVIRONMENT FOR OUR SPIRIT, SOUL AND BODY TO HEAL, RESTORE AND RENEW. THE CARING CABIN, HAS BEEN UTILIZED FOR FAMILIES TO MAKE FOREVER MEMORIES SPEND QUIET TIME TOGETHER IN A PLACE OF HARMONY AND PEACE. THE CABIN HAS BEEN ESTABLISHED WITH ONE PURPOSE IN MIND. THAT PURPOSE, OUR MISSION, IS TO BRING COMFORT, JOY AND HOPE TO EVERY FAMILY VISITING, ENABLING THEM TO RENEW THEIR SPIRTS MENTALLY AND PHYSICALLY AND PROVIDE ""STRENGTH"" FOR THEIR JOURNEY.

mission: During the period of time during which the Success Foundation, Inc. was raising monies to support its summer study program for low-income ninth-graders with college potential (2002-2008), it met the public support threshold. Since 2008-09, the Success Foundation has not conducted any fundraising activities or raised any monies. In 2009, in the face of the recession the Foundation suspended it summer study program and fundraising efforts. Over the past years since 2009, the Foundation has made modest grants to support educational programs for low-income students. The last such grant was made in 2018.

mission: Community Bikes is a reuse and repair program that also promotes bicycles as an environmentally friendly form of transportation. We teach all interested parties - regardless of age, skill level or financial status, to safely maintain, repair and reuse bikes. Our staff repairs bikes as a low cost community service and refurbishes donated bikes that are then sold at a discount or given to agencies for individuals in need. Zero Waste Action - Sonoma County promotes and advocates for high diversion and Zero Waste practices, policies and programs. We conduct a wide range of volunteer activities via our large network and in collaboration with other nonprofit groups. Examples include writing articles, event tabling, giving presentations and workshops and organizing symposiums, repair fairs, swaps, etc.

mission: EDUCATION AND OUTREACH EVENTS - IN 2012, WINDUSTRY PRODUCED AND STAFFED FOR THE SEVENTH YEAR IN A ROW, THE WIND ENERGY CENTER OF THE ECO EXPERIENCE AT THE MINNESOTA STATE FAIR. WITH THIS EVENT WINDUSTRY PRESENTED WIND ENERGY AS AN ENVIRONMENTAL SOLUTION TO NEARLY 260,000 ECO EXPERIENCE VISITORS OVER THE 12 DAYS OF THE FAIR. THE EXECUTION OF THE EVENT INVOLVES SECURING CORPORATE SPONSORSHIP, RECRUITING, TRAINING, AND SCHEDULING VOLUNTEERS, UPDATING AND CURATING THE EXHIBITS, DESIGNING NEW MATERIALS AND VOLUNTEER T-SHIRTS, SET-UP AND TEAR-DOWN, HAVING A PAID STAFF PERSON ON SITE 13 HOURS A DAY FOR 12 DAYS. THIS YEAR, 72 WIND ENERGY CENTER VOLUNTEERS WORKED OVER 347 HOURS DURING THE COURSE OF THE FAIR. WE COLLECTED OVER 1,000 SIGNED POSTCARDS FROM FAIR-GOERS, DECLARING THEIR GENERAL SUPPORT FOR MORE WIND ENERGY IN MINNESOTA. THESE CARDS ARE DELIVERED TO STATE LAWMAKERS DURING THE 2013 LEGISLATIVE SESSION. IN DECEMBER 2012, WINDUSTRY HELD A WEBINAR TO EXAMINE AND LEARN FROM THE CASHTON GREENS PROJECT, A COMMUNITY WIND PROJECT IN WISCONSIN. THE WEBINAR, ATTENDED BY 74 PEOPLE, EXPLORED THE UNIQUE PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN TWO PRIVATE ENTERPRISES, GUNDERSEN HEALTH SYSTEM AND THE ORGANIC VALLEY FAMILY FARM COOPERATIVE. WE WERE PLEASED AND HONORED TO PARTNER WITH THE WIND POWERING AMERICA TEAM AT THE NATIONAL RENEWABLE ENERGY LABORATORY (NREL) TO PRESENT THIS WEBINAR. LANDOWNER WIND ENERGY ASSOCIATION RESOURCE CENTER - WINDUSTRY PROVIDES DIRECT SERVICES, SUCH AS SITE ASSESSMENTS, WIND RESOURCE ANALYSES, ECONOMIC MODELING, EQUIPMENT ASSESSMENT AND ADVISING BUSINESS SET-UP, TO THOSE SEEKING TO DEVELOP A COMMUNITY WIND PROJECT. IN 2012, WITH SUPPORT FROM THE USDA, WINDUSTRY'S LWEA RESOURCE CENTER CONTINUED TO ASSIST EMERGING RURAL WIND ENERGY ENTERPRISES IN THREE STATES (WISCONSIN, MONTANA AND WEST VIRGINIA) AND TO MOVE THESE LANDOWNER GROUPS FURTHER ALONG TOWARD THE GOAL OF COMMUNITY-OWNED WIND ENERGY. THROUGH THE LWEA, WE ALSO COORDINATED THE REGION NINE SMALL WIND BULK BUY PROGRAM IN MINNESOTA. WIND ENERGY ADVOCACY - WINDUSTRY WORKS ON THE FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL LEVELS TO INFORM AND ADVOCATE FOR POLICIES THAT WILL STIMULATE WIND DEVELOPMENT AND OTHER FORMS OF RENEWABLE ENERGY. ADVOCACY EFFORTS IN 2012 INCLUDED:WINDUSTRY WORKED WITH TWO WIND INDUSTRY GROUPS (AMERICAN WIND ENERGY ASSOCIATION-AWEA AND DISTRIBUTED WIND ENERGY ASSOCIATION-DWEA) ON FEDERAL LEGISLATION TO EXTEND THE FEDERAL PRODUCTION TAX CREDIT (PTC)/INVESTMENT TAX CREDIT (ITC). WINDUSTRY SERVES ON THE COMMUNITY WIND COMMITTEE OF AWEA, WHICH SUCCESSFULLY SOUGHT AN EXTENSION OF THE SECTION 48 PTC/ITC FOR LAND-BASED WIND POWER. THE ITC EXTENSION FOR LAND-BASED WIND POWER REPRESENTS A CRITICAL PIECE OF PUBLIC POLICY NECESSARY TO CONTINUE THE GROWTH OF DISTRIBUTED AND COMMUNITY WIND. ALSO, AS AN ACTIVE MEMBER OF DWEA, WINDUSTRY SOUGHT AN EXPANSION OF THE EXISTING ITC FOR COMMUNITY WIND PROJECTS UNDER 20MW WHICH WOULD BE GOOD UNTIL 2016. IN THE END, THE FEDERAL PTC/ITC WAS EXTENDED IN JANUARY 2013 FOR ONE YEAR WITH THE ADDED TIME THAT IF A PROJECT BEGINS CONSTRUCTION IN 2013 IT CAN BE COMPLETED BY DECEMBER 2014.WINDUSTRY PARTICIPATED IN AND WAS INVITED TO SPEAK AND SUBMIT COMMENTS IN A RECENT DISTRIBUTED GENERATION (DG) FACILITATED STAKEHOLDER DIALOG LED BY THE MINNESOTA DIVISION OF ENERGY RESOURCES (DER). SEVERAL IMPORTANT FINDINGS CAME OUT OF THESE DISCUSSIONS THAT WILL SERVE TO MOVE THE DG PROCESS AND MINNESOTA'S NET METERING POLICY FORWARD. THIS WORK WILL HELP TO CREATE THE CULTURE OF SUPPORT AND ENCOURAGEMENT FOR DG IN THE SHORT TERM AND THE GREATLY INCREASED DG DEPLOYMENT IN THE STATES ENERGY SYSTEM OVER THE LONG TERM THAT THE ORIGINAL POLICY NEVER DID. PROGRAM SERVICE- COMMUNITY AND SMALL WIND RESOURCES. THROUGH OUR WEBSITE AND OTHER ELECTRONIC FORMATS, INCLUDING THE TELEPHONE, E-NEWSLETTER, AND SOCIAL MEDIA, WE HAVE DAILY INTERACTION WITH STAKEHOLDERS IN COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE COUNTRY. THE INFORMATION PROVIDED THROUGH THESE FORMATS IS CONSTANTLY MONITORED, UPDATED AND REFRESHED. ONE OF THE MOST UTILIZED TOOLS ON WINDUSTRY'S WEBSITE IS THE COMMUNITY WIND TOOLBOX. THIS UNPARALLELED RESOURCE INCLUDES 16 CHAPTERS OF ABUNDANT, PRACTICAL INFORMATION FOR FARMERS AND RURAL LANDOWNERS LOOKING TO DEVELOP COMMERCIAL-SCALE WIND PROJECTS, WITH SECTIONS DEVOTED TO PROJECT PLANNING, SITTING, PERMITTING, COST, TURBINE SELECTION, PUBLIC POLICY, AND OTHER KEY SUBJECTS. IN 2012, WE ALSO DEVELOPED NEW COMMUNITY AND SMALL WIND RESOURCES AND REBUILT THE INFRASTRUCTURE OF OUR WEBSITE TO BETTER SUPPORT OUR RESOURCES: WE RESEARCHED AND DRAFTED CASE STUDIES OF COMMUNITY WIND PROJECTS NATIONWIDE. THIS WORK INVOLVED CONDUCTING IN-PERSON AND TELEPHONE INTERVIEWS AND ONLINE RESEARCH, DOCUMENTING THE PROJECTS, AND DESIGNING A UNIFORM PRESENTATION FORMAT THAT IS INVITING AND ACCESSIBLE. TEN CASE STUDIES WERE COMPLETED. THESE CASE STUDIES WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE ON BOTH THE AMERICAN WIND ENERGY ASSOCIATION'S AND WINDUSTRY'S WEBSITES. DOCUMENTING THE SUCCESS STORIES OF EXISTING COMMUNITY WIND ENERGY PROJECTS AND MAKING THEM AVAILABLE TO STAKEHOLDERS IS AN IMPORTANT FIRST LEVEL OF TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. WE ALSO LAUNCHED A PROJECT TO DEVELOP OF A SET OF REPLICABLE, STREAMLINED, INNOVATIVE MULTI-OWNER BUSINESS MODELS. THESE MODELS ARE BASED ON REAL-WORLD WIND PROJECTS DESIGNED FOR USE BY MUNICIPALITIES, LANDOWNERS, LOCAL UTILITY COMPANIES, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS AS THEY SEEK TO ESTABLISH COMMUNITY WIND PROJECTS. BECAUSE SUCCESSFUL BUSINESS MODELS CAN ONLY EXIST WITHIN A FRAMEWORK OF SUPPORTIVE PUBLIC POLICY, THIS ONGOING INITIATIVE ALSO PROVIDES GUIDELINES ON CREATING A POLICY ENVIRONMENT FAVORABLE TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF COMMUNITY WIND ENERGY PROJECTS.THE CONTENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (CMS) UPON WHICH THE WINDUSTRY WEBSITE WAS BUILT WAS WOEFULLY OUT OF DATE. IN 2012, WINDUSTRY'S TECHNICAL STAFF ATTENDED TRAINING SESSIONS AND WORKED WITH WEBSITE ENGINEERS TO TRANSFER AND REBUILD THE SITE. WE RECREATED MOST OF THE ADVANCED LOGIC THAT WAS BUILT INTO THE SITE ORIGINALLY AND IMPROVED THE USER EXPERIENCE WITH BETTER NAVIGATION TOOLS. MOST NOTABLY, WE CLEANED UP OUT OF DATE CONTENT AND DEAD LINKS, CAREFULLY ASSESSING 1600 PAGES ON THE SITE AND REFRESHING ABOUT 800 OF THEM IN SOME WAY. THIS NEW, IMPROVED WEBSITE GIVES US A BETTER PLATFORM UPON WHICH TO CONTINUE TO SERVE OUR LARGE ONLINE CONSTITUENCY (APPROXIMATELY 1,000 UNIQUE VISITORS PER DAY).
reason: The summary focuses on environmental education, advocacy for wind energy, and community resources without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: THE FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN GROCERY PROGRAMS GOAL IS TO SUPPLY NUTRITIOUS GROCERIES TO LOW INCOME FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN WHO LIVE IN WESTERN CANADIAN COUNTY. WHEN CHILDREN ARE OUT OF SCHOOL DURING THE SUMMER MONTHS AND OTHER TIMES OF THE YEAR, THESE FAMILIES HAVE TWO MORE MEALS PER CHILD THAT MUST BE PROVIDED ON A DAILY BASIS. THIS CREATES A FINANCIAL DRAIN ON THE FAMILIES DURING THESE SCHOOL BREAKS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO PROVIDE HEALTHY, KID FRIENDLY GROCERIES TO FEED CHILDREN WHO MIGHT OTHERWISE GO HUNGRY. THE GROCERIES AND GROCERY VOUCHERS ARE GIVEN FIVE TO SIX TIMES IN THE SUMMER, AT SPRING BREAK, AND FALL BREAK. A FAMILY MAKES APPLICATION AND APPROVALS ARE BASED PRIMARILY ON INCOME. OVER 12,000 PEOPLE HAVE BENEFITED FROM THIS PROGRAM OVER THE PAST TWO YEARS. SINCE 1999, EL RENO BLESSING BASKETS HAS ORCHESTRATED THE COMMUNITY CHRISTMAS PROGRAM IN WESTERN CANADIAN COUNTY. CHRISTMAS BASKETS OF FOOD, TOYS AND OTHER TANGIBLE ITEMS ARE DISTRIBUTED BY VOLUNTEERS TO THOSE IN NEED AT CHRISTMAS. FOOD, GROCERY VOUCHERS, ESSENTIAL HOUSEHOLD GIFT ITEMS AND A PROVISION FOR THE PARENTS TO PURCHASE THEIR CHILDREN(S) GIFT ARE PROVIDED. FAMILIES MAKE AN APPLICATION AND APPROVALS ARE BASED ON INCOME AND SPECIAL SITUATIONS. PHYSICAL AND PSYCHOLOGICAL NEEDS ARE MET WITH THE CARE AND CONCERN SHOWN BY THE COMMUNITY. IN THE PAST TWO YEARS, OVER 2,500 PEOPLE HAVE RECEIVED CHRISTMAS BASKETS. THIS PROGRAM IS DESIGNED TO SERVE THE NEEDY AT A STRESSFUL TIME OF YEAR AND CURTAIL THE DEPRESSION OF POVERTY, GIVING THEM HOPE DURING THE HOLIDAYS. MANY CIVIC ORGANIZATIONS, BUSINESSES, SCHOOL CLASSES AND INDIVIDUALS VOLUNTEER FOR THE CHRISTMAS BASKET PROGRAM. EL RENO BLESSING BASKETS DISTRIBUTES GROCERIES AND GROCERY VOUCHERS TO FINANCIALLY ELIGIBLE SENIOR CITIZENS ON A MONTHLY BASIS. THESE SENIOR CITIZENS LIVE IN LOW FOOD SECURITY SITUATIONS AND WITH EXPONENTIAL FOOD COST INCREASES, ADDITIONAL GROCERIES ARE NEEDED. FROM MAY 2023 TO JUNE 2024, THE NUMBER OF SENIORS SERVED HAS DOUBLED, APPROXIMATELY 140 SENIORS RECEIVING GROCERIES MONTHLY.
reason: The summary mentions 'El Reno Blessing Baskets' and describes programs that provide hope and support during the holidays, which reflects a faith-based motivation and community compassion typical of religious charities.

mission: COMMUNITY OUTREACH-OUTREACH THROUGHOUT OUR STATE IS CRITICAL TO OUR MISSION. TO REACH PARENTS, NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, LOCAL AND STATE ENTITIES AND RELATED BUSINESS AND CORPORATE REPRESENTATIVES, WE ARE ACTIVE IN THE FOLLOWING AREAS OF OUTREACH: - WORKSHOPS-WE PARTNER WITH PARTNERSHIP FOR DRUG-FREE KIDS TO PROVIDE WORKSHOPS FOR PARENTS WITH CHILDREN WHO STRUGGLE WITH SUBSTANCE USE DISORDER. PHP SPONSORS BY PROVIDING FUNDS FOR THE FACILITATOR AND MATERIALS. THE PARTNERSHIP FOR DRUG-FREE KIDS PROVIDES THE TRAINING FOR FACILITATORS. - EXHIBITOR-WE PARTICIPATE AS EXHIBITORS AT MENTAL HEALTH AND ADDICTION RELATED CONFERENCES, WORKSHOPS, SPECIAL EVENTS AND MORE TO MAKE OTHERS AWARE OF OUR PROGRAMS AND SERVICES. SOME OF THESE INCLUDE: ODAPCA CONFERENCE-OKLAHOMA DRUG AND ALCOHOL PROFESSIONAL COUNSELOR ASSOCIATION. ODMHSAS- PREVENTION AND RECOVERY CONFERENCE-OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF MENTAL HEALTH AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE NATIONAL FEDERATION OF FAMILIES FOR CHILDREN'S MENTAL HEALTH- HOUSTON ODMHSAS: SUICIDE PREVENTION CONFERENCE-OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF MENTAL HEALTH AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE CHILDREN'S BEHAVIORAL HEALTH NETWORK - JOINING FORCES CONFERENCE NAMI WALK-NATIONAL ALLIANCE ON MENTAL ILLNESS - PARTICIPATION-WE PARTICIPATE ON STATE AND LOCAL BOARDS AND ADVISORY BOARDS. WE ALSO PARTICIPATE IN CONFERENCES WHICH ALLOWS US TO NETWORK ON LOCAL, STATE AND NATIONAL LEVELS. FOR EXAMPLE, IN NOVEMBER 2018 WE ATTENDED THE NATIONAL FEDERATION OF FAMILIES FOR CHILDREN'S MENTAL HEALTH CONFERENCE WHICH PROVIDED OPPORTUNITIES TO NETWORK AND SPEAK ABOUT PHP ON A NATIONAL LEVEL. - PRESENTATIONS-WE PROVIDE PRESENTATIONS FOR NON-PROFIT AND OTHER ORGANIZATIONS. THESE INCLUDE PARENT PANELS, SPEAKERS FOR SCHOOL EVENTS, ETC. - COMMUNITY AWARENESS-THROUGH OUR CHAPTERS, WE PROVIDE SPEAKERS FOR OUR PARENT MEETINGS. THESE INCLUDE REPRESENTATIVES FROM THE MENTAL HEALTH FIELD, PERSONS IN RECOVERY, RELATED NON-PROFITS, ETC. - RESOURCES-WE PROVIDE AN ABUNDANCE OF RESOURCES INCLUDING, FREE LENDING LIBRARIES, A PARENT/CAREGIVER RESOURCE PAGE ON OUR WEBSITE, INFORMATION PROVIDED IN OUR QUARTERLY NEWSLETTER AND MORE. - SPECIAL EVENT-WE GENERATE AWARENESS AND EDUCATION THROUGH OUR ANNUAL SPECIAL EVENT WHICH FEATURES SPEAKERS RELATED TO OUR CAUSE. CHAPTER DEVELOPMENT-PHP CONTINUALLY SEEKS OUT AND ENCOURAGES DEVELOPMENT OF NEW CHAPTERS THROUGHOUT THE STATE. TO GIVE STARTUP CHAPTERS THE BEST OPPORTUNITY TO BECOME SUSTAINABLE CHAPTERS WE PROVIDE THE FOLLOWING: - PHP BOARD VOLUNTEERS AND THE EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR OFTEN SPEAK WITH PARENTS WHO ARE INTERESTED IN ESTABLISHING PARENTS HELPING PARENTS CHAPTERS. IF REQUESTED, WE WILL TRAVEL TO THEIR COMMUNITY TO TALK ABOUT THE POSSIBILITIES AND REQUIREMENTS TO ESTABLISH A CHAPTER. TO ENSURE THAT STARTUP CHAPTERS CAN BE SUSTAINABLE AND WILL FOLLOW THE REQUIREMENTS TO BE FORMALLY AFFILIATED WITH PHP: THE PHP BOARD HAS PUBLISHED A CHAPTER MANUAL TO INCLUDE ALL OF THE PERTINENT INFORMATION WITH REGARDS TO ESTABLISHING A CHAPTER. THE PHP BOARD HAS WRITTEN AND APPROVED BYLAWS FOR ESTABLISHED CHAPTERS WHICH MUST BE APPROVED BY THE CHAPTER'S BOARD OF DIRECTORS. THE PHP BOARD HAS WRITTEN AND APPROVED A CHAPTER AGREEMENT WHICH MUST BE SIGNED BY THE CHAPTER PRESIDENT AND RETURNED TO PHP. - WE PROVIDE GUIDANCE AND MATERIALS FOR STARTUP CHAPTERS. OUR BOARD VOLUNTEERS AND THE EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR MAKE OURSELVES AVAILABLE TO HELP WITH FINDING LOCATIONS, SPEAKERS, LOCAL CONTACTS, ETC. AS PREPARATION BEGINS TO ESTABLISH A NEW CHAPTER. WE PROVIDE A FREE LENDING LIBRARY OF BOOKS FOR OUR STARTUP CHAPTERS. WE PROVIDE A CHAPTER PHONE AND BUSINESS CARDS FOR OUR STARTUP CHAPTERS. WE PROVIDE OUR STARTUP CHAPTERS WITH FUNDS TO PURCHASE THEIR FIRST YEAR OF LIABILITY INSURANCE ONCE THEY ARE INCORPORATED. - WE'VE RECENTLY LAUNCHED A VIRTUAL CHAPTER TO ENSURE THAT PARENTS IN OKLAHOMA AND ACROSS THE NATION HAVE AN OPPORTUNITY TO ATTEND A CHAPTER MEETING TWO TIMES EACH MONTH. ADVOCACY- WE ADVOCATE FOR THE NEEDS OF THE PARENTS WHO ATTEND OUR MEETINGS AND ALL PARENTS WHO HAVE CHILDREN OF ANY AGE WHO STRUGGLE WITH SUBSTANCE USE DISORDER. - WE ATTEND AWARENESS GATHERINGS AT THE STATE CAPITOL WHICH ARE RELATED TO OUR CAUSE. - PHP BOARD VOLUNTEERS AND PARENTS TAKE ADVANTAGE OF OPPORTUNITIES TO SPEAK AT HEARINGS, CONFERENCES, ETC. ON LOCAL, STATE AND NATIONAL LEVELS. - PHP BOARD VOLUNTEERS AND PARENTS PARTICIPATE ON LOCAL AND STATE BOARDS, ADVISORY GROUPS, ETC. WHICH RELATE TO OUR MISSION TO ENSURE THAT POLICIES INCLUDE CONSIDERATION FOR PARENTS OF CHILDREN WHO STRUGGLE WITH SUBSTANCE USE DISORDER. ACCOMPLISHMENTS FOR FISCAL 2019 CHAPTERS: WE CURRENTLY HAVE TWO ESTABLISHED PARENTS HELPING PARENTS CHAPTERS. THOSE INCLUDE NORMAN AND EDMOND, OKLAHOMA. - IN 2019, WE LAUNCHED A PHP VIRTUAL CHAPTER AND WE'VE LAUNCHED TWO STARTUP CHAPTERS WHICH INCLUDE OKLAHOMA CITY AND TULSA, OKLAHOMA. - APPROXIMATELY 1,100 PARENTS/CAREGIVERS ATTENDED OUR CHAPTER MEETINGS. - VIRTUAL CHAPTER-IN THREE SHORT MONTHS, MORE THAN 700 ADDITIONAL PARENTS OR OTHER INTERESTED INDIVIDUALS HAVE VIEWED OUR RECORDED VIRTUAL CHAPTER LIVE MEETINGS. - WE PARTICIPATED AS EXHIBITORS AT CONFERENCES, SCHOOL FAIRS AND OTHER EVENTS RELATED TO MENTAL HEALTH AND SUBSTANCE USE DISORDER. WE ESTIMATE THAT WE REACHED APPROXIMATELY 2,000 PARENTS, CAREGIVERS OR OTHER INTERESTED INDIVIDUALS AT THESE EVENTS. WE PROVIDED INFORMATION ABOUT OUR CHAPTER MEETINGS AND OTHER ITEMS RELATED TO OUR CAUSE. - PHP BOARD MEMBERS AND CHAPTER REPRESENTATIVES PROVIDED PRESENTATIONS ABOUT OUR ORGANIZATION TO MORE THAN 500 PARTICIPANTS AT CONFERENCES, SCHOOLS FAIRS AND EDUCATIONAL EVENTS.

mission: CYT provided affordable classes in three 9-week sessions for students ages 6-18, in three locations (Lone Tree, Centennial, Littleton). In the fall of 2013, we expanded this offering to two time slots in our Centennial location to meet demand. Classes include instruction in dance, acting, singing, improv and a variety of other specialty classes. In 2014, CYT proudly provided 16 - 1/2 tuition scholarships to students in need of financial assistance. CYT served a total of 529 students in those three sessions. CYT workshops were offered FREE to prepare students for upcoming auditions, this program continues today, and was introduced initially in the fall of 2013. CYT Denver produced 6 full scale productions during 2014. Of the 529 students enrolled in classes, 352 auditioned to be part of one of the 6-full scale productions. Of those 414 auditioners, 322 were cast. These shows were professionally produced by some of the areas finest theatrical arts teachers, and performed in front of nearly 10,000 patrons. 300 of these tickets were given to under privileged families through ArtReach Denver. Summer Camp at CYT Denver offers campers ages 6-18 the opportunity to participate in a one week day camp to hone their performing arts skills in singing, acting and dancing. The week culminates in a showcase for families where students perform the skills they acquired during the week. Camps also focus on personal development and building character both on and off the stage. In 2014 CYT offered 5 weeks of camp serving 253 students in 4 locations. Bi-Annually CYT Denver takes a group of teen students to the CYT National improvathon competition. For 2014 that event was held in San Diego, California. We were able to take 22 students 1/2 of which were par to our teen leadership program HYPE (High School youth Pursuing Excellence). The other have service on improv teams who competed at the event.
reason: The summary focuses on performing arts education and activities without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: Artemis Institute successfully ran its Summer Remote Studio program with the completion of a Natural Playground designed and built for the Ennis Community Children's School in Ennis, MT Artemis Institute partnered with the Gallatin Valley Land Trust (GVLT), a local Non-profit to design a community park bridge in celebration of the 25th anniversary of the GVLT. The design for the bridge was completed through a weekend design charrette of Remote Studio alumni who volunteered their time to design expertise. The charrette was held in the donated conference room space of JLF Associates in Bozeman, MT. As an opening event for the charette a community cocktail event was held at GVLT to introduce the community to the alumni designers and also gain donations to cover the costs of the charrette itself. Artemis Institute launched the use of its custom container shop for Remote Studio and developed the accommodation aspect of Remote Studio through a fully transportable system of wall tents combined with camping tents for the installation period of the design/build project. Artemis Institute developed a three year community client with The Trust for Public Land as part of the Remote Studio's design/build course. Artemis Institute searched for future housing and shop locations in Bozeman, MT. The Executive Director recruited for Remote Studio in Louisiana, Montana, and Texas. The ED was an invited speaker Eastern Carolina College, the lecture titled The House You Build. The ED also wrote an essay about Remote Studio to be published in an upcoming book published by Routledge Press.

mission: GRSF ENGAGES AND TREASURES A LARGE NUMBER OF PATRONS AND SUSTAINERS WHO DESIRE HIGH-QUALITY SHAKESPEARE AND OTHER THEATER PRODUCTIONS IN THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER REGION. OVER 11,300 PATRONS EXPERIENCED THE PERFORMANCES OF ""TWELFTH NIGHT,"" ""HENRY V,"" AND THE INTERN AND APPRENTICE PRODUCTION OF ""MACBETH."" THERE IS A COMMUNITY-WIDE EFFORT TO PREPARE AUDIENCES FOR THE PLAY PERFORMANCES THROUGH NEWSPAPER, RADIO, TELEVISION, AND SOCIAL MEDIA FEATURES AND ADVERTISING. THE PROCESS OF MOUNTING A PERFORMANCE IS EXPLAINED TO THE PUBIC, WHO ARE ALSO INVITED TO OBSERVE DIRECTORS' AND SET AND COSTUME DESIGNERS' WORK SEVERAL MONTHS BEFORE THE SEASON OPENS AT A WELL-PUBLICIZED EVENT. DURING THE REHEARSAL PERIOD, ACTORS APPEAR AT VARIOUS LARGE GATHERINGS TO PREVIEW THE SHOWS AND COSTUMES. ACTORS, DIRECTORS AND SOME DESIGNERS ARE ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC FOR EXPLANATION OF THE PROCESS OF BRINGING SHAKESPEARE TO THE STAGE. DURING THE SEASON, THE ACTORS ENGAGE WITH AUDIENCES IN ""COMPANY CONVERSATIONS"" AFTER THE SHOW, TAKING QUESTIONS. THEY ALSO ENGAGE WITH YOUNG THEATER-GOERS AT SPECIALLY-PRICED ""CHILL WITH WILL"" PERFORMANCES. SATURDAY AFTERNOONS FEATURE ""NARRATED SET CHANGEOVER,"" WHERE PEOPLE SEE HOW SET CHANGES ARE ACCOMPLISHED AND CAN QUESTION THE GRSF CREWS. ON SUNDAY MORNINGS, COMPANY MEMBERS GATHER TO DISCUSS THE PLAYS AND ANSWER QUESTIONS FROM ATTENDEES AT THE ""ASK THE COMPANY"" EVENTS. FREE ""CONCERTS ON THE GREEN,"" FEATURING REGIONALLY-KNOWN MUSICAL ACTS ARE HELD BEFORE EACH WEEK-END PERFORMANCE, BRINGING SHY COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO THE GREEN IN FRONT OF THE THEATER, WITH THE HOPE OF GETTING THEM TO MAKE THE LEAP FROM THE GREEN INTO A SEAT IN THE THEATER.PREVIEW PERFORMANCES FEATURE ALL SEATS AT $10 EACH, AS DO ALL TUESDAY PERFORMANCES OF THE PLAYS, AT ""$10 TUESDAYS."" EDUCATION IS A LARGE PART OF THE GRSF MISSION. A HIGHLY SOUGHT-AFTER APPRENTICE PROGRAM IS A CHANCE FOR THEATER STUDENTS TO SPEND A SUMMER SEASON WITH A PROFESSIONAL COMPANY, LEARNING ALL ASPECTS OF THE PERFORMANCE. THE ACTING APPRENTICE COMPANY TAKES CLASSES AND WORKSHOPS FROM GRSF COMPANY MEMBERS, RANGING FROM STUDY OF SHAKESPEARE'S FIRST FOLIO TO MOVEMENT TRAINING. THE ACQUIRE TOOLS TO CREATE A SOLID WORKING PROCESS FOR REHEARSAL AND LEARN HOW TO APPLY THAT PROCESS IN A PROFESSIONAL SETTING. GRSF TEXT COACHES LEAD THE MAJORITY OF CLASSES.APPRENTICES ARE GIVEN UNDERSTUDY ASSIGNMENTS IN ONE OF THE THREE PROFESSIONAL COMPANY PRODUCTIONS. BY FOLLOWING ONE MEMBER OF THE PROFESSIONAL COMPANY FROM BEGINNING TO END OF THE REHEARSAL PROCESS, APPRENTICES HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO OBSERVE FIRST HAND HOW AN EXPERIENCED ACTOR HANDLES THE CHALLENGES OF WORKING ON SHAKESPEARE IN A PROFESSIONAL SETTING. APPRENTICES APPLY WHAT THEY HAVE LEARNED AS THEY REHEARSE AND PERFORM THEIR OWN PROJECT UNDER THE DIRECTION OF GRSF ARTISTIC STAFF, WHICH THEY PERFORM TO PAYING AUDIENCES TOWARD THE END OF THE SEASON.""SHAKESPEARE FOR YOUNG ACTORS"" AND ""SHAKESPEARE FOR YOUNG DESIGNERS"" ALLOWS STUDENTS IN GRADES 7 - 12 TO WORK WITH THE PROFESSIONAL COMPANY IN ACTING, SCENERY, COSTUMES AND PROPERTIES. THEIR OWN SHORT PERFORMANCE TOPS OFF THE THREE-WEEK EXPERIENCE.""WILL READS"" FEATURES DISCUSSIONS OF EACH OF THE PLAYS LED BY LOCAL UNIVERSITY OR HIGH SCHOOL EDUCATORS. THE FREE SESSIONS ARE HELD ON WEDNESDAY EVENINGS AND ARE OPEN TO ALL. A ROAD SCHOLAR (FORMERLY ELDERHOSTEL) SESSION IS HELD AT GRSF. THE GRSF COLLEGIUM PROVIDES AN IN-DEPTH STUDY OF THE SEASON'S PLAYS FOR FIFTEEN WEEKS DURING LATE WINTER PRIOR TO THE SEASON, LED BY A UNIVERSITY PROFESSOR OF ENGLISH. A LOW-COST FRONT PORCH SERIES FEATURES A ""SHAKESPEARE SYMPOSIUM"" BRINGING TOGETHER SHAKESPEARE SCHOLARS AND MEMBERS OF THE GRSF COMPANY FOR EXTENDED PUBLIC CONVERSATIONS ABOUT THE SEASON'S PLAYS. ALSO ON THE FRONT PORCH SERIES ROSTER ARE NATIONALLY-KNOWN SHAKESPEARE SCHOLARS, PLAYWRIGHTS, ACTORS, AND DIRECTORS. THE MARIA W. FAUST SONNET CONTEST ENGAGES THE COMMUNITY AS WELL AS POETS FROM ALL OVER THE WORLD IN A POETRY CONTEST IN HONOR OF THE BARD.

mission: Patient Registry: In 2007, the Fibromuscular Dysplasia Society of America (FMDSA) began a data registry with the goal of increasing understanding of FMD. The goals of this registry are to identify patient characteristics associated with FMD, potential markers of the disease, and commonly used imaging and treatment modalities. Michigan Clinical Outcomes Research and Reporting Program is the coordinating center for the registry. The first patient was entered in 2009. Over the last year, enrollment in the registry increased from 2675 patients to 3018 patients at the end of 2020. We currently have 17 registry centers constituting the largest FMD registry. Seattle Childrens Hospital and the University of Colorado joined the registry in 2020. Our goal is to continue enrolling patients and adding additional centers. The registry data helped us to learn more about FMD, how to treat the disease and has driven research hopefully leading to a cure. Patient Support:As we spread awareness, and see a drastic increase in diagnosed patients, patient support becomes a larger part of our responsibility. Due to the demand, we have continued to grow the Volunteer Support Network. These volunteers have been identified in the US and internationally. Many groups have evolved to the point of holding local meetings. We also offer support through social media platforms including Inspire, Instagram and Facebook where we have thousands of patients participating. We are also active on Twitter allowing patients, clinicians and physicians to communicate. We continue to add FMD materials and videos to our website and patient toolbox. We offer FMD materials in Spanish and Japanese and work with our international colleagues who offer materials in several other languages. Finally, we continue to participate in patient meetings throughout the US and internationally, offering guidanace and resources to patients. Public Awareness Program:This program was initiated in July 2005 as a Grass Roots Awareness Program. We help patients educate their family, friends and healthcare providers about FMD with material provided by FMDSA. We have many valuable resources on our website to help communicate FMD in laymens terms, including a Public Service Announcement, as well as more in depth information for physicians that can help bridge the gap and build a better relationship between patient and physician. The Public Awareness Program also includes educational work with media outlets, other organizations, journals, speaking engagements and articles. We also offer live Zoom meetings. There is rarely a day that goes by that we are contacted by a newly diagnosed patient. We have seen the diagnosis rate grow in direct proportion to our programs. See additional info on Schedule O Healthcare Professional Education Program:This program combines attending medical conferences and presenting within hospital environments and is a major focus of FMDSA and has been an avenue to educate thousands of medical professionals. The result is a greater awareness of FMD within the medical community, improved medical expertise for patients, and development of critical partnerships that are helping us spur more research activity. In addition to our Physician page, we have also maintained a research Network Page on the website containing all the information published from the patient registry and other researchers studying FMD. There are also PowerPoint presentations and videos available for health care providers. We have seen a direct correlation between our awareness and educational programs to the increase in patients getting diagnosed. Unfortuntely, in 2020, our 13th annual meeting was postponed due to COVID. See additonal info on Schedule O.
reason: The summary focuses on healthcare, patient support, and education related to Fibromuscular Dysplasia, without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: Homes of Hope made a direct difference to the lives of 172 women and children in Fiji, Solomon Islands, and Malawi in 2015. Indirectly, we positively impacted over 49,000 people through education and community programs. These programs are described below. [1a] Campus-Based Programs: The residential campus is a government-registered campus for single mothers and their children. In 2015, a vocational training program was started for campus residents and ""day scholars"". Day Scholars benefit from the same counselling, training and care programs only they reside off-campus. This ""GO! Girls Training Program"" provides tools to help our clients rebuild their life. As a bridging program, it opens more training options and uncovers additional employment opportunities, together with training to operate various home-based businesses. Costs for the Residential Programs were mostly provided by donations through Homes of Hope, Inc.[1b] In 2015: 40 mothers (aged 14 to 27) and children found a home at the Homes of Hope campus and received safe, secure accommodation and training. Other important numbers include: 6 healthy babies born while their mothers were in the care of HoH; 9 women completed the residential program and were reintegrated into a safe community with continued support from HoH; and 21 infants and toddlers participated in early childhood education at the campus school. Additionally, 35 victims were withdrawn to attend our training programs as Day Scholars. [2] Community-Based Programs: CBT was active in strategic villages in Fiji and in the Solomon Islands. They trained community leaders to recognize indicators of sexual exploitation and to take action to break the culture of silence towards violence against women. They continued recruiting and training ""gatekeepers"" to take action to prevent and protect the victims of sexual trafficking and vulnerable individuals in each community. Costs for the Community-Based Programs were met largely by various grants and also by donations through Homes of Hope, Inc.[3] Duplication/Networking: Homes of Hope Fiji has increased its impact by sharing research, procedures, and curriculum with similarly tasked organizations and government agencies. They continue to chair a Fijian government subcommittee on Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children (CSEC). The Fiji campus has also hosted groups from organizations in the Solomon Islands, in the South Pacific, and Malawi, South Africa. Also other networking opportunities have opened in Cambodia and Guatemala. Costs were funded by donations through Homes of Hope, Inc. as well as grants.
reason: The summary focuses on community programs, vocational training, and support for women and children, without mentioning any religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: Since 1998, the Minneapolis chapter of Men Against Destruction - Defending Against Drugs and Social Disorder (MAD DADS) has been dedicated to addressing the issues of drugs, gangs, and violence in the Twin Cities. In 2012, the Minneapolis chapter also became home to the organization's national headquarters. MAD DADS' mission is to bring about positive change, and encourages, motivates, and guides committed men and women in the struggle to save children, communities, and themselves from the social ills that plague neighborhoods. We recruit and engage parents to become vocal, visible, and vigilant in restoring safe communities and healthy families. In 2020, the Minneapolis chapter of MAD DADS has served more than 80,000 families as we work to keep our communities safe. MAD DADS' programs center on crime prevention, community building, youth development, and family enrichment. MAD DADS works with males and females of all ages, focusing our support on low-income families struggling with domestic violence, crime, abuse, and other challenges. Our work spans the Twin Cities Metro area, with a focus on Minneapolis, Saint Paul, Brooklyn Park, and Brooklyn Center. All programs are included in description 1 All programs are included in description 1

mission: Through our Shelter Aid Program we provide support to various migrant shelters in Tijuana Baja California and Mexico. We provide funding to help cover the cost overrent utilities shelter construction projects and food for shelter residents. This support has become more crucial to migrant survival and well-being during the COVID-19 pandemic. The pandemic has limited cross border travel and most organizations that previously worked in Tijuana such as fail-based organizations and our own Caravans of Love have been completely halted leaving families without the donations that they once relied on. Our Shelter Aid Program assists over 900 migrants daily supporting 15 different migrant shelters in Tijuana. Groups of vounteers leave bottles of water in the desert to prevent death by thirst of border crossers. Border Angels has left thousands of gallons of water in the desert along paths most commonly traveled by migrants. On every first Saturday of the month we visit two sites where day laborers congreagate and we provide them with food water clothes and hygiene products. Our programs goal is to provide moral and emotional support and to document their stories. We also provide free immigration and employee rights consultations to those in need.

mission: LEJ serves the Bayview-Hunters Point community in Southeast San Francisco.San Francisco is a tale of two cities. On the citys western side, residents enjoy a wealth of parks such as Crissy Field and the new $118 million Presidio Tunnel Tops Park; healthy food options from large grocery stores to boutique markets to countless restaurants; and the peace of mind and freedom that comes with living in a safe, low-crime neighborhood.Across the city in the southeast, lies a different San FranciscoBayview-Hunters Point. For decades, this historically African American community has served as the dumping ground for San Franciscos dirty utilities, heavy industry, and toxic pollution. This three-square-mile industrial neighborhood is bordered by two freeways and home to 700 hazardous waste sites, 325 underground petroleum storage tanks, two Superfund sites, and decades of illegal dumping (SF Department of Public Health -SFDPH).It is also home to 34,000+ residents, 26% of whom are under the age of 18the highest percentage of children of any San Francisco neighborhood (SFDPH). According to CalEnviroScreen, 80% of Bayview-Hunters Point residents are people of color with 33% identifying as African American (the citys largest concentration of African Americans), 34% as Latinx, and 25% as Asian American. Approximately 40% of families in Bayview-Hunters Point are severely low-income, living twice below the federal poverty levela cycle of poverty that will continue without education and workforce development opportunities. Unlike families on the western side of the city, a healthy stroll around the Bayview-Hunters Point neighborhood is not an option. In addition to air pollution from heavy industry and the neighboring freeways, more than half of Bayview residents report feeling unsafe in their community. Bayview-Hunters Point has double the violent crime rate of San Francisco as a whole (SFDPH).According to the SFDPHs Bayview-Hunters Point Community Resiliency report, Bayview-Hunters Point received Low to Very Low rankings for residents access to healthy food. In addition, that same report noted that unlike other parts of San Francisco, healthy, green parklands and trees are scarce in this heavily industrialized neighborhood.LEJ serves over 1,000 SFUSD youth each year and works closely with community organizations to engage youth and young adult audiences in our environmental education and workforce development programs. We engage Bayview residents in volunteer park stewardship, workshops, and environmental advocacy.
reason: The summary focuses on environmental education, community engagement, and social issues without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: Brooklyn Montessori Ltd is a school that recognizes and values the importance of staff and teacher professional development. The professional development theme for the year was positive communication with children and adults. Each teacher was given two books to read throughout the school year. The Power of Our Words by Paula Denton and Choice Words by Peter H. Johnston were used throughout the school year in study groups and whole staff gatherings to review the chapters and concepts presented in the text. Teachers were invited to visit other schools to see examples of positive communication. The MDS PTA purchased a cooking cart that housed equipment that could be used in food preparations and cooking projects with children. Cookbooks and programs were purchased to support teachers' cooking units. Elizabeth Solomon, alumni parent and expert on childhood nutrition, presented a workshop to teachers on healthy choices for young children. We drafted a nutrition policy for the school to follow as a result of working with Elizabeth and acquiring the tools needed to increase food preparation and cooking in our curriculum and programming. With the hiring of a Montessori trained and experienced Executive Director, teachers received additional guidance on classroom environment and curriculum planning and implementation. Each classroom improved as additional Montessori equipment and literacy materials were purchased and placed out in the classroom for children to explore and learn. Teachers worked together to improve their record keeping and progress reporting practices. A standardized plan and set of forms were adopted across the school community. Goal setting forms were used to create a collaborative platform for parents and teachers to work together to support each child's individual needs and learning style. The adults revisited the goals set at the previous conference. This focused attention on action plans and allowed for reflection and feedback. This uniformed system increased the level of professionalism in communicating with parents about their child's progress and learning needs. An added parent-teacher conference improved adult relationships and created an additional opportunity for parents to discuss developmental concerns with their child's teachers in a timely manner. Brooklyn Montessori Ltd is also committed to supporting the needs of parents. The School's PTA sponsored several well-attended workshops on a variety of topics. The Executive Director explained the sequence of materials and lessons in Montessori Math. One teacher presented a parent education workshop entitled ""Montessori At Home."" The presentation presented a variety of ways that parents could involve their children in activities at home, including ways to support their children's independence, abilities to make choices and take on responsibility. Teachers also shared some of the common language that they use while communicating with children around positive discipline strategies so parents could understand how to apply this language at home. Parents also benefited from a workshop given by Joyce Szuflita, owner of NYC School Help, LLC and expert on navigating the NYC school system. She presented an informative workshop on how to choose a school that is a good match for their child and family; from application to acceptance. Parents were able to build their relationships with her through her blog, newsletter, website and individualized counseling sessions.
reason: The summary focuses on educational activities, professional development, and parental support without any mention of religious or faith-based concepts.

mission: Educated the public about Texas' film and video heritage and preservation at ""Texas Film Round-Up"" screenings and exhibits held in 3 Texas locations: Plano, Laredo and Fredericksburg. mission: RESEARCH: CENTER FOR AUTOMOTIVE RESEARCH PARTICIPATES IN SEVERAL MULTI-YEAR AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRY RELATED RESEARCH PROJECTS THAT ARE SUPPORTED BY FEDERAL, STATE, FOUNDATION AND PRIVATE INDUSTRY SOURCES. DESPITE THE PANDEMIC, CAR RESEARCHERS COMPLETED 22 RESEARCH PROJECTS, OF WHICH 2 WERE FEDERALLY FUNDED. THEY ALSO HAVE 9 PROJECTS THAT CARRY OVER TO 2021, OF WHICH 7 ARE FEDERALLY FUNDED. THE MOST SIGNIFICANT CONFERENCE OFFERED IS THE CAR MANAGEMENT BRIEFING SEMINARS (MBS). THE MBS HAS TAKEN PLACE ANNUALLY FOR MORE THAN 50 YEARS. IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING UP-TO-DATE INFORMATION ON AUTOMOTIVE RELATED TOPICS, THE SEMINARS PROVIDE NETWORKING OPPORTUNITIES TO PARTICIPANTS AND PROMOTES THE SHARING OF IDEAS. IN ADDITION TO THE MBS, CAR CONDUCTS OTHER REGIONAL AND LOCAL AUTOMOTIVE RELATED CONFERENCES. DURING THE PANDEMIC, CAR FORGED AHEAD WITH ALL VIRTUAL EVENTS. THE PREMIER MBS EVENT HAD 675 VIRTUAL ATTENDEES THAT COULD ALSO NETWORK VIA CHAT ROOMS. CAR ALSO HELD 20 OTHER SMALLER WEBINARS WITH 2,570 TOTAL REMOTE ATTENDEES.
